text: Marx is born at 2 a.m. in Trier, at Brückergasse 664 (now Brückenstrasse 10), into which the family had moved only days before, on May 1.
Heinrich Marx (father) buys the house at Simeonsgasse 1070 (now Simeonstrasse 8). The family moves in later in the year or perhaps early next year.
Engels is born at 9 p.m. in Barmen.
E is baptized in the Reformed Evangelical Parish in neighboring Elberfeld. Godparents: grandfather Caspar E and grandmother Franciska Christina van Haar.
M’s paternal grandmother, Eva Moses Lvov Marx, dies in Trier.
The children of the M family—Sophie, Hermann, Henriette, Louise, Emilie, Caroline, as well as Karl—are baptized in the Evangelical church. (For the father’s baptism, see *Marx, Heinrich.)
M’s mother Henriette is baptized in the Evangelical church.
M’s brother Eduard is born.
M’s paternal uncle, Rabbi Samuel M—the city’s rabbi-dies in Trier.
E enters the Barmen municipal school (Stadtschule) which he will attend until 1834.
M enters Trier’s Friedrich-Wilhelm-Gymnasium (high school) (-* 35:3).
(1832-34) M may well have become a member of a “Young German Literary Circle” which exists at the high school.
M’s sister Sophie starts a poetry notebook, which she will work on until 1837; it contains some poems by young M, incl his earliest known (see #M661).
Young E writes a poem “To my grandfather” (#E811).

M’s father Heinrich participates in, and gives a political toast at, a liberal banquet in favor of representative government, held by the Casino Society; as a result he comes under surveillance by the Prussian government.
A similar banquet leads to government harassment of many participants.
M is confirmed in the Evangelical church, by Pastor J. A.  Küpper, religious instructor at M’s high school. The godfathers include three of Heinrich M's fellow lawyers and a government official.
He enters the Elberfeld Gymnasium (high school) [-> 37:12]. For some indications about E’s work there, see #E472.5.
E graduates from the Barmen municipal school [<— 1829].
Religious essay (#M956); also Greek trans (of Sophocles’ Trachiniae, verses 140-76, passage headed “Deianira”).
M takes final examinations at the Trier Gymnasium and writes examination exercises (Abiturientenarbeiten).
German essay (#M729).
French trans (of passage headed “Exemples, qui servent ä prouver, que l’homme peut motiver les influences du climat, qu’il habite”).
Mathematics exercise (one each in geometry, trigonometry, and algebra).
Latin essay (#M251).
Extempore Latin trans (of passage headed “De Hemsterhusii moribus”). (For the text of all exercises, incl those not in the Register, see MEGA I, 1.2:164 or New Mega I, 1:449.)
M graduates from the Trier Gymnasium [«- 30:1); receives his graduation certificate, with a summary of his schoolwork.
M leaves Trier for Bonn, to begin studies at the university there.
M matriculates at the university, beginning studies in the Law Department (jurisprudence).

M attends the following lectures: jurisprudence, with Puggö; institutions, with Booking; history of Roman law, with Walter; mythology of Greece and Rome, with Welcker; Homer, with Schlegel; modern art history, with D’Alton.
E enters the second form (Sekunda) at the Elberfeld Gymnasium. (For some extant schoolwork, notebooks, and exercises, etc., see #E351.5, 528.5.)
His father writes M his first long letter, full of advice and encouragement.

M is a member of the Assoc of Trier Students. He participates, together with E. Geibel, Karl Grün, et al, in a poetry circle, which enters into competition with a Göttingen circle (whose members include Bernays, H. B. Oppenheim, Creizenach, etc.).
During the Christmas holidays, M journeys to Nijmegen (Neth.) to visit his mother’s Dutch relatives, till Jan A.
M spends the Easter holiday at his parents in Trier.
M gets involved in debts; his father sends extra money to cover them.
M attends lectures on history of German law, with Walter; Propertius, with Schlegel; European international law and natural law, with Pugg6.
M is charged with “making a row at night, and drunkenness”; sentenced by the university proctor to one day’s detention ()une 16-17).
M’s father signs the consent form for his transfer from Bonn to the U. of Berlin
Still at Bonn, M is involved in a duel and wounded above one eye.

The Bonn administration issues M’s Certificate of Release, summarizing his record. It mentions that a charge of carrying prohibited weapons in Cologne is still under investigation; but M is not suspected of involvement in “any forbidden assoc“ of students.
M spends the summer holiday in Trier. He gets secretly engaged to Jenny von Westphalen.
E finishes the second form (Sekunda) at the Elberfeld Gymnasium [«- 35:6).
M matriculates in the Law Department of the university (Friedrich Wilhelm Univ.; today, Humboldt Univ.).
M moves to the capital; address, Mittelstrasse 61.
M attends lectures in the Pandects, with Savigny; criminal law, with Gans; anthropology, with H. Steffens.
M puts together three notebooks of poems (Book of Songs; Book of Love, Parts I and II) (#M662), and sends them to Jenny (Trier).
Concerned by Jenny's difficult position re the secret engagement, M’s father and sister Sophie press M to plan how to resolve the situation.
Father urges M to face up to the duty of straightening the situation out, presumably by getting a commercial job.

Father writes M of his concern that the son should quickly fit himself to earn a living so that marriage can solve the sticky situation; he urges getting an academic post fast, even if a low one. He warns: “Your views on law are not without truth, but are very likely to arouse storms if made into a system--”
(Winter 1838/37) M tries to work out a new theory of law and jurisprudence (cf #M61), which he will outline in a letter (#M455).

In the summer semester M attends lectures on church law, common German lawsuits, and Prussian lawsuits, all with Heffter. He carries on studies in jurisprudence, reads i.a. Savigny’s Right of ownership, Feuerbach’s Penal law, Grolmann’s Principles of criminal science; he translates Aristotle’s Rhetoric, reads Bacon’s Advancement of learning, and Reimarus’s Von den Kunsttrieben der Tiere.

M continues working on his new philosophical presentation of law and jurisprudence (#M61) [*- 36:15); it remains unfinished. He carries on philosophical and historical studies, incl studies on Hegel. He establishes his lifelong habit of filling notebooks with excerpts and notes on books read.
M puts together a poetry album dedicated to his father on his birthday (#M663), incl a “comic novel” Scorpion and Felix (#M811) and a drama OuJanem (#M623) [-* :6).
Around this time M writes the two poems which will later be pubd as “Wild Songs” (#M992) [-*41:41.
Father’s letter wonders whether M’s “demon” is “heavenly or Faustian,” and expresses forebodings about his course.
Father writes M approvingly on his adjustment to the university, etc.

E is confirmed at the United Evangelical church in Lower Barmen. The biblical motto selected by local pastors is Phil. 3:13-14: “... forgetting those things which are behind, and reaching forth unto those things which are before, I press toward the mark....”
M makes an intensive study of Hegel’s philosophy and the Hegelian school, and makes the acquaintance of the Young Hegelian circle.
M moves to Stralau, near Berlin, on his doctor’s advice, because of overwork.
M presents the poetry album (#M663) [«- :4] to his father.

About this time (summer) M writes a philosophic dialogue “Cleanthes” (#M149) on “the starting point and necessary progress of philosophy.” Also, around summer-autumn he writes a piece called “The visit” (#M967), which his father later calls an extract from Karl’s diary.

In the summer semester M attends lectures on church law, common German lawsuits, and Prussian lawsuits, all with Heffter. He carries on studies in jurisprudence, reads i.a. Savigny’s Right of ownership, Feuerbach’s Penal law, Grolmann’s Principles of criminal science; he translates Aristotle’s Rhetoric, reads Bacon’s Advancement of learning, and Reimarus’s Von den Kunsttrieben der Tiere.
Doctors Club. M enters the circle of the Doctors Club (Young Hegelians) and makes the acquaintance of Bruno and Edgar Bauer, Rutenberg, Köppen, et al.
M’s father, who is quite ill and staying at Bad Ems for his bad health, writes chidingly, urging more consideration for the parents.
Father sends more advice on studies and preparations to enter the legal profession.
M participates in plans to publish a magazine on theater criticism, with contributions from the Hegelian school.
Father’s letter to M weighs alternatives on what field to prepare for—law, writing, academia, etc.
On his father’s insistence, E leaves high school (Gymnasium) before completing it, to begin work as a commercial assistant in his father’s firm in Barmen.
At the school's public ceremony, E reads a Greek poem of his composition in epic verse (#E745).
A school-leaving certificate is issued to E as of this date.
M sends some poems for publ to Chamisso’s Deutsche Musen-Almanach; they are rejected.
Winter semester: M attends only the lectures on criminal trials, by Heffter.

M writes a long letter (the only extant letter to his father) reviewing his university life, intellectual crises, and strivings during this first year in Berlin, esp his conversion to Hegelianism (#M455).
His father, in reply, chides him for this letter “without form or content....”
Father writes with irritation and apprehension about M’s failure to ensure earning a living instead of “misty excursions” and “brooding.”
M’s brother Eduard, 12, dies of tuberculosis, in Trier.
M’s father, beset by sinking health, sends a somewhat milder version of previous criticisms [«-37:16], ending on a note of perplexity and resignation.
M’s mother writes urging him to avoid the year of military service on medical grounds. Around this time M suffers from heart trouble (cardiac dilation), also eye trouble.
M receives a medical certificate, sent on to him by his mother, releasing him from military service for medical reasons (“chest weakness and periodic coughing-up of blood”).
M revises, with corrections and additions, a pamphlet written by his father on the Cologne church dispute (#M252).
M’s father dies in Trier, of tuberculosis and liver ailments.
M attends lectures on logic, with Gabler; general geography, with Ritter; Prussian common law, with Gans. Gabler and Gans mark him “very diligent.”
E, prob with his father, goes on a trip to the Netherlands and England; first, down the Rhine to Rotterdam.
E stops in Rotterdam.
E goes by paddle steamer from Rotterdam to London, then by railway to Manchester.
E is in Manchester, where the firm of Ermen & Engels is established by a merger with Peter Ermen.
E goes to Bremen, either direct from London or via Amsterdam.

E takes up life [cf «- :2] as a clerk in training in the commercial house of Heinrich Leupold, boarding with the minister G. G. Treviranus (source: ST/56; but MEW Daten puts arrival for duties in Bremen at July M).
E’s first pubd writing is a poem in a Bremen paper (#E73).
M attends lectures only on inheritance law, with Rudorff; he is marked “diligent.”
In a letter to a friend, E includes a poem “Florida” (#E281) on the American Indians as freedom fighters.
E sends a friend an unpubd poem, “The Pietist declares his love” (#E211).
He gets a second poem (#E840) into a Bremen paper.
E writes and pubs his first article, “Letters from the Wuppertal,” in the Young Germany organ T/D, in six installs (#E452).
E pubs a third poem in a Bremen paper (#E94), signed “Theodor Hildebrandt.”
For his T/D article, see <- :5; this article scandalizes the Barmen-Elberfeld (Wuppertal) district.
In personal letters, E includes other poems of his (#E231, 357, 590A).
He gets a fourth poem into a Bremen paper (#E816), also by “Hildebrandt.”
During the summer semester M attends lectures in only one course, on Isaiah, with Bruno Bauer. He is prob also continuing his dissertation work on Greek philosophy.
He pubs another article in T/D, on F. W. Krummacher (#E263).
In response to attacks on his Wuppertal article (#E452), E pubs a reply in an Elberfeld paper (#E572).
E sends a friend a poem titled “German July days, 1839“ (#E332); it looks to a revolution against the German kings and princes, like the French “July revolution” of 1830.
M corresponds with B. Bauer in Bonn. He works on logic studies, reads and excerpts Aristotle’s De anima, and plans a work polemizing against F. A. Trendelenburg. [-* 40:4).

After B. Bauer departs from Berlin for a post in Bonn, M becomes close friends with Köppen. He now plans to cover all of Epicurean, Stoic, and Skeptical philosophy in his dissertation, and looks forward to qualifying for the Bonn faculty after graduation [-> 40:6).
E pubs two more articles in TfD (#E300, 330), the first signed “S. Oswald,” the second “Friedrich Oswald” (which will be his pen name for the next period)
He writes another article, “Karl Beck” (#E404) [—► :11], and begins “Retrograde signs of the times” (#E683) H 40:5).
E pubs “Karl Beck” in TfD (#E404) [<— :10). He writes “Platen” (#E586) [-> 40:5].

M works on a satire directed against K. P. Fischer’s Idee der Gottheit, to be called “Fischer vapulans”: not finished, not extant. He also continues, or perhaps begins, working on his anti-Trendelenburg polemic [<— 39:9]
E works on two articles for TfD (#E400, 677) [-* :8].
For M, see <- :4. E pubs more articles in TfD, “Retrograde signs ...” (#E683) and “Platen” (#E586) [«- 39:10,11].
M works with B. Bauer on the latter’s edition of Hegel’s Philosophy of religion, and intends to write a work on the subject itself.
E pubs his first article of literary criticism (#E491).
M’s friend pubs Friedrich der Grosse und seine Widersacher, with a dedication to “my friend Karl Heinrich Marx of Trier.”
E pubs more articles in TfD (#E400, 677, 536) [♦- :4 for the first two].
M’s mother writes him that since her husband’s death the Westphalen family has become less friendly.
E travels around Westphalia, visits Münster, and meets Levin Schücking.
E writes a travel piece (#E414) [-* :12].
E’s travel piece (#E414) [«- :11] is pubd in T/D.
M plans a book criticizing Georg Hermes’ ideas, and through Bauer tries to get a publisher in Bonn.
E pubs the first two articles (#E804, 454) in a series (#E674) of socioliterary essays on Bremen life, in the Morgenblatt.
E takes a trip (July 5) to Bremerhaven, and soon afterward writes it up as an article (#E575) for the Morgenblatt, which, however, will publish it only a year later [-> 41:15]
He pubs a poem “An evening” (#E256) in T/D, and offers satirical verse in a letter (#E590B).
E breaks into the prestigious Allgemeine Ztg of Augsburg (AZ) with reportage (#E506).
E writes an article on Krummacher (#E881), pubd in T/D this month. He also writes four pieces pubd in Oct, q.v.
He offers an ode to mustaches (#E590C) in a letter, and begins writing a long essay on Arndt (#E248) [-> :18].
AZ pubs another piece of reportage (#E729).
Morgenblatt pubs a literary essay (#E550), and two more in the series on Bremen life (#E651, 737).
T/D pubs a poem on Napoleon (#E721); E writes a poem on Siegfried (#E743) [-+ :18).
AZ pubs two reportage pieces (#E184, 780).
M takes only one course, on Euripides with Geppert— “diligent attendance.”

Besides publishing the Siegfried poem (#E743) [«- :16) in T/D, E works, around the turn of the year, on an opera libretto “Cola di Rienzi” with a political-historical theme; unfinished (#E149). Around the end of the year E writes the poems “Night journey” (#E524) [-* 41:5) and “Imperial cortege” (#E370) [-► 41.-6]; also around the turn of the year, an article on Immermann (#E368) [—► 41:10]. He finishes the article on Arndt (#E248) [<- :15;-> 41:5].
For M's notes on Leibnitz and Hume, see #M79
Athenäum pubs two of his poems, "Wild songs" (#M992)--his first pubd work.
M gets acquainted with Eduard Meyen
E pubs the long Arndt article (#E248) in TfD [<- 40:15, 18], also the poem "Night journey" (#E524) [<- 40:18] in Deutscher Courier.
E pubs three articles (#E233, 663, 456) in the ongoing Bremen series (#E674).
E pubs the poem "Imperial cortege" (#E370) [<- 40:18] in TfD
The Augsburg AZ pubs its last E article (#E425).
In preparation for publishing it, M writes a dedication, a foreword, and some notes (#M236-37, 240).
For M's notes on Spinoza and on Rosenkranz's book on Kant, see #M79.
This is the date on M's leaving certificate from the U. of Berlin.
M finishes his doctoral dissertation [<- 40:1].
E leaves Bremen and returns to Barmen.
M sends his dissertation to Prof. Bachmann, philosophy dean at the U. of Jena (application form, #M475; curriculum vitae, #M210).
Prof. Bachmann praises the dissertation and recommends granting the degree.
M receives the Ph.D. degree from Jena (the document is so dated).
M travels from Berlin, via Frankfurt, to Trier, where he will stay till July A.
Since E attacked Paniel in the Morgenblatt (#E233), when the paper praises Paniel, E sends a polemical "Statement" (#E774) which is rejected; E ceases contributions to the paper.
E pubs an article on Immermann in TfD (#E368) [<- 40:18].
With his father, E leaves on a trip to Switzerland and northern Italy.
They stay at the Three Kings Hotel in Basel
At the Hotel Baur in downtown Zürich.
At the Red Lion Inn in Chur.
They travel through the Splügen Pass and Chiavenna to Milan.
Details on E's tour through northern Italy in June-July are not available. Perhaps E now drafted his "Wanderings in Lombardy" (#E897), which he began publishing in Dec [-> :23]; see Register.
E and his father return from Italy to Barmen.
M studies Feuerbach's Essence of Christianity
M moves from Trier to Bonn to seek a post at the university. Here M remains close to Bauer until the latter leaves for Berlin (May A, 1842).
M helps Bauer as the latter writes the polemical pamphlet The trumpet of the last judgment on Hegel... (pubd Nov A).
E's article on his trip to Bremerhaven (#E575)--which he wrote over a year ago [<- 40:12]--is at last pubd in the Morgenblatt, as the last-pubd part of E's series on Bremen life (#E674).
M is drawn into the work of founding the Rheinische Ztg, through G. Jung and Hess in Cologne.

M and Bauer plan a joint Part 2 of The trumpet of the last judgement... In this connection M studies the history of art and religion, and starts a critical examination of Hegel's political theory (Rechtsphilosophie); cf #M204.
Hess writes a friend that young M is the greatest living philosopher.
E leaves Barmen for Berlin as a one-year volunteer in the artillery to do his required military service. For his sojourn in Berlin, see -> 42:1
En route, E stops over in Brunswick, possibly looking up the pub'r G. C. E. Meyer.
E arrives in Berlin
(autumn) E begins to attend lectures at the U. of Berlin and frequents the Berlin circle of Young Hegelians; begins studying Feuerbach's Essence of Christianity (sometime in the second half of 1841).
E begins military service
(autumn) After Bauer is suspended from the Bonn faculty, M abandons hope of getting a university post.

M begins working on a critique of Hegel's philosophy of right (Rechtsphilosophie, legal and political theory), esp his theory of constitutional monarchy (cf #M204) [->42:9]; also on an essay on religion and art (cf #M595)
E attends an important lecture by Schelling at the university, and writes a polemic, "Schelling on Hegel" (#E727) [-> :23]
(and turn of the year) M once again plans to publish his dissertation (#M235) [<- :7] and to this end drafts a new foreword (#M238).
E's first polemic against Schelling is pubd in TfD (#E727) [<- :21]. He also begins working on an anti-Schelling pamphlet (#E726), continued after the turn of the year [-> 42:9].
E pubs travel sketches of his trip [<- :11-13] in a Young Hegelian magazine (#E897)
M stays in town with Ludwig von Westphalen, who is very ill [-* :7).
Re M’s plans for his dissertation at the tum-of-the-year period, see «-41:22.
Rutenberg, whom M has recommended for the post of RZ editor, gets the job.
M writes his first political article, on censorship and freedom of the press (#M156); but it will not be pubd for over a year [—> 43:6].
M informs Ruge of this intention, and also sends the now-finished article on freedom of the press (#M156), for the Deutsche Jahrbücher [«— :5).
M contemplates writing two critical articles for the Deutsche Jahrbücher, on W. Vatke and K. Bayer.
Ludwig von Westphalen dies in Trier.
M resumes his study of the history of religion and art, begun last Sep («- 41:16]. He has apparently drafted, or outlined, an essay on “Christian art.”
For M’s “Bonn notebooks” on the history of art and religion, see #M93.
M writes Ruge that this essay should be pubd in the Anekdota. He also begins to rewrite his critique of Hegel’s political theory (#M204) I*- 41:20) as a contribution to the Anekdota.

M writes Ruge that the essay on Christian art is to be rewritten as one “On religion and art, with special reference to Christian art.” He promises it for Apr M; but he cancels his plan for an article on Hegel's philosophy of right.
E's first pamphlet against Schelling (#E726) [«- 41:23] is pubd. E writes his first article for RZ, on liberalism (#E526) [—► :12].
For M’s “Bonn notebooks” on art and religion, see #M93 and «- :8.
He moves to Bonn, where he resumes close assoc with Bauer.
M receives a visit from the theologian F. R. Hasse of Greifswald, who is prob at the U. of Bonn.
M first moves to Cologne, but finds the atmosphere unconducive to work.
M writes the last-listed article as “The philosophic manifesto of the historical school of law" (#M655) [—► :22].
M writes his first article for HZ, a second article on freedom of the press (#M216) |-* :14); it deals with the proceedings of the Rhineland Diet of May-July 1841.

Writing to Ruge, M now promises four essays: on religion and art [«— :8], “On the romanticists” (cf #M613), “The positive philosophers” (#M680), and (the only one actually written and pubd) on the historical school of law.
E pubs his first HZ article (#E526) [*— :9].
M comes home because of the death of a younger brother, Hermann; he will stay until July M.
M writes the second article in this series (#M217). which never appears because of the censorship.
M pubs his first article in HZ, dealing with the Diet debates on freedom of the press (#M216) |<— :11], first of a series on Diet proceedings.
M begins a reply to a Hess article on centralization; it remains an unfinished fragment (#M722).
He pubs three more articles in HZ (#E224, 703,467), and writes another (#E591) [“* :!»]•
E pubs a second pamphlet against Schelling (#E728).
M’s mother blocks his getting any money from his father’s estate; she deplores his refusal to embrace an academic or governmental career; M has to postpone his marriage plans.
Re the censored second article in the Rhineland Diet series (#M217), see «— :14 [-+ :20].
M writes a polemical article against K. H. Hermes in defense of the Young Hegelians (#M448) [—► :20).
E works with Edgar Bauer on the satiric “epic” The triumph of faith (#E872) [-> :36].
E pubs four articles in HZ (#E591, 577.5, 453, 240), and writes another (#E549) [-> :21).
E writes a long article on Alexander Jung (#E684) [-» :21).
M’s sister Sophie is married to a Maastricht lawyer, W. K. Schmalhausen.
M moves from Trier back to Bonn.

M writes Ruge that he plans to publish the censored article (#M217) [<— :14] on the Cologne church dispute as a brochure if necessary. He also criticizes the Berlin group “Die Freie” (The Free) as empty phrasemongers.
M’s polemic against Hermes (#M448) [<— :17] is pubd in HZ.
E pubs the long article on A. Jung (#E684) [*- :18] in Deutsche Jahrbücher.
E pubs another article (#E549) [<— :18] in HZ.
M influences the editing of HZ through his letters to Oppenheim and G. Jung.
M’s article on the historical school of law, written for the Anekdota (#M655) [<- :11|, is pubd in RZ.

Writing to D. Oppenheim, M says he plans to write a number of articles for RZ, including one on civil rights for Jews (attacking K. H. Hermes), a critique of Edgar Bauer’s antiliberal articles in RZ, and one on the system of Rhenish municipal government.
E includes light verse in a letter to his sister (#E590D).
E ends his (unofficial) attendance at the university, in anticipation of the end of his military service.
E has two articles pubd in RZ (#E262, 77).
M writes an article on Bauer and academic freedom (#M995) |—► :31).
E pubs an article on “Centralization and freedom” (#El32) in RZ.
E’s period of military service ends.
M is installed as editor-in-chief. The same day, he writes a rejoinder to the Augsburg AZ on communism and the RZ position (#M165), pubd Oct 16; a follow-up comment is pubd Oct 23 (#M166).
M accepts the editorship and moves to Cologne.

M writes the third article in the Rhineland Diet series, on the debates over the wood-theft law (#M218); pubd in RZ, Oct 25 to Nov 3. Around this time M participates in a weekly gathering of the RZ circle discussing the “Social Question" and tariff policy, which will continue meeting into 1843. M studies French socialism: Fourier, Cabet, Dezamy (CaJomnies et politique de M. Cabet), Leroux, Considörant, Proudhon (What is property?).
M gets acquainted with Karl Heinzen.
E arrives in Frankfurt: perhaps visits his brother Hermann, who is in training in a bank.
E stays in Cologne at the Bonn Inn; meets Hess, prob also Peter Ermen (of the Manchester firm), but he is unable to meet with RZ editor Marx.
E arrives home in Barmen.
With the end of his military service [«— :25] E leaves Berlin.
E writes a programmatic article on Prussian politics (#E299) which will be pubd some months later |—► 43:19).
M pubs a number of articles in RZ (#M164. 188, 123, 669), also ed notes (#M473, 601, 64); for Dubiosa, see #M265. A sharp conflict starts developing with the government censorship.

In reply to a Nov 12 threat from the government, M sends a letter to the governor on behalf of the RZ pub’r (#M456), defending the right to independent expression. The RZ shareholders are also pressing for “moderation.”
This Berlin Young Hegelian circle (“The Free”) is dissatisfied with M’s treatment of their contributions.
M receives a letter from Herwegh on his and Ruge's conflict with the Berliners, also a letter from E. Meyen on behalf of the group.
M writes the Berlin group his own criticism of their radical phrasemongering.
M pubs a piece in RZ (#M64) reporting Herwegh’s and Ruge’s attitude, ed by M. This public rebuff, plus others, produces a definitive break.
M writes Ruge that he has replied sharply to Meyen and expects a break.
M’s article on Bauer and academic freedom (#M995) is pubd in Deutsche Jahrbücher [«— :24).

En route, with a friend K. A. Erbslöh, E stops in Cologne, staying at the Wiener Hof Hotel. Here he visits the RZ office and meets M for the first time, a cool meeting since M thinks E is associated with the “Free’’ group (source: ST/56; KMC says Nov c.24; MEW Daten, Nov CD).
E takes the ship Sir Edward Banks from Ostend to England.
E spends some days in London before going on to Manchester.

E writes two articles on the “internal crises’’ in England for AZ, without even unpacking all his bags (#E247, 379) [—► :36). (Note: E will later write in a letter that he arrived in Manchester “at the end of Nov”; perhaps.)
E sets out to take up a post in the family firm in Manchester.
M pubs a long three-part article on the estates-committees (#M869).
M writes and pubs an article exposing the government's divorce bill (#M249).

M is informed that the Moselle correspondent Peter Coblenz, who had pubd three articles on the plight of the wine-growing peasants (Nov 15 to Dec 18) which had displeased the governor, is the recipient of official charges, and Coblenz has declared himself unable to write an effective reply; therefore M himself must undertake it. He begins on it (#M965) Dec D or Jan 1 [-► 43:4).
M perhaps begins writing #M667; see —► 43:5.
M works on the first of a number of polemical articles against other papers on the issue of the government ban against the Leipziger Allgemeine Ztg (#M72) ]-> 43:4).
M goes to Kreuznach to visit Jenny.
In Manchester E becomes acquainted with Mary Burns; they become lovers (time uncertain).
E arrives to complete his commercial apprenticeship in the office of Ermen & Engels; for an overview, see —► 43:2.
The anonymous pamphlet The triumph of faith (#E872) [«- :18] is pubd in Germany.
E’s first articles on England (#E247, 379) |«- :32 (Nov 29-30)] are pubd in RZ. ed by M.
E pubs three more articles in RZ (#E597,170,186) on English politics and economics, incl his first “condition of England” article (#E170).

M writes [«- 42:33] and pubs a series of polemical articles on the government ban against the Leipziger Allgemeine Ztg (#M72, 431, 352, 741, 742, 233, 781). He researches the situation of the Moselle peasants in order to reply to the governor's charges against RZ [«- 42:33).
M announces (#M41) and then pubs the first two parts of his “vindication” of the Moselle articles (#M965) [-> :6).
The Prussian government decides to ban RZ as of Apr 1 and to put it under stricter censorship till then. (This decision is dated Jan 21 in some places.)
RZ is officially informed of the ban.
Writing to Rüge, M says he is eager to leave RZ and quit the stifling atmosphere of Germany; he intends to get married and work with Herwegh in Zurich on editing a new periodical.
A Cologne protest meeting of about 100 condemns the RZ suppression, with a petition to the king (text: MECW 1:710) [—► :6 (Feb 18)].
M pubs ed notes polemizing against the Augsburg Allgemeine Ztg (#M667, 668).
For an example of M’s editing of a correspondent’s article, see #M187.
M drafts notes for replying to the ban on RZ (#M585); perhaps also drafts a memorandum (#M507?).
The censor bans M’s Part 3 of the Moselle article (#M965; cf #M966) (<- :4 (Jan 3-20)]; M abandons the project.

A special meeting of RZ shareholders votes for moderating the paper’s policy, M voting with the minority. The meeting adopts a petition (signed also by M) promising a more moderate tone but not repudiating past policy. (This petition will be pressed on the government by Oppenheim et al during Feb-Mar.)
The Jan 30 petition is sent to Berlin with 911 signatures.

M, who aims to persuade the government to lift the RZ ban if he ceases to be editor, works at getting an article pubd in the Mannheimer Abendzeitung which portrays him as the “evil spirit” of RZ; this article is pubd Feb 28.
M persuades the censor Saint-Paul, in the course of discussions, to recommend to the government that the RZ ban be lifted after M resigns.
M’s article on freedom of the press (#M156) written in early 1842 [*- 42:5] now appears in the Anekdota.
Ruge proposes that M become coeditor of a new periodical replacing the suppressed Deutsche Jahrbücher, to be pubd in Switzerland [—► :11].
M is pressed by Herwegh to collaborate on the planned Deutsche Bote aus der Schweiz.
M pubs his last three articles in the paper (#M477, 782, 866).
M formally resigns as editor, and pubs a statement (#M38).
The king decides to confirm the RZ suppression.
The shareholders’ petition of Feb 12 is officially denied.
Ditto the citizens’ petition of Jan 30.
M visits Jenny in Trier.
M goes on a trip to the Netherlands, presumably to discuss the matter of his inheritance with his mother’s Dutch relatives.
M writes Ruge proposing that the new magazine [«- :7] be jointly ed by them and be pubd in Strasbourg (France) together with French leftist Democrats.

Writing to Ruge, M is enthusiastic about their plans for the magazine, to be called the Deutsch-Französische Jahrbücher (DFJ), pubd outside of Germany (Strasbourg or Switzerland); he announces his coming marriage (“head over heels in love”). Shortly before Mar 13 he has received from Ruge the Anekdota issue containing his article (#M156) [«-:6], in which he reads Feuerbach’s latest essay “Preliminary theses toward the reformation of philosophy”—which, he comments to Ruge, is insufficiently concerned with politics.

While traveling in Holland (see«- :10) he writes Ruge on the necessity of revolution in Germany; this letter will later be pubd in DFJ (#M471); Ruge’s pessimistic reply will be pubd in the same exchange of letters.
M replies to Ruge's pessimistic letter [«- :11] with the second of his programmatic DFJ letters (cf #M471).
M goes to Dresden for a few days to discuss the planned DFJ with Ruge.
M moves to Kreuznach where Jenny is living with her mother.
Continuing the reports on England he had done for the now banned RZ, E starts publishing a series of four articles on England in a Swiss paper (#E447); the first two are pubd May 16 and 23 [—► :17].
E enters into relations with the leaders of the League of the Just— Schapper, Moll, H. Bauer, et al.
M and Jenny sign the marriage contract.
M, 25, marries Jenny von Westphalen, 29, in Kreuznach at 10 a.m. (cf MECW 3:571); they stay in Kreuznach for their honeymoon.
M receives and rejects an offer, made via J. P. Esser (Prussian official, friend of M’s father), to enter into the state’s service as editor of a government publ.
E pubs the last two articles of a series on England (#E447) [«-: 14] in a Swiss paper.
M works on his critique of Hegel’s political theory (#M206; cf preliminary work #M204), along with extensive reading and note-taking (see-* :32).
Ruge comes to visit, to discuss problems of issuing DFJ.
E’s important article on Prussia (#E299) [«- 42:28] is pubd in the collection Einundzwanzig Bogen (ST/31).

Still on honeymoon, M prob works on his critique of Hegel (#M206) [«- :18] and on a draft program for DFJ (#M254). Ruge’s reply (-*— :12] continues the programmatic exchange of correspondence (#M471).
M addresses a final letter to Ruge [«- :20] in the programmatic exchange of letters for DFJ (#M471).
M and Ruge finally fix on Paris as place of publ.
Perhaps M starts work on his essay on the Jewish question (#M609)—see—► :22.
M works on his essay ”On the Jewish question” (#M609), prob finished later in autumn in Paris (pubd in DFJ, —► 44:6).
M writes Feuerbach asking him to collaborate on DFJ, suggesting an article against Schelling.
Feuerbach declines.
M and his wife move from Kreuznach to Paris (rue Vanneau, in the Faubourg St-Germain, first at no. 23, then no. 31, finally settling at no. 38).
E visits the office of the Northern Star in Leeds, perhaps referred by James Leach, and gets acquainted with editor Harney.
E begins writing his first article for the Owenite New Moral World, marking the start of his collaboration with this movement (-+ :27].
E writes his seminal article on polit eco (#E576) for DFJ, and sends it off (MEW dating: end of 1843 to Jan) [-► 44:6].
M makes connections with the French Democrats and socialists and leaders of workers’ secret societies; he attends meetings of German and French workers’ groups.

By this date (as M informs DFJ pub’r Fröbel) M has gotten busy on the editorial work, held ’’protracted discussions” on rejected articles with Hess and others, and carried on editorial correspondence, while awaiting Ruge’s arrival in Paris.
E pubs his first article in the Owenite NMW (repr’d Nov 11, 25 in the Chartist NS), reporting on the state of the Continental movement (#E623).
M and Ruge publish a statement on Lamartine and DFJ (#M459) in Dömocratie Pacifique.
M begins work on his intro to a critique of Hegel for DFJ (#M205) [-> 44:4].

Around the end of this year (perhaps Nov-Dec) M begins an intensive study of the history of the French Revolution, with the idea of writing a history of the Convention; M reads such works as Blanc’s Histoire de dix ans; see —► :32, 33, for a list of authors. At the same time M also reads in polit eco, taking notes on Adam Smith, Say, Skarbek, et al.
M becomes acquainted with Heine through Ruge; Heine soon becomes a close friend and regular visitor.
E makes the acquaintance of Georg Weerth, the revolutionary German poet; they become friends.
E continues writing on the Continental movement, with an article (#E622) pubd in NS and repr’d in NMW.

M completes his intro to Hegel’s political theory (#M205) for publ in DFJ [-> :6] and receives E’s two articles for DFJ (#E576, 169). He continues his reading on the French Revolution, e.g., his notes on Levasseur (#M338).
E writes an important article reviewing Carlyle’s Past and present (#E169) for DFJ.
E pubs a note on the Times and the German movement (#E808) in the Owenite NMW.
E sends NMW a correction on this note (#E296) |-> :7].

The first (and last) issue, a double number, appears in Paris, in about 1000 copies (800 of which will be confiscated by the German police). Besides the programmatic letters by M (#M471), it contains four important articles: M’s essay on the Jewish question (#M609) [<- 43:22) and his introductory critique of Hegel (#M205) [<-:4]; E’s article on polit eco (#E576) [«- 43:25] and his review of Carlyle (#E169) [«- :5].
E begins work on a series of articles on the “condition of England,” originally intended for DFJ; he completes the first one (#E167) [-* :29).
Three pieces by E are pubd in one day—two in NMW (#E296,182), one in NS (#E618)—all dealing with reports about the Continental movement.
M writes a letter to Ruge breaking relations; the immediate trigger is Ruge’s attacks on Herwegh, with whom M enters a close friendship this spring.
Relations become strained as a result of business friction over DFJ and Ruge’s hostility to communist ideas, which M is now espousing.
M receives a visit from Count Cieszkowski.
H. J. Claessen (in Cologne) sends M the sum of 1000 talers, a fund collected from former HZ supporters on G. Jung's initiative as financial subvention for M’s activities in the Paris movement.

At an international Democratic “banquet” (political meeting), M meets a number of Russian 6migr6s and travelers, incl Bakunin, V. P. Botkin, G. M. Tolstoy, and French Democrats and socialists, incl Leroux, L. Blanc, F. Pyat, V. Schoelcher, as well as other emigres, Bemays, Ribbentrop, et al; they all discuss questions of theory and politics.
annos: ('meet','M','Bakunin','?'); ('meet','M','V. P. Botkin','?'); ('meet','M','G. M. Tolstoy','?'); ('meet','M','Leroux','?'); ('meet','M','L. Blanc','?'); ('meet','M','F. Pyat','?'); ('meet','M','V. Schoelcher','?'); ('meet','M','Bernays','?'); ('meet','M','Ribbentrop','?');

text: In the course of his economic readings, M reads James Mill’s Elements of political economy (in French) and sets down a comment which turns into his first significant statement on economics (#M303).
E writes the second article (#E168) [«- :7] in the “condition of England” series [-► :36).
To counter press rumors, M sends the Augsburg AZ a statement on the suspension of DFJ (#M460); pubd Apr 20.

On the basis of M's DFJ articles, the Prussian government charges him with “high treason and läse majestä,” and issues a warrant for his arrest if he enters Prussia. (Under June D, KMC says that this news and press reports about it reach M in Paris.)
Roland Daniels of Cologne visits M.
Around this month M enters into personal relations with the Paris leaders of the League of the Just (e.g., Ewerbeck) and of secret workers’ societies, without joining any group.
M begins drafting the Economic and philosophical mss (#M261), the “first ms” being written c.Apr-May.
E continues his study of English economics and workers’ conditions, collecting material for his planned work on English history and workers’ conditions; this preparatory work will continue till Aug.
E comes to an agreement with NS to send regular articles on Continental affairs [—► :17].
M’s first child is born, named Jenny.
NS pubs an announcement, in the form of an unsigned letter by E, promising regular articles on the Continental movement (#E441).
NS pubs six pieces by E, mainly on Germany (#E750, 515, 273, 74, 577), one on Russia (#E518).
Mass actions by hungry weavers against their local exploiters are bloodily repressed by military force [—► :25].
Jung writes M that the Silesian revolt is a brilliant confirmation of M’s thesis in DFJ on the role of the proletariat (#M205).
M and Jung plan the smuggling of DFJ into Germany; M also criticizes B. Bauer’s Allgemeine Literatur-Ztg.
She takes the baby (“Jennychen”) to Trier, to be shown to the two grandmothers; soon after arrival, the baby falls ill, but is pulled through [-* :34].
NS, as promised in May, pubs four articles by E, on Switzerland (#E145), France (#E514), and Prussia (#E517, 318).

M gets acquainted with Proudhon and begins discussions with him, i.a. on Hegelianism. —M begins to associate, until c.Sep, with the physician Georg Weber of Kiel, and helps him write for Vorwärts, with which M is also beginning to collaborate; M enters into closer relations with the Vorwärts circle, incl Bernays, Bömstein, Weill, et al.
Writing to G. Jung, M again [<— :19) criticizes Bauer’s Allgemeine Literatur-Ztg; Jung sends recent issues, incl a review of Sue’s Mystöres de Paris.
Vorwärts pubs an article signed “A Prussian” (Ruge) on “The king of Prussia and social reform,” in which Ruge poohpoohs the Silesian revolt and retreats from revolutionary oppositionism.
M writes a reply to Ruge (#M203) [-► :25j.
M abandons his intention of writing a critique of Hegel’s political theory as a single work, aiming instead ta write separate brochures on “law, ethics, politics, etc.,” and link them up later.
M’s reply to Ruge [«- :23], titled “Critical notes on the article [etc.]” (#M203), is pubd in Vorwärts. It is M’s first article in that paper; he gets increasingly involved with its editorial work.
M pubs a minor article in Vorwärts (#M383).
M hears further from G. Jung [«- :22], who sends recent writings by Bauer and by Szeliga and Stimer on E. Sue, and urges M to write a criticism of the Bauer school.

M receives another issue of Bauer’s paper containing an anti-M article; he decides to come out against Bauer; he plans to publish a part of his Paris mss (#M261), prob the “First ms,” together with a discussion of Hegel’s dialectic, as a brochure, and writes a preface for it (unfinished) attacking Bauer and defending Feuerbach.

M sends Feuerbach his DFJ essay on Hegel (#M205), expresses his high opinion of Feuerbach’s writings, and invites him to correspond. M also describes the great impact of the workers in the Paris communist clubs.
During this period they often meet and discuss.

header: 29. Engels Meets Marx: The Alliance Begins
text: E leaves Manchester for Paris (source: ST/56; MEW’s date is Aug c.26).

header: 29. Engels Meets Marx: The Alliance Begins
text: E sojourns in Paris and gets acquainted with M; in discussions they find that they agree on basic questions. E is persuaded to collaborate with Vorwärts, and acquaints himself with the French leftist and workers’ movement.

header: 29. Engels Meets Marx: The Alliance Begins
text: E pubs in Vorwärts the first of a pair of “condition of England’’ articles (#E167) [«- :7; -► :36).

M&E plan the writing of this critique of the Bauer school (#ME76); the few sections by E are written before he leaves Paris. M quits working on the unfinished Economic and philosophical mss (#M261) [«- :14).
M works on the book Holy family (#ME76), extending its scope. The foreword is written in Sep.

(rec’d c.24): Heine writes M (from Hamburg) that he is sending, under separate cover, his new poem “Germany, a winter’s tale’’ and other political parts of his forthcoming book Neue Gedichte, requesting that M get Vorwärts to publish whatever he thinks advisable, and also write an “introductory word’’ for the “Winter’s tale.’’ (M will get some of the poems pubd in Vorwärts, esp the “Winter’s tale,’’ but will not write an intro.)
Since the Holy family (#ME76) contains only incidental reference to polit eco, the writing of this book represents a hiatus in M’s work on the economics opus.
She returns from Trier [«- :20] with baby Jenny, also with a wetnurse named Gretchen from her mother’s household.
E departs from Paris (source: ST/56; MEW's date is Sep c.6).
E stays over in Aachen, at Im Mainzer Hof.
E arrives home in Barmen.
E makes trips to Cologne.
Before leaving Paris, E meets M’s Russian acquaintances, G. M. Tolstoy and Bakunin.

E works in his father’s firm in Barmen and Engelskirchen, also doing socialist propaganda work in the district and contacting other Rhenish socialists; he works on his book on the English working class (#E171).
Vorwärts finishes publishing E’s first of two “condition of England’’ articles (#E167).
Vorwärts pubs E’s second of this pair (#E168) [-:7,11].
E writes M on the needs of socialist propaganda work in Germany, esp for books of basic theory. In this, E’s first (extant) letter to M, he is already urging M to finish his book on polit eco.
(after Oct 18): Weitling (in London) writes to M, proposing correspondence.
E pubs a short piece on the Continental movement in NMW (#E183).
E writes an article for a yearbook on existing communist colonies (#E218) [-► :47].
In his notebook, M sets down an outline for a book on the state (#M253) and notes on Hegel’s Phenomenology (#M368)—both possibly dated Jan 1845.
M finishes work on the Holy family (#ME76) [-* 45:15]. Unbeknown to M. Ruge blackmails Fröbel into refusing to publish it; Bömstein, the Vorwärts pub’r, also turns it down.
The book is accepted for publ by J. Rütten (see ST/ME25).
M associates with Karl Grün and H. Bürgers, who have moved from Cologne to Paris.
Having read Stirner’s new book The ego and his own in advance proofs sent by the pub’r, E discusses it in a letter to M.
E starts writing an article—the first of three—on the progress of communism in Germany (#E649) [—► :47].
M reads Stimer’s book [«— :42] and plans to write a critique for Vorwärts.
M receives 1000 francs from the pub’r for the Holy family (#ME76).
The paper suspends publ, as a result of Prussian-inspired government harassment.
M continues his study of English and French political economists.
E’s article on communist colonies (#E218) [«- :39) is pubd in a yearbook.
E’s first article on the progress of communism in Germany (#E649) [<— :43] is pubd in NMW; for two more, see —► 45:17.
See «- 44:40 for two notebook jottings by M which may possibly belong to this month: an outline for a book on the state (#M253) and notes on Hegel (#M368).
Min of the Interior Guizot orders the expulsion from France of M and other Vorwärts collaborators, under pressure from Prussia.
M writes to Heine that leaving him behind will be the worst part of being expelled [-»:12J.
M receives—first from Leske, then from Hess— an invitation to collaborate on the Rheinische Jahrbücher planned by Püttmann.
M meets with Louis Blanc.
M sends E a criticism of Stiraer [«- 44:42], with which, Jan 20, E says he agrees; this discussion will lead to the writing of the German ideology (#ME66).
M continues his study of polit eco [«— 44:46), at least till his expulsion on Feb 3.
M plans to write a critique of F. List [—► :19).
Once again [<— 44:37] E urges M to finish his book on polit eco, as he will continue to do for the next few decades.
M negotiates with pub’r Leske for a contract for his Economica [-* :14).
E announces he will work with Hess in establishing a new monthly, Gesellschafts-Spiegel, in Hagen, beginning Apr 1.
E collaborates with Hess in drawing up the editorial statement for the new monthly (#E862).
M makes a contract with pub’r Leske; see —► :14.
M meets with Cabet.
In accordance with the government expulsion order [«- :8] M quits Paris for Brussels.
M goes to Brussels, via Lifege, with H. Bürgers. After stopping at the Hötel de Saxe, his first address is 35 rue Pacheco “vis-ä-vis du höpital St-Jean.”
M gets acquainted with Freiligrath, who has recently pubd his poetry, and at his home again meets Karl Heinzen, who has fled from Germany.
M sends the Belgian king a formal request for permission to reside in the country (#M887).
M receives money from a fund initiated by E in Barmen to help the M family resettle after expulsion; he gets about 50 talers this month, 122 francs in Mar [-► :21).
Hermann Kriege, recommended by E and Julius Meyer, comes to see M.
Settled in Brussels, M continues his study and work on polit eco; see -* :50 for details.
The Darmstadt pub’r H. Leske (who is visiting Paris) signs a contract with M for publ of a two-volume work on polit eco, Critique of politics and polit eco. (For the contract, see MECW 4:675.)
The Holy family (#ME76) is pubd in Frankfurt [«- 44:40].
E gives talks at two meetings he helps to organize in nearby Elberfeld, to popularize socialist ideas (#E770) [—► :34).
E participates in a third such meeting.
E receives an official order from the Elberfeld mayor banning further socialist meetings.
E spends a week in Bonn and Cologne (staying at friends' houses) organizing propaganda activities (on which he reports to M, Mar 7).
E writes the second of three articles on the progress of communism in Germany (#E649) [«- 44:47; -» :27).
M’s house is the scene of a farewell party for Freiligrath, with Bürgers and Heinzen.
M signs the required pledge not to publish in Belgium on current politics (cf text, MECW 4:677).
M writes a critique of F. List’s polit eco, unfinished, apparently for Püttmann’s planned Rheinische Jahrbücher (#M591).
M&E plan [<- :5] the publ of a series of edns of the major socialist/ communist writings, with the collaboration of Hess (cf #M659); but pub’r Leske turns the project down.
E writes, and dates, his English-language Dedication (#E173) to be included in the book.
For E’s propaganda activity, see «- :16.
E finishes writing his book on England (#E171) [<- :4; —► :27].
M receives more money (750 francs) from the resettlement fund [<— :13) sent by G. Jung, from Bielefeld and Cologne.
M goes to Hamburg on a visit (source: KMC, based on newspaper reports; no further info).
M sets down a short note on the state (#M565).
(spring): M writes down his “Theses on Feuerbach” (#M878) as a seminal statement of his new views of society.
Mrs. M’s mother sends her own maidservant to join the M family in Brussels; from this time on Helene Demuth stays permanently with the family as a key member of the household.
In Barmen, E submits a request to the mayor for permission to emigrate to England.
E is in Düsseldorf.
E moves to Brussels, near the M family. (This account follows ST/56; MEW dates E’s move “after Apr 5.”)
E sojourns in Bonn; on Apr 15 he stays there with his father, who may have been returning from a quick trip to England.
E writes, or finishes writing, the last of three articles (#E649) [«-:17] for the Owenite NMW, this one reporting the Elberfeld meetings [«- :16]. This is his last piece before moving to Brussels.
The M family moves from Plaine Ste-Gudule to 5 rue de 1’Alliance, in the Brussels suburb Saint-Josse-ten-Noode, “ftors de la Porte de Louvain." E lives nearby, at no. 7 on the same street.
NMW pubs the last two articles of E’s report on the German movement (#E649) [«— :25].
E’s book The condition of the working class in England (#E171) is pubd in Leipzig.
M’s reading of E’s new book on England (#E171) [«- :27] makes a significant contribution, often overlooked, to M’s orientation in the field of polit eco.
M receives an advance of 1500 francs from pub’r Leske for his planned book [«- :14).
Mrs. M goes to her mother’s house in Trier for the summer, along with little Jenny and Helene Demuth.
M&E are visited by G. Weerth, who stays for some weeks (source: KMC, on basis of Weerth’s letters; but it is not clear how this jibes with the next item; cf -» 46:21).
M&E depart together for a trip to England (London, Manchester), to get acquainted with the English workers’ movement and to study English conditions and polit eco in the libraries. See —► :32.
M’s study of polit eco in London’s BM and Manchester libraries is extensive; it is in this period that M studies the “socialist Ricardians” (for M’s reading, see —> :51).
M&E spend much time in library study of economic sources [<— :31] as well as in meeting and talking with labor and socialist leaders in London and Manchester.

They participate in a conference along with Chartist leaders, League of the Just people, and other Democratic 6migr6s. A resolution is passed (E supporting) to establish in London an international organizn of Democrats for exchange of info. (This will be founded next month as the Fraternal Democrats.)
M&E return to Brussels (source: MEW; the chronology in ST/56 dates this return Aug c.14, without explanation of discrepancies).
They meet with Harney, and with the London leaders of the League of the Just (Schapper, Moll, et al).
In correspondence with Ewerbeck (in Paris), M convinces him to come out against Karl Griin’s activity among the German workers in Paris.
E’s Elberfeld speeches (#E770) [<- :16] are pubd in Rheinische Jahrbücher.
She gives birth to a daughter, Laura.
Mrs. M returns from Trier [«- :30|.

M&E read the new Vol. 3 of Wigand's Vierteljahrsschrift, with polemical essays by Bauer and Stimer, and they plan to write a critique—which will later become part of the German ideology (#ME66). Possibly they start writing it in Sep (so according to MEW, but see —> :43 for MECW estimate).
Back in Brussels, M continues his reading and study in polit eco [—» :44] (for details, see—► :52).
E pubs three articles (#E420, 887, 924) in NS on Germany and the Continental movement.

M sends to the Trier burgomaster a request (#M885) for a certificate for emigration to the US, thus entailing release from Prussian citizenship |—»:42]. It is not certain whether M actually contemplates emigration at this time or whether this is a device to block Prussian government pressure on the Brussels authorities.
M&E plan to write a work on the tariff question, protection vs free trade; they offer the project to pub’r Campe (source: KMC).
E pubs two more articles in NS on the Continental movement: a report on anticommunist persecution (#E582) and E’s first article on the “state of Germany” (#E772) [— :45).

In response to a query from Trier [«- :39] on whether his request applies to his family, M answers yes if necessary for granting consent (#M886). There is no record that the request is granted [—* :46].
M&E start writing the German ideology (#ME66)—according to MECW (but see dating in Sep from MEW). — Around this time (autumn) E makes notes on “Feuerbach” (#E278), prob for the joint book.
M&E write a reply to B. Bauer’s criticism of the Holy family (#ME129) [-> 46:7}.
The German ideology project means the interruption of M’s work on polit eco, though he may have continued some reading in the field.
G. Jung writes M that he and his friends are looking forward to the coming work on polit eco.
(end of the year): E writes the article “The Festival of Nations” (#E277). Around this time, perhaps as early as Sep, M writes a piece on Peuchet and suicide (#M653).
E pubs the second article of the series “The state of Germany” (#E772) [<- :41; -► 46:10].
As a result of his harassment in Brussels by the Prussian government, M sends an official request to be relieved of Prussian citizenship.
The pub’r Leske [«- :14] presses M to finish his book on polit eco.
The Telegraph für Deutschland, for which E has not written since 1841, pubs his article on the English corn laws (#E354), sent to it by a press bureau commissioned by E.
M sends a statement to Trier’sche Ztg repudiating his alleged assoc with that paper, as it is “bourgeois-philanthropic,” not communist (#M847); pubd Jan 26.
M&E fix on the book’s framework and contents, as well as title and subtitle [-* :17,19].

Previously written pieces appear in print: M&E’s reply to Bauer on the Holy family (#ME129); M’s article “Peuchet: On suicide” (#M653); the first part of E’s supplementary material on England (#E792) [«—45:4).
Around this time (perhaps in Jan) M&E establish this attempt at a political center in Brussels.
M informs Ewerbeck (in Paris) of the CCC project—"a new system of propaganda”—and asks him to collaborate. M&E also inform Harney and request his support, esp of a planned periodical [—> :11].
M receives from Bürgers (in Cologne) a loan of 370 francs.
M accompanies his wife partway as she goes to visit her sick mother in Trier; he stops in Arlon.
E pubs the rest («- :7] of his supplementary material on England (#E792).
He writes the third article in his series on Germany for NS (#E772) [«-45:45;—» :18J.
The Brussels circle adopts a resolution against Thomas Cooper for deserting Chartism.
Harney writes from London that he will collaborate with the Brussels circle if the London group of German communists (esp Schapper) does.

The Brussels group holds a discussion meeting at M's house with Weitling, newly arrived from London, on propaganda work in Germany; there is a sharp conflict. Present are Gigot, Weydemeyer, Seiler, Edgar von Westphalen, Heilberg, plus Annenkov as guest, besides Weitling and M&E.
M is visited by P. V. Annenkov, a Russian traveler who comes with a recommendatory letter from G. M. Tolstoy.
Pub’r Leske abrogates the agreement to publish M’s work [«-45:14] in view of its probable banning in Germany. (But see-» :28.)

Writing to Harney to ask his support for the Brussels CCC (see his reply «- :11), E says he expects the speedy coming of a revolution in England, the winning of the Charter by the end of the year, and the abrogation of private property within three years. E criticizes O’Connor’s leadership of the Chartist movement and praises Harney’s.

M writes Heine (in Paris) introducing Annenkov; he also mentions an intention to write an article defending Heine’s book against Börne, which has been attacked in the press. (No such article is extant.)
M&E begin working on a circular repudiating the US activities of the Weitlingite, H. Kriege (#ME28) [-» :20).
Writing to Ewerbeck (in Paris) to introduce Annenkov, M reports the conflict with Weitling [-«— :11] and warns against Karl Grün.
Wolff, a recent emigre from Germany, looks up M&E in Brussels. They become acquainted, then close friends; Wolff joins the CCC.
M writes a critique of Grün’s book which will later be included in the German ideology (#ME66) and also pubd separately [—» 47:16).
M&E are finished in the main with the first vol. of the work. Weydemeyer takes the ms with him back to Westphalia where he expects to finance publ through a couple of affluent socialists.
E pubs the third article in his NS series on Germany (#E772) [«— :10J.
M writes Weydemeyer that the second vol. is almost finished, and the rest of the first vol. is en route to him; he should start publ immediately.
M learns from Weydemeyer that his “angels" («- :17J will not finance the book [-» :27).
M writes Proudhon (in Paris) requesting that he be French correspondent; M also warns against K. Grün.

The Brussels CCC in session votes to criticize Kriege’s noncommunist activities in the US and adopt M&E’s circular on him (#ME28), only Weitling voting against. The circular, lithographed, is sent out to CCC contacts and to Kriege’s paper in America.
Proudhon replies [«- May 5] rejecting M’s proposal because he is against revolutionary action, and defending Grün.
M writes to Hess, sharply criticizing Weitling’s politics.
Hess says he separates himself from the “Marx tendency" but assures M of his personal regard.
Sending the circular against Kriege, the CCC proposes to the League of the Just and GWEA in London (led by Schapper) to form a London CCC and correspond regularly with the Brussels group.
The M family moves to an inn, Au Bois Sauvage, Plaine Ste-Cudule, no. 19 (or 19-21).
Weerth visits and stays at M’s address I-» :44.5).
E pubs an article on Prussia in NS (#E889).
M&E finish the second vol., and return to Ch. 1 for redrafting.
It asks G. Weber (in Kiel) to act as correspondent for northern Germany.

M receives a favorable reply from the London communist group [«- :20); they will form a Correspondence Comm; they approve the break with Weitling [«- :11] but criticize the sharp tone of the circular against Kriege [«- :20].

CCC sends a communication to the communists in the Wuppertal (Barmen, Elberfeld), addressed to Köttgen (#ME86), discussing propaganda and organization measures, but opposing an immediate congress of German communists as premature.
CCC writes the London comm urging a fight against “philosophical and sentimental communism”; it suggests holding a general communist congress in England.
M is visited by a German worker from Paris, Adolph Junge (introduced by Daniels and Bürgers), who reports on the movement in France.
E writes an article on Prussia for NS (#E641) [-* :30].
M receives final word that Weydemeyer’s publishing angels [«- :19] refuse financial support.
M&E end work on their redraft of Ch. 1 I«- :23], leaving it unfinished.
Pub’r Leske [«-:12] writes M asking him to return the advance or else immediately deliver the ms [—* :33].
M&E, signing “Democratic Communists of Brussels,” send greetings, via Harney, to Chartist leader O’Connor for his election victory in Nottingham (#ME4); pubd in NS, July 25.

(rec’d c.19): Schapper replies for the Londoners [<— :24] complaining of “intellectual arrogance,” advocating a softer attitude on “sentimental communism” and on Kriege, and proposing London for a communist congress.
Harney [<-:11] writes M&E that he will support the CCC project in view of the agreement reached with the London communists (Schapper et al).
(rec’d c.29): Ewerbeck (in Paris) promises to be active in Paris on behalf of the CCC.
M proposes to Bürgers the formation of a CCC in Cologne [—> :34]. He writes Ewerbeck that E will go to Paris soon.
CCC sends further suggestions for propaganda to Weber (in Kiel) [«— :24].
E pubs an article on Prussia in NS (#E641) [«- :26).
E takes a seaside holiday in Ostend with his mother and sister [—* :35].
M has an attack of asthma.
M drafts the preface; this is the last work done on the ms.
M replies to Leske [«- :28] with a promise to supply the ms of the first vol. by Nov D.
Bürgers replies [<- :29] that formation of a CCC in Cologne would be premature.
CCC, via W. Wolff, makes contact with Silesian communists, who begin sending reports on the working-class situation.
M joins E in Ostend [<- :31 ].
E leaves.
M leaves.
E makes the acquaintance of Cabet.
E moves to Paris, to carry on CCC work esp in the League of the Just, aiming to form a CCC branch.
E sends his first report (letter) to the Brussels CCC on the situation in Paris (#E439).
Sometime in this period E writes the second part of his “German socialism in verse and prose” (#E337) [<- :4; -► 47:31].
M resumes work on polit eco, till the end of the year (for his reading, see—► :51—53).
M inquires from Annenkov (in Paris) whether the Tolstoy exposed in the German press as a Russian secret agent is the G. M. Tolstoy they both know [—> :43].
E argues against the views of Grün and Proudhon in the League of the Just [—► :44].

E sends a second report (letter) to the Brussels CCC (#E439), i.a. criticizing Proudhon’s new book, as also in a letter to M, Sep 18. E has made extensive notes for himself on Proudhon’s book [—* :48].
E writes an article on France for NS (#E339); pubd Sep 5.
Bürgers sends M reports on Cologne, incl the work of d’Ester in the city council.
M and the Brussels comm send the London comm (Schapper et al) a report on the progress of the movement in Germany.
M draws up a second circular against Kriege, which is issued over his signature only (see #ME28, note).
In reply to M’s inquiry [«- :39], Annenkov answers that the secret agent is not G. M. Tolstoy.
The M family moves to 42 rue d’Orleans, Faubourg de Namur (but M also writes:     Faubourg d'lxelles). The street will later be renamed rue du Präsident [—► 48:9j.
E writes M a critique of Feuerbach’s Essence of religion, which he has just read.

In a third report (letter) to the Brussels CCC (#E439), E says he has won over a majority of the Paris branch of the League of the Just against “True Socialism” and Proudhonism, after three meetings of discussion in which E described the principles of communism.

London leaders of the League of the Just (Schapper et al) send out, without consulting Brussels, a circular to League branches proposing a communist congress in May and suggesting distrust of the Brussels “intellectuals."
M writes him about the conflict with Weitling.
M informs E (in Paris) of the new tension with the London communists [«- :45). E replies, discussing possible alternative courses. —In Paris, the police begin surveillance on E.
Stimulated by E’s letter [«— :40], M reads Proudhon’s new book.
In reply to an inquiry from Annenkov, M sends the Russian a long letter analyzing Proudhon.

M's reading of Proudhon’s book (see «- :48) moves him to reply in the arena of polit eco; his refutation will lead to his writing a book against Proudhon (#M681). In his Dec 28 letter to Annenkov (see :48) M reports he has not been able to get his Economica published.
M’s son Edgar is bom (either this month or next, Jan 1847).

The London comm of the League of the Just empowers Moll to go to Brussels and Paris to invite M&E to join, with the assurances that the League is ready to change its organizn and program in accord with their views.
M begins work early in the year on his book against Proudhon (#M681).
E writes an essay on the “True Socialists” (#E873), unfinished, continuing the subject from the German ideology (#ME66).
(Possibly Jan) M’s son Edgar is born (or see «- 46:50).
M's sister Caroline dies, in Trier.
Discussions take place in Brussels between Moll [«- :8] and M, as Moll urges him to join the League of the Just and recast it in accord with his "critical communism."
Pub'r Leske [«-46:33] definitively abrogates the publishing agreement, and requests speedy repayment of the advance with threats to take measures.
E writes "The Prussian constitution" (#E642) for NS [-> : 15).
M writes to Daniels and Bürgers (in Cologne) that one of them must come to Belgium (to meet at Malines, not Brussels) because there are matters that cannot be discussed by mail.
Weerth comes from Paris to visit M.
E writes an important pamphlet on German politics and the constitutional question (#E779), directed against profeudal "True Socialism" [—► :18].
E's article on Prussia is pubd in NS (#E642) [«- :13).
M makes efforts to publish his critique of Grün’s book [«- 46:17] as a brochure; Bürgers and Daniels in Cologne look for a pub’r [-» :25].
M sends in a statement attacking Grün (#M220) for a piece in Trier'sehe Ztg of Mar 25 on M's forthcoming anti-Proudhon book.
The statement is pubd in DBZ and Trier’sche Ztg. (This is M’s first contribution to DBZ.)
For E’s pamphlet on Germany (#E779), see «- :15 [-* :18].

In his first extant letter to E (in Paris), M writes that the recent arrest of Brussels pub’r Vogler in Aachen prevents publ of E’s pamphlet on Germany (#E779) [*- :15]. M says the first third of the ms is very good, but the other two (parts or thirds?) will need changes. (This may indicate that the ms contained three numbered parts; the extant ms ends before the end of Part 2.) In fact the pamphlet will remain unpubd.
DBZ pubs a special supplementary page reproducing a caricature by E, given to the paper by M, of the Prussian king’s speech from the throne of Apr 11. (For the caricature, see MEW 4: opp. 32.)

The congress in London has been organized by the London comm of the League of the Just in agreement with M&E, who are ready to join [<- :11); it will be the first congress of the new Communist League. M is unable to go to London, mostly for lack of money; E goes from Paris, Wolff from Brussels.
E and Wolff meet in Ostend and take the ship Belgian Railway to Dover.
E takes an active part in the congress.
At its last session the congress adopts E’s draft, to be sent to the branches for discussion.
E writes a draft of a communist credo (#E229) for the program of the new Communist League.
E returns to Paris.
M is visited by Herwegh, in Brussels.
M finishes his book on Proudhon, Poverty of philosophy (#M681); at any rate, this is the date of the preface (—► :24].
E writes an article on French politics and Guizot's decline (#E212) for NS [-> :27].
E writes an article on the tariff question for DBZ (#E638); pubd June 10.
M’s Poverty of philosophy (#M681) is pubd in Brussels in 800 copies [«- :22].
Unable to publish his critique of Grün’s book (Ch. 4 of German ideology—see #ME66) as a brochure [«- :16], M sends the ms to Weydemeyer (in Hamm) for publ in Westphälische Dampfboot H :29].
E leaves Paris to return temporarily to Brussels, where he will consult with M on CL affairs. (He will stay in Brussels till Oct M.)
E pubs his article on French politics (#E212) in NS |«- :23].
M plans to publish a monthly, with a printshop and publishing house.
M&E establish a Brussels branch of the CL, with M as chairman (Präsident); also a district exec (M, Gigot, Wolff, Junge). For M’s minutes of this meeting, see #M564.
M writes Cologne friends to subscribe shares.
M and the Brussels CL set up a German Workers (Educational) Assoc, like the London GWEA; its exec includes Wallau, Hess, Wolff, Riedel.
M’s critique of Grün [«- :25] is pubd in Westphälische Dampfboot, under M’s name, for 27Vi Reichstaler.
DBZ editor Bomstedt agrees to print all material supplied by M&E.
E arrives in Dover, from Ostend (source: ST/56, which does not explain what E is doing there).
In line with the agreement [<— :29], M&E begin publishing regularly in DBZ; M exercises a growing influence on the editorial management of the paper. (KMC dates this Sep M to Feb.)
M writes “The communism of the Rh. Beob.” (#M167).
DBZ pubs two major articles: the preceding (#M167) against feudal socialism, and E's “German socialism in verse and prose” (#E337), which is pubd in eight installs till Dec 9.
E pubs an article on the free-trade congress (#E234) in DBZ (-► :32).

The International Congress of Economists meets in Brussels; M&E take part, and develop arguments on the issue defending working-class interests. M prepares a speech but is prevented from delivering it.
M begins to write up his undelivered speech from notes (for part of which, see #M705).
E writes an article for DBZ on the congress (#E234); pubd Sep 23.

M attempts to get the speech pubd; the Brussels Atelier Dämocratique pubs it (or part of it) on Sep 29. For E’s report of the speech (#E291), see -* :40. The first part of the speech will later be pubd in pamphlet form (#M706).
M’s attention to the free-trade and tariff question during this period must be considered part of his continuing work on polit eco; note that it will lead [—► :53] to lectures on the subject.
The second part of M’s critique of Grün [«- :29] is pubd in Westphälische Dampfboot.
M goes off to visit his Dutch relatives, on financial matters (source: KMC).
While M is away, E attends a Democratic political banquet at which the Democratic Assoc of Brussels is founded. E agrees to accept the vice-presidency as a stand-in for M.
E writes to M describing the complex intrigues accompanying the affair.
E writes the first part of a polemic against Heinzen (#E152) [-+ :41j.

M returns from the Netherlands. From now till Dec, M will continue negotiations with his mother regarding payment of part of his paternal inheritance, through the mediation of his brother-in-law Schmalhausen of Maastricht.
M, still in the Netherlands, receives E’s long letter [«- :36] on the founding of the Democratic Assoc.
The London CC of the CL asks the Brussels branch to send a delegate to the CL second congress, urges M to come himself.
M asks Herwegh to support the plan to publish this monthly; in this letter M writes enthusiastically about the prospects of revolutionary activity in “little Belgium” even as compared with France.
Stephan Bom arrives from Paris and visits M, on E’s recommendation.
M and Jottrand, the editor of D6bat Social, discuss problems of organizing the Democratic Assoc.
M writes A. Gottschalk (in Cologne) to push the sales of shares for the planned monthly organ [<- :28] in order to finance the project.
To Lüning, M proposes publ of this essay in Westphälische Dampfboot.
E pubs a report on the free-trade congress (#E291) in NS [<- :32).
M plans to write an essay on the issue.
E writes the second part [«- :37] of a polemic against Heinzen on some basic political issues (#E152); the article is pubd Oct 3, 7, in DBZ.
Heinzen replies in DBZ with an abusive anticommunist blast.
M continues the argument with a long analysis of Heinzen’s politics, “Moralizing criticism [etc.]” (#M531), which is pubd in DBZ, Oct 28 to Nov 25.
E writes his first article for La Röforme, on England (#E151); pubd Oct 26.
E visits the office of the Christian Socialist organ L’Atelier, whose editors urge him to contribute; he gives them for publ a letter on the class struggle in England (#E472) [—► 49).
E writes an article on the Chartists for La Räforme (#E8) [-» 49).
E enters into relations with the Democratic left around La Räforme.
E tries unsuccessfully to persuade L. Blanc and Flocon that La Rtforme should publish M’s undelivered speech on the tariff issue [<— :32].
E returns to Paris, to begin building a CL branch.
At a session of the Paris CL district exec, E criticizes Hess’s draft of a communist credo: the exec charges E with writing a new draft.

E works on a new draft program for the CL, later called “Principles of communism” (#E620), in catechistic form, for consideration by the CL [—► :45]. Note: Andreas has argued that E drafted it during the summer.
M is elected vice-pres, replacing the departed E [«— :36], at the assoc’s second membership meeting; ]. Imbert is president.
The Paris district exec elects E as its delegate.
In a letter to M, E suggests dropping the catechistic form of the communist credo [<- :43) and calling it “Communist manifesto.”
Before leaving Brussels, M commissions S. Born to speak for the Brussels Workers Assoc at the international f§te for Poland taking place in Brussels on Nov 29.
M travels with Victor Tedesco from Brussels to London as delegate to the CL congress. They meet E, coming from Paris, in Ostend, and spend the night there, discussing congress problems.
They arrive in London (source: MEW, KMC; according to ST/56, M arrives in London on Nov 28 and E on Nov 29 after traveling Ostend-Dover on the ship Onyx).
CL holds its second congress, with M&E taking an active part (see —► :50).

In London, M&E attend the international meeting organized by the Fraternal Democrats to celebrate the anniversary of the 1830 Polish uprising; both give speeches on Poland (#M833, #E768) [-► :54]. M gives the Fraternal Democrats a communication from the Brussels Demo Assoc urging closer relations. At a banquet, in the name of the Demo Assoc, M invites those present to an international Democratic congress to be organized next year [—► :52).

M&E give talks at a meeting of the London GWEA (for minutes, see #M749, #E430A). M reports on the Brussels Workers Assoc and discusses leftist literature in France and Germany, esp Blanc’s history of the French Revolution; E talks on the socioeconomic consequences of the discovery of America.
M asks his brother-in-law Schmalhausen [«- :38) for a loan.
He receives 150 francs.
DBZ pubs the last parts of M’s polemic against Heinzen (#M531) [«— :41).
E’s article on England (#E472) [«— :42] is pubd in L’AteJier.

Work for La R6forme: E pubs his article on Chartism (#E8) [«- :42], and writes another on the Chartist electoral banquet (#E137), pubd Nov 6; Nov 21, he writes again on Chartism (#E138), pubd Nov 22; and Nov 30 E writes a report of the Poland meeting of Nov 29 (#E20) [—► :54).

Work for NS: It reprints Nov 6 the article in La Röforme on Chartism (#E8) [<— Nov 1]; Nov A, E writes an article on Lamartine (#E466), pubd Nov 13, and also an article on the French reform movement (#E657), pubd Nov 20; Nov D, he writes an article on the split in the French left (#E771) [—► :57).
E writes an article for DBZ on Switzerland (#E144); pubd Nov 14.
E gives a lecture at the London GWEA on economic crises and overproduction (#E430B).
Finding himself in bad financial straits, M asks Annenkov (in Paris) to lend 100-200 francs, to be sent to Brussels.
M leaves London to return to Brussels.
Ditto E.

As the congress continues [«— :45], M&E are commissioned to write the programmatic manifesto of the movement; the Rules are changed in the direction of an open, democratic structure in accord with M&E’s proposals. M carries on discussions with Chartist leaders also: Harney, Jones, et al.
M&E work on the Manifesto [see «- :50] while still in London.
M works on it in Brussels. (Besides #ME33, see also #ME34, 35.)
Harney writes M that his proposal for an international Democratic congress [«— :46) has been unanim approved by the Fraternal Democrats, London GWEA, and Chartists.
At the Demo Assoc, M reports on the Polish meeting of Nov 29 in London, and Harney’s acceptance of the congress proposal. The Assoc names E as its representative in Paris.
M and Bornstedt protest at the office of the Journal de Bruxelles against that paper's attacks on foreigners in Brussels.
At the Demo Assoc, M supports the admission to membership of Bakunin and d’Ester.
At the New Year’s Eve celebration by the German Workers Assoc, M gives a short talk in the form of a toast, stressing appreciation of Belgium's democratic freedoms (see MECW 6:639).
M gives lectures at the German Workers Assoc on polit eco, and prepares the lectures for publ [—► 48:8] as a pamphlet on “Wages” (#M970; see also #M968—969, and notes on #M231).
Reports on M&E's speeches of Nov 29 appear in Deutsche Londoner Ztg and NS.
E’s report of the Nov 29 meeting (#E20) is pubd in La Röforme [«- :46].
The speeches (#M833, #E768) are pubd in DBZ.
M writes an article defending the communists against Bartels (#M732); pubd in DBZ, Dec 19.
M writes in defense against attacks by Lamartine (#M441); pubd Dec 26.
Ditto the Brussels Demo Assoc (see «-:52).
The London Fraternal Democrats ask E to be their representative in Paris.
E gives a talk at the New Year’s Eve celebration of the German 6migr6s in Paris.
E goes to Paris.
NS pubs E’s article on France (#E771) [«— :49).
E pubs articles on France (#E659, 455) in DBZ, and an article on England (#E136) in La Räforme.
E writes two articles on the French reform movement (#E656, 658) for NS; pubd Dec 18.
The Communist League’s Central Comm (CL/CC) in London sends M a warning that he has until Feb 1 to finish the Manifesto, or measures will be taken.
M finishes the Manifesto.
He sends it to the printer in London, prob right after receiving the CL/CC’s warning. (This may be dated Feb A.)
M gives a lecture on this subject at a public meeting of the Demo Assoc, which votes to publish it as a pamphlet (#M836) [-* :8].
M goes to Ghent with a delegation to establish a branch.
E pubs articles on the Chartist movement in England (#E148, 140, 139) in La Rtforme.
E pubs an article on O’Connor and the Irish (#E275) in DBZ.

header: 6. Publ on the Eve of Revolution
text: E pubs two articles on France (#E723, 261) in NS.

header: 6. Publ on the Eve of Revolution
text: M sums up the French situation (#M820) in DBZ.

header: 6. Publ on the Eve of Revolution
text: La R6forme reprints this piece (#M820) in Paris.

header: 6. Publ on the Eve of Revolution
text: E pubs an important survey of Europe on the eve, “The movements of 1847” (#E497).

header: 6. Publ on the Eve of Revolution
text: Ditto on Austria (#E75).
The tottering government expels E for revolutionary activity in Paris workers’ circles.
E returns to Brussels (KMC dates this Feb M).
M prepares his lectures on “Wages” [<— 47:53] for pamphlet publ, and gives the ms to the Brussels printer Callewaert (#M969); but publ will be aborted by the outbreak of revolution [—> 48:31].
