For the first issue of the new magazine M writes Part I of his study of the failed revolution in France, which will later be entitled Class struggles in France, 1848-1850 (#M148).

M&E write two book reviews, one of a book by Daumer on religion (#ME142), the other of a book by Ludwig Simon of Trier (#ME142), and possibly also a third review (#ME138; see —> :6). These reviews will appear in no. 2 of the Revue.
An appeal for stock subscription is issued, signed by K. Schramm as manager (gärant) (cf MECW 10:605).
M&E’s announcement of the magazine (#MEll) starts appearing in the German press.
M&E write, and date, the “Review” of the month (#ME134), but it will be pubd in no. 2 of the Revue, with a part added in Feb.

M is ill the last week and a half of the month, and does not finish his Part I of the Class struggles [—> :6]; mss are slow in coming in. M wants to postpone publ for some weeks and then begin with a double number, but pub’r Schuberth protests on Jan 18. On Jan 25 M’s Hamburg agent Hagen demands the mss for the first number, which, however, is delayed.
The CL/CC, incl M&E, begins reorganizing the League.

On M’s proposal, the CL/CC decides to send K. Schramm as emissary to America—representing the left Chartists and the French Blanquist emigration as well—to raise money and support for NRZ-Revue and for other propagandist purposes.
M calls on CL supporters in Germany to raise funds for Schramm’s mission; Freiligrath sends 40 talers on Jan 26. (The trip will not take place for lack of funds.)
M writes to Röser (in Cologne) urging establishment of a CL branch in the city and elsewhere in the Rhineland, necessarily illegal because of the de facto suppression of civil liberties.

—Leaders of the German Democratic emigration (R. Schramm, Struve, etc.) call a meeting for Jan 3 to organize the ämigräs; they exclude M’s supporters (e.g., F. Wolff, K. Schramm) while inviting M&E on Jan 2; M&E refuse to participate.
M writes Part II of his Class struggles (#M148).
M&E add a section to the “Review” of the period (#ME134) [«- :4], for no. 2
—They write a book review on Guizot’s brochure about England (#ME138), also for no. 2.
—E finishes his study of the German armed campaign of 1849 (#E328) [<- 49:35; -► :10].
M finishes writing Part I of his Class struggles (#M148) [«- :4].
M&E send the ms copy for no. 1 to the Hamburg printer. The printing will be drawn out because of M’s difficult handwriting and pub’r Schuberth’s worry about government harassment [—► :10).
M writes G. Bergenroth (in Berlin) for an article on Prussian finances, and asks him to look for other contributors.
Lassalle writes M about his activity on behalf of the Revue, and about the Hatzfeldt case.
Issue no. 1 is printed and goes to the bindery (till Mar 7).
M&E write an announcement about the magazine's delay (#ME54A), for publ in no. 1.
On M’s behalf, E asks Dronke (in Paris) to supply a contribution on France.
R. Schramm [<— :4) again asks M for collaboration in ämigrä organizn.
E speaks at a banquet of the French Blanquist ämigräs celebrating the February 1848 revolution; he ends with a toast to the Paris June insurgents, “amidst thunderous applause” (cf MECW 10:607).

M replies to a question from Röser that the CL should base its propaganda on the Com Manifesto, and that the coming League congress will work out new statutes to replace the obsolete ones of 1847 or 1848.
For an example of day-to-day problems in refugee comm work, see #E855—a case requiring liaison with the Hungarian refugee comm in London.
M gives several lectures on polit eco, at home, for friends (Pfänder, Eccarius, et al).
E writes the article “The ten hours’ question” for Harney’s Democratic Review (#E800) [-► :11].
Bruno Bucher (in Köslin) proposes that M write a popular almanac (Kalender) on polit eco, esp intended for peasants, to be pubd by Bucher.
M&E write book reviews of Carlyle’s Latter-day pamphlets (#ME139) and of two books by French police agents (#ME141)—to be pubd in no. 4.
M finishes Part II of his Class struggles (#M148).
M writes Part III of the same.

The first number of the magazine appears in Hamburg and is sent out, dated Jan. Main contents: Part I of M’s Class struggles in France (#M148); Part I of E’s “German campaign [etc.]” (#E328), and an article by K. Blind on “Austrian and Prussian parties in Baden.”
M sends a letter to Naut (in Cologne) about his financial crisis: 30 talers are urgently needed.

The second number of the magazine is pubd in Hamburg, dated Feb. Main contents: second installment of the ongoing series by M (Class struggles, #M148) and by E (“German campaign [etc.]” #E328); three book reviews (#ME137, 142, 138), and the “Review” of Jan-Feb (#ME134).
M receives 30 talers from Naut, borrowed from a bookseller.
E writes an article on the English ten hours’ bill for the Revue (#E246); it will be pubd in no. 4.
For two articles which are perhaps begun by M&E (#M489, #ME69), see —» :14.
Demo Review pubs E’s article on the ten hours' question (#E800) [«— :9J.
The financial statement of the S-D Refugee Comm [«-49:40], signed i.a. by M&E, is approved at a GWEA meeting (#MEl57A).

Bürgers (in Cologne) writes M for advice on political management of the Cologne Westdeutsche Ztg, of which he is to become an editor. (In subsequent letters, M disapproves of collaboration with that paper.)
The CL/CC sends H. Bauer as an emissary to the branches in Germany, to help reorganize the League.
M&E write a circular to the League membership (“Address to the CL," #ME2) in which they analyze the basic lessons of the failed revolution of 1848-49 and advocate a “Permanent Revolution” policy.
There is a sharp break between M&E and Müller-Tellering, former NRZ correspondent in Vienna, accompanied by Tellering’s personal attacks on M&E.
For M’s lectures on polit eco, see «— :8.
The third issue of the Revue is pubd in Hamburg, dated Mar. Its contents consist of the third installment of M’s Class struggles series (#M148) and of E’s “German campaign [etc.]” (#E328).
Lassalle writes M reporting on his activity in Düsseldorf in the interests of the Revue.
M&E finish, and date, the “Review” of the period Apr-Mar (#ME135), for no. 4.
M&E write a book review of Girardin’s book on socialism and taxation (#ME140— perhaps written by M alone), for no. 4; also a brief ed note on one Heinrich Didier (#ME54C).
For no. 4, M finishes an addendum to his Class struggles: an article on financial speculation under Bonaparte (#M489). M&E write an article on Kinkel (#ME69) for the same number.
M&E participate in an international meeting organized by the Fraternal Democrats for Robespierre’s birthday. E’s speech recalls English revolutionary traditions, incl the Levelers.

In Elberfeld, 122 defendants go on trial for participation in the uprising of May 1849, incl E in absentia [<-49:25], on the basis of an indictment (cf MECW 10:602) which recounts E’s doings [—► :19].

M&E, with Willich, as representatives of the CL, meet with leaders of the London Blanquists (Sociätä des Proscrits Dämocrates Socialistes), Adam and Vidil, and with Harney for his Chartist left wing. They agree to establish a Sociätä Universelle des Communistes Rävolutionnaires on the basis of a six-point program mentioning the “dictatorship of the proletarians” (#ME80) [—> :38].

The CL/CC, under M, sends Dronke as emissary to Switzerland to reestablish the CL there (together with W. Wolff in Zurich) and to counteract the secret society of the reformist Democrats called Revolutionäre Zentralisation (Revol. Zent.). Dronke is to do likewise in Baden.

About 30 refugees issue a joint statement supporting the S-D Refugee Aid Comm against attacks on it by its Democratic opponents (R. Schramm, Struve, etc.) and thanking M and the other comm members for its work (cf MECW 10:350).
At a meeting of the refugee comm, minutes taken by E (#ME157B) show testimony on how little Schramm, Struve, et al are doing for refugees (cf MECW 10:612).
M&E write letters to Weydemeyer, T. Schuster, Lassalle (and prob others) requesting a fund collection for refugees in Germany; also requesting contributions to finance the NRZ-Revue.
The refugee comm issues a statement, cosigned by M as chairman, refuting insinuations that the comm is partisan in distributing aid (#ME164).

M (as chairman), E, and others sign the financial statement of the aid comm, which also appeals against the machinations of “Struve, Bobzin, Bauer, and others” who on Apr 22 set up a rival comm (#ME157C).

Because of unpaid rent, the M household goods are seized by bailiffs. The family is forced to move, at first into the German Hotel at no. 1 & 2 Leicester Street, adjoining Leicester Square, where they live until May A [-► :21).
Naut (in Cologne) sends M 25 talers from sales.

The fourth issue of the magazine is pubd in Hamburg, dated Apr. Contents: a French poem by Louis Mänard on the June days of 1848, “Jambes”; E’s article on the ten hours’ bill (#E246); three book reviews (#ME139, 141,   140); the “Review” of Mar-Apr (#ME135), and a “Miscellany” comprising two minor articles (#M489, #ME69) and a piece about Karl Vogt by W. Wolff.
M makes a draft of £15 on Naut without informing him; it is partially covered by Weydemeyer with 20 talers from Revue sales in Frankfurt.
On behalf of the CL/CC, M&E establish relations with the left wing of the Hungarian emigration, incl Türr and Johann Bangya.
On behalf of the CL/CC, E writes W. Wolff (in Switzerland) to follow the activity of the Revol. Zent. group in Switzerland and Germany and to report regularly.

Sazanov (in Geneva) writes M that he has become a communist and asks him to collaborate with a “communist” periodical planned in Paris with Herzen and Pyat. Since the latter two are anticommunists, M does not reply.
M&E warn Pardigon, a leader of the French Blanquist group in London, against close relations with G. Struve’s 6migr6 group, otherwise the CL would break off relations.
In Elberfeld, the trial of the 122 defendants [«- :15] ends; most are found guilty and sentenced to various jail terms.
W. Wolff sends in a report [«- :19].
The Times pubs a letter from the “Democratic Socialist Comm for German Political Refugees” (signatures headed by M) repudiating Struve’s activities (#ME179).
At the CL/CC, H. Bauer reports on his trip to Germany, just concluded.
On a GWEA outing, M makes the acquaintance of W. Liebknecht, who has come to London after his expulsion from Switzerland. (Liebknecht’s memoirs date this “summer.”)
There is an assassination attempt against Friedrich Wilhelm IV in Berlin by an ex-soldier, Max Sefeloge, a royalist lunatic.
The Neue Preussische Ztg links this attentat to an alleged trip by M to Berlin at the time.
M, E, and Willich, on behalf of the GWEA, write to the Prussian ambassador, Baron Bunsen, requesting the issues of the Neue Preussische Ztg with the allegations reported in the press (#ME89).

The Prussian government presses the English to apply its Alien Act provisions against the refugees; M&E, as well as others, find themselves dogged on every side by spies and “tails,” prob both English police spies and Prussian agents.
The M family moves to 64 Dean Street, Soho. Around this time E starts living at 6 Macclesfield Street, which is a continuation of Dean Street.

M&E, usually also with Willich's signature, send letters to various papers denouncing the Prussian spy campaign against London refugees [«- :20J, also denouncing efforts to apply the English Alien Act to harass refugees.
The Sun prints one of these letters (#ME122), likewise NS; the Spectator prints a longer one (#ME123); a letter to the Globe (#M909) goes unpubd.
Röser writes, for the Cologne branch, that it opposes accepting Lassalle into CL membership because of his “autocratic principles.”
M&E write separate statements (#ME165) replying to the editor of the NDZ, Lüning, who has reviewed the NRZ-Revue and made critical remarks about M’s Class struggles in France (#M148) [-> :29).
(if not already May D): M&E write a second circular (“Address to the CL”) to the League membership, reporting on the work of the organizn (#ME3).

A CL member from Solingen, Karl Klein, visits M in London on behalf of the Cologne branch. Through him, M sends the “Address” to the Cologne members, also his proposal to accept Lassalle into the League.
M addresses himself to Savoye (in Paris) for financial support to the comm’s work.
The comm, in a statement signed i.a. by M&E, refutes the charge made by 6migr6 political enemies that it is aiding only communists (#ME68).
M sends his regrets (#M891) to a refugee public meeting in London that illness prevents him from attending; he refers to his defense of the June 1848 insurgents of Paris.
M resumes giving lectures on polit eco, partly at home, partly at the GWEA.
M obtains an admission card to the British Museum Library.
notes: Chronicle says June M, but this article says June 12 Higgins, C. (2017). “Seeing ‘Sights’ That Don”t Exist’: Karl Marx in the British Museum Round Reading Room. Library & Information History, 33(2), 81–96. doi:10.1080/17583489.2017.1298892

text: M&E send a letter, for publ in the German press, exposing the Weser-Ztg’s falsified quote from the Spectator on the Prussian spy campaign (#ME183); pubd July 10.

Dronke sends reports to E and to the CL/CC reporting on his organizn work in Switzerland and on his dealings with the Revol. Zent. group [«— :19], which is proposing unity. (The CL/CC will reject the proposal.)
A. Goegg (in Paris) writes M asking for more detailed info on the works on socialism that M is planning to write.
—Dronke sends E a second report on his organizing work in Switzerland, esp his dealings with d’Ester and Techow.
In the CL/CC controversy arises with Willich over his leaning toward closer relations with the 6migr6 group of Democrats in London (KMC dating: c.Aug).
A communal lodging and eating house for refugees is set up, also the beginnings of a common workshop for the jobless.
A financial statement for May-July, which reports on this communal enterprise, is signed by M&E et al (#ME157D).
or Aug (summer): Johannes Miquel writes his first letter to M, declaring he is a communist and referring to “dictatorship of the proletariat." (Erroneously dated by KMC and by Bernstein in NZ.)
Charles A.  Dana of the NYDT [<— 40:81] writes M assuring him of his friendship and asking him to forward an enclosed letter to Freiligrath.

M begins a systematic study of the economic history of the past decade, on the history of prices, the bank system, economic crises in England and Europe, incl the file of the London Economist. In the course, M comes to the conclusion that just as the 1847 economic crisis was behind the 1848 outbreak, so returning prosperity conditioned the later reaction. By July D he concludes that the economic crisis has definitely ended and revolution is no longer imminent.
For M’s lectures, see <— :24.

M incorporates the foregoing view in his "Review / May to Oct" (#ME136), which will appear in NRZ-Revue, no. 5/6. This "Review” includes a section which will later become Part IV of his Class struggles in France (#M148).
During this period E works on his history of the Peasant war in Germany (#E579) for NRZ-Revue.
NDZ pubs the M&E statements (#ME165) [«— :22]\
In a discussion with Techow (in a wineshop, E and K. Schramm present) M vainly tries to persuade him to quit the Revol. Zent. group [«- :19] and join the CL.
At a meeting of the S-D Refugee Aid Comm, a sharp conflict [<— :25] takes place between M plus the comm majority and Willich, who says he is leaving the comm.

At a GWEA meeting, Willich announces his resignation from the refugee comm; M&E criticize him sharply. Most GWEA members side with Willich; the basic issue is Willich’s desire for adventurist policies looking to a quick revolution, hence reestablishment of the 1848 alliance with the Democrats, i.e., a fast replay of 1848. In contrast, M has concluded [«- :28] that the 1848-49 revolutionary crisis is now over.

M considers plans to move to America with his family, E to follow in Nov. M asks Rothacker, who is going to America, to make contacts for this purpose and to survey the prospects for founding a paper.
For M’s lectures, see «- :24.

(or betw May D and Aug): E writes part of an article, intended for NRZ-Revue, on the reformist German writers, like Grün, who raise the slogan of abolishing the state and talk of "anarchy"; it remains, unfinished (#E566.5).

At a CL/CC session there is a sharp controversy between M and Willich [<— :30j. M spurns Willich’s challenge to a duel, but K. Schramm accepts despite M’s dissuasion. (For the membership list of the CL/CC, see #M474.5.)
M&E, with H. Bauer and Pfänder, announce their resignation from the S-D Refugee Aid Comm. The GWEA supervisors check the comm’s financial accounts and find all correct.
The Willich-Schramm duel takes place in Ostend; Schramm receives a minor head wound from a pistol shot.
Röser, for the Cologne branch, writes M urging that he republish the Com Manifesto, rewriting it in light of 1848-49, and that he finish his book on polit eco.

At a session of the CL/CC, at which M speaks twice (#M836.5), the first stage of the split takes place after a sharp debate in which a majority of the CC supports M’s view. M’s organizational proposal is that the London membership form two branches and that the CC move to Cologne (cf MECW 10:625-30). However, the Willich-Schapper faction will in fact form its own CC, thereby consummating a split formally.
M&E plus 10 supporters send in a statement of resignation (#ME163) from the GWEA, whose majority supports Willich-Schapper, and from the refugee comm.
M&E, with H. Bauer and Pfänder, sign their last financial statement of the refugee comm, for the period Aug 1 to Sep 10 (#ME157E).
M sends the minutes of the Sep 15 split meeting to Cologne; Eccarius is assigned to send Cologne a complete report.
Through H. W. Haupt as emissary, M sends Röser (in Cologne) a letter on the split. Haupt is also commissioned to organize a new branch in Hamburg.
Röser sends M the provisional opinion of the Cologne branch Exec on the split, and requests documents and communications.
M&E send letters on the split to CL friends in Germany—to W. Wolff (in Zurich), Weydemeyer (in Frankfurt), Dronke (in Geneva), et al.
E makes a much-applauded speech at a Fraternal Democrats meeting called to protest the London visit of Austrian Field Marshal Haynau (cf MECW 10:624).
For M’s reading and study in this period, see —► :50, 51; 51:60-69. This represents roughly the period between the suspension of the NRZ-Revue work and the outbreak of the Crimean War (cf <— :3).

During this time M is in the midst of working on his “Review” of May-Oct (#ME136) for the magazine (see also a fragment ascribed to Sep-Oct, #M563.5); and E is working on his Peasant war in Germany (#E579) [<- :29].
Haupt [«-:34] sends M his first report on Cologne, the reconstitution of the CC there, and its first steps.

M, E, and Harney send a letter (#ME171) to the French Blanquist group stating that they consider the SUCR [«- :15] to be "long since” dissolved; the original agreement will be burned at E’s house on Oct 13.
M helps Eccarius write his article on tailoring for the magazine. M&E write an ed note (#ME53) specially hailing this article by a worker in the trade.
Harney writes M apologizing for failing to write a promised article for the magazine; he promises to do so for a future issue.
M writes Weydemeyer (in Frankfurt) to redeem Mrs. M’s pawned silverware [<- 49:27, 28], then sell it, and remit the difference [-» :43).
M asks Haupt (in Hamburg) to raise funds there, and assigns him to proofread no. 5/6 of the magazine.
— M writes Daniels (in Cologne) to sell a part of the library M had left there.
Goegg (in Paris) writes M that the Soci6t6 de la Ligue des Peuples invites him to collaborate on its paper.
Röser again [«- :34] writes M about reprinting the Com Manifesto.
The first English trans of the Manifesto, by Helen Macfarlane, is pubd in Harney’s Red Republican, with an ed note naming the authors (cf #ME33).
The London CL, M participating, proposes to the Cologne CC that the Willich-Schapper group be formally expelled since they have set up a parallel organization (cf MECW 10:633).
— King Friedrich Wilhelm IV of Prussia sends a secret memo to Prime Min Manteuffel on a plan to invent a “Communist plot” f—► 51:1].
M&E finish, and date, the “Review / May to Oct” (#ME136), which includes also what will later be Part IV of M’s Class struggles (#M148).
M asks Haupt to take up with pub’r Schuberth the possibility of continuing publ of the Revue as a quarterly.
Haupt sends M £2Vi collected in Hamburg [«- :39|.

The last issue of the NRZ-Revue, double number 5/6, is pubd in Hamburg, dated “May to Oct.” Contents: E’s Peasant war in Germany (#E579); a reprint of Section III of the Com Manifesto (naming the authors—cf #ME54D); Eccarius’s article on tailoring in London [<- :39]; and the “Review / May to Oct” (#ME136).
M makes efforts to continue the magazine as a quarterly, in discussions with CL members in Cologne and Hamburg as well as with publishers [—► :46].
For M’s reading, with emphasis on money and banks, see —* :51.
Weydemeyer (in Frankfurt) informs M that the sale of his silverware («- :39] will hardly exceed the cost of redemption [—> :48).
M’s son Guido (Heinrich Guido) dies suddenly.
M receives a letter (Oct 14) from Rothacker (NY) with unfavorable news on the prospects for founding a paper there [«- :3lj.
In Manchester, E begins a study of military science.

E departs for Manchester to go to work in the firm of Ermen & Engels, mainly to support M while he works out his theory of polit eco. From this time on M&E carry on a regular correspondence, beginning with M’s letter of Nov 19. E’s first residence in Manchester is 70 Great Ducie Street, Strangeways [-+ 52:38).
The new CL/CC in Cologne issues a circular (“Address”) to the membership on the split in the League; text in ST/ME12 (CCT) 254.
Haupt (in Hamburg) sends M a report on the League situation there and on differences with Nothjung, emissary of the Cologne CC.

M receives the Cologne circular and a draft of the CC’s new statutes (for which, see MECW 10:634, incl M’s notes on the statutes); also a communication to the London CL on Bruhn’s activity in Hamburg with a request to take a position on it; and info on the fantastic plans for revolution sent by Willich in letters to H. Becker.
M&E draft a statement for Pfänder and H. Bauer against a Willich-Schapper slander campaign (#ME52).

Re his plan to publish NRZ-Revue as a quarterly beginning Feb [«— :41), M writes H. Becker (in Cologne) about undertaking the task. M also asks about the possibility of publishing a German trans of his Poverty of philosophy (#M681) and a "library” of socialist literature in a series of small pamphlets.
—M urges E to write a critical essay on Mazzini for the quarterly NRZ-Revue.
M writes H. Becker (in Cologne) about his plan to publish M’s Collected essays (#M151), from 1842 and later: this letter (not extant) prob contained specifications of the contents [—► 51:6).
M makes notes on Ricardo's book On the principles of polit eco [etc.], esp on Ricardo’s money theory (#M581). For M’s reading during the last months of this year, see—► :51.
M and his wife attend a lecture by Ernest Jones on the history of the popes.
The M family moves to 28 Dean Street, Soho, into two or three furnished rooms.
Weydemeyer proposes to M that a lottery be held for the silverware [«— :43); M will not give his consent.
Harney invites E to translate his Peasant war in Germany (#E579) for publ in Friend of the People.
E sojourns in London, staying with M.
At a New Year’s affair in London held by the Fraternal Democrats, attended also by M and his wife, E gives a talk on the causes of the failure of the revolution (cf MECW 10:637).
E begins studying the Russian language.
E replies that he lacks time right now, and (Dec 16) Harney assures him there is no hurry.
The London CL, M participating, approves the new draft Rules proposed by the Cologne CC [<— :45).
Miquel (in Göttingen) writes M reporting on his activity for the CL.
W. Wolff (in Zurich) writes M about the tribulations of German refugees in Zurich; he has nothing to report on the CL.
M draws up a statement replying to an attack by Ruge pubd in the Bremen press on ]an 17; signed by M&E (#ME162). (The Bremen paper will not print it.)
H. Becker (in Cologne) writes M with more info on Willich’s letters containing plans for a "revolution” (putsch) under a dictatorship [-> :10).
M meets with Landolphe and informs him on the split in the CL.
The Deutsche Londoner Ztg reprints the “Review / May to Oct” (#ME136) in part.
M receives a letter (Dec 15) from Wilhelmi (in Cincinnati) proposing that M&E contribute to German-American papers he is going to found. (M will decline.)
Becker informs M that the Collected essays project [«- 50:46] is being held up by lack of book paper [—► :11].
M corresponds with Schabelitz (in Bern) on publ of the NRZ-Revue as a quarterly in Switzerland.
M wants to force pub’r Schuberth by court action to continue publishing the NRZ-Revue as a quarterly, and Jan 17 he asks W. Haupt (in Hamburg) to get a lawyer [—► :11).
M writes E with a criticism of Ricardo's theory.
E presses M to hurry and finish his book.
M is studying the question of ground rent.
M appeals to E for money: the landlady is pressing for two weeks' unpaid rent.
E sends £1.
Social soiree at M's house brings Harney and his wife, Liebknecht, Eccarius, Pieper.
E attends a Chartist meeting at which E. Jones defends the platform of the left Chartists.
E informs M that he plans to organize a local club or regular meetings based on discussions of the Com Manifesto with Chartist left-wingers.
E intends to write a series of articles for Harney’s Friend of the People on the 6migr6 Central Comm of the European Democracy (Mazzini, Ruge, Ledru-Rollin, etc.) (—► :13J.
M asks H. Becker (in Cologne) to send him the Wiilich letters [«- :5]. (He will not get them.)
Dronke (in Geneva) informs M on the activity of A. Majer, emissary of the Willich-Schapper group in Switzerland, against M and his group; Dronke asks for info and suggestions.

Harney supports a meeting (held to honor Polish Gen. Bern) together with Willich-Schapper and L. Blanc; M denounces this (to E) as Harney’s turn toward allying himself with the anti-M wing of the emigration.
M urges E. Jones not to support the so-called Banquet of the Equals (celebration of the Feb Revolution anniversary on Feb 24) with the new 6migr6 alliance of L. Blanc + Willich-Schapper + Harney.

The French Blanquist Tessier du Mothay informs M on the background of the Feb 24 banquet, involving a Byzantine tale of clique rivalry between L. Blanc and Ledru-Rollin in the French emigration, with Blanc now lining up Harney and Willich-Schapper on his side.

Two of M’s supporters, K. Schramm and Pieper, try to attend the banquet at the Highbury Bam Tavern, chaired by Wiilich. They are beaten up physically and thrown out, in a public act. Among others, Harney is present, sees this, and makes no protest. At midnight Pieper, clothes ripped, comes to M's house and tells him about it.

La Patrie (Paris) reveals that Blanqui had, on request, sent (Feb 10) a “toast,” or political message, to the Feb 24 banquet, but since Blanqui's toast had attacked L. Blanc and others, it had been suppressed by the banquet organizers [—► :14).
M sends an account of the Feb 24 affair to the Cologne CL and asks that the German workers be informed.
Meeting Landolphe, M learns that he now supports Willich-Schapper and will participate with L. Blanc in a Willich-Schapper banquet on Feb 24, anniversary of the Feb Revolution.
H. Becker (in Cologne) sends M a file of the old RZ, to be used in editing the Collected essays project [«- :6j; he had found the RZ file after much effort.
Haupt (in Hamburg) informs M that the lawyer for the proposed court action against Schuberth [<— :6] wants his expenses guaranteed; the matter is dropped.
M sends the RZ file back to Becker, marked to indicate what to condense out of which articles, for the proposed Collected essays.
M sends E his views on his developing theory of money, resulting from his study of polit eco and his criticism of Ricardo.
E informs M that he has sent Harney three articles in the planned series [<- :9] and speaks of six more (none extant); also that he has helped to found a Chartist branch locally.
On hearing of Harney’s turn toward a right-wing alliance [<- :10], E resolves to write Harney withdrawing the articles he has sent.

Together with M, E sends a letter to Harney sharply condemning him for his participation in the Feb 24 banquet and for his new political alliance. (This inaugurates a period of distant relations with Harney.)

E visits M in London to discuss how to expose the scandal of the Feb 24 "Banquet of the Equals," the beating-up of Schramm and Pieper, and the suppression of Blanqui’s toast [«— :10], now disclosed. M&E translate Blanqui’s toast into German and English. The German version, with a prefatory note by M&E (#ME81), is printed up in 30,000 copies for wide distribution.
E sends an open letter to the Times, signed "Veritas,’’ dealing with this affair and enclosing a copy of Blanqui’s toast in English (#E827); it is not pubd.
M sends a report on the latest happenings to the Cologne CL/CC, with Blan-qui's toast.
Harney in his Friend of the People pubs an open letter by K. Schramm on the Feb 24 attack, with an ed note assuring Schramm of his confidence.

L. Blanc, Willich and Schapper, and the other banquet organizers publicly deny all knowledge of Blanqui’s toast, denying its suppression. (Not long after, a conscience-tom Vidil reveals that these people, as the organizing comm, formally voted, seven to six, to suppress the toast.)
Rothacker (in NYC) informs M that Weitling’s Republik der Arbeiter and other German-American Democratic papers are printing attacks on M.
M has two meetings with the Hungarian “baroness’’ Wilhelmine Beck, former Kossuth agent, to discuss the Hungarian emigration.

To E. I. Koch, a German Catholic priest and contributor to New Yorker Staatszeitung who wrote Feb 26 with the request, M sends 20 copies of the Com Manifesto plus the English trans in Red Republican, and proposes that the trans be pubd as a brochure.
H. Becker (in Cologne) reports that the first three printer’s sheets of M’s Collected essays (#M151) have been typeset [«- :11]; he also sends 50 talers.
M sends Daniels (in Cologne) an extensive critique of a big work by Daniels that he has just read, Mikrokosmos, subtitled “Sketch of a physiological anthropology’’ (M's letter is not extant).
In Notebook VII, M writes up some “Reflections'* on polit eco (#M728).
Continuing his study of Ricardo, M indexes Ricardo’s book (#M582) and makes notes (#M583). Also see #M527, a still-unpubd ms.
In desperate financial circumstances, M draws a draft on his mother in Trier, thereby leading to a heated correspondence.
M’s daughter Franziska is bom.
M writes E of a “mystbre” (secret matter) which he promises to explain in his next letter and which involves E in some way |-* :23].

After the falling-out with Harney [«- :13j M’s relations with E. Jones become close; by now (if not earlier) M begins working with Jones’s Notes to the People (writing and general editing) and helping Jones with his articles about cooperativism.
Daniels (in Cologne) writes M that Lassalle is “isolated” and his efforts at “reconciliation” with the Communist group have been rejected; he warns that Lassalle may appeal to London.

Daniels replies, expressing the Rhenish Communists' view that Lassalle is “a shallow blagueur and a pure-Democratic charlatan,” that the hostility to Lassalle is not “personal” in origin, and that M is “deluded” in Lassalle's favor.

M asks Weerth and Daniels to obtain money and a passport for W. Wolff, who has been expelled from Zurich and will go to London. In his letter to Daniels, M defends Lassalle against the Cologne branch.
E drafts a memo (not for publ) discussing the prospects from a military standpoint of a revolutionary France faced in 1852 by counterrevolutionary invasion (#El 77).
M proposes that E write a history of the Hungarian revolutionary war of 1848-49.
H. Becker (in Cologne) writes M about his plan to publish a communist magazine Neue Zeitschrift with Bürgers, Daniels, Weydemeyer, et al; he requests M’s collaboration.
M asks Weerth (in Hamburg) to write an article against Kinkel for this projected organ.
M promises Becker he will contribute as requested.
Becker pubs a prospectus for the Collected essays (#M151).
The first fascicule of the Collected essays is pubd in Cologne.

In a letter to Daniels (in Cologne) M criticizes Feuerbach’s philosophic views, and opines that Daniels has not fully freed himself of this influence [cf <— :16); M also requests shipment of Feuerbach’s works.
Daniels sends M the seven volumes of Feuerbach’s works.
Stimulated by an article in the 1845 Economist, M studies literature on the application of electricity to raising land productivity; he corresponds on this with E and Daniels.
M continues his study of Ricardo; he makes notes on Ricardo’s system (#M580).
M writes E: “In five weeks 1 will be finished with all the economic crap.... It is beginning to bore me.”
E replies: “I'm glad you’re finally finished with the Economics. The thing has really dragged itself out for too long a time....”
M asks Freiligrath and Daniels to find a pub’r for his Economica. Freiligrath, via Ebner (in Frankfurt), tries Cotta, who says no.
Re the “mystfere” [«- :18), M writes E that he will have to visit E in Manchester to discuss it.
M’s desperate financial situation [<— :18] is eased a bit by receipt of money from E.
M receives £50 from Cologne friends via Daniels.
He receives £5 from Weerth.
M visits E in Manchester, where i.a. he discusses the “mystöre” (which prob concerns Helene Demuth’s pregnancy—see *Demuth, Frederick).
M sends the Cologne CL/CC a report on the whole episode of Blanqui’s toast [«- :14].
M attends a lecture by E. Jones on the cooperative movement [«- :19].
M encounters Harney at a lecture by Robert Owen, for the first time since their falling-out [«-:13J.
Freiligrath arrives in London from Cologne, and reports on the activity of the Cologne CL/CC, which is planning to hold a communist congress in a few weeks.

Haupt (in Hamburg) writes M of the beginnings of the new police crackdown on the Communists in Germany: arrest of Nothjung on May 10 in Leipzig (after touring Germany as a field organizer), arrest of H. Becker and Röser in Cologne on May 19.
Freiligrath informs M of the arrest of Bürgers on May 23 in Dresden.
Freiligrath and E. Jones visit M.

The outlines of the German police campaign become clear; those arrested are charged with treason. To maintain contact with Cologne, M begins correspondence with Bermbach, a CL member (KMC dates M’s contact with Bermbach a month later). All this is the beginning of the process leading to the Cologne Communist trial of 1852.

From Becker, M receives a single copy of his Collected essays, first fascicule (#M151), just off the press (<-:20). M sends Becker, as requested, a copy of Poverty of philosophy (#M681) for excerpting in Becker’s planned magazine [«- :20].
The arrest of Becker [«- :24], added to financial difficulties and other police harassment, means the collapse of the Collected essays project and of Becker’s proposed Neue Zeitschrift [«- :20).
Most of the Collected essays edn is confiscated by the police at the Hartmann bindery; few copies, if any, go on sale.

M agrees to write a preface to Daniels’s work on anthropology [«— :16]; he will expound this thought: “The Communists have to show that only under communist conditions can the technological truths already attained be put into practice.’’
—M begins work on an article for E. Jones’s Notes to the People, which he is now supporting very actively [*- :19; —► :28).
Lassalle writes M that he is “voraciously hungry’’ for his opus on polit eco, which he asks about.

Mrs. Keene, wife of the London Daily News correspondent, brings M letters from Daniels (in Cologne) confirming that the arrest of Becker and Bürgers suspends the plans for Neue Zeitschrift and M’s Collected essays [«— :25J.
W. Wolff, expelled from Switzerland, arrives in London.
E visits M in London, no doubt i.a. to discuss the CL crisis in Germany.
Weydemeyer (in Frankfurt) informs M of other arrests in Germany.
M writes Miquel a letter dealing with the arrests of Rhineland Communists (source: KMC).

As a result of police seizures of CL literature found in the homes of Communists arrested, a number of German papers publish the “Address to the CL’’ (#ME2) and other CL documents—first a Dresden paper on June 28, then others (into July).
Jones’s Notes to the People pubs M’s article on the French constitution of 1848 (#M180).
Lassalle reports his fruitless negotiations.
M asks Lassalle to find a pub’r to continue issuing the Collected essays (#M151) [«- :25).
M explains to Weydemeyer that the subject ramifies so much that he cannot finish before another “six to eight weeks,” but the work is “rapidly” ending.
Helene Demuth [<- :23] gives birth to a son; see *Demuth, Frederick.

Writing to Freiligrath, M discusses his letter rejecting the invitation of the right-wing Democrats (Ruge, Fickler, Goegg, etc.) to help them found an 6migr6 club; Freiligrath emphasizes his political solidarity with M.
Miquel [<— :27] writes M about the effect of the Communist arrests in Germany on intimidating the Democrats.
—M writes Lassalle a letter with “descriptions of the German professors of revolution in London/’ i.e., the 6migr6 Democrats.
M attends the funeral of Gustav Julius, a German “True Socialist” writer who, M felt, was evolving leftward.
M and other CL leaders come into conflict with K. Schramm, who, just before leaving for Paris, wants to deposit the CL document files with Louis Bamberger rather than M.
Weerth, who has been living in the same house as M, is about to leave London, and M asks him to deal with the pub’r Campe (in Hamburg) about publishing a paper.
M writes E about a project to supply the German-American press with articles through a lithographed correspondence service, aided by E and Wolff.
M requests Reinhardt (in Paris) to send him Dureau de la Malle’s Economie politique des Romains via Karl Weerth. (Reinhardt will send the volumes on July 23.)
M writes E reporting that Ebner has written that Gotta will prob publish the Economica.
Ebner (in Frankfurt), to whom M on Freiligrath’s recommendation has sent the plan of his opus, promises M to find a publisher. (Ebner is actually an Austrian police agent.)
M’s continuing financial situation is so bad that it interferes with his work.

M sends Weydemeyer (in Zurich), who is preparing to emigrate to America, a recommendatory letter by W. Wolff to Reichhelm, co-owner of the New Yorker Staatszeitung, and suggests he look up Dana of the NYDT.
Bermbach [«— :24] sends M a report on the Prussian government’s investigation directed against the arrested Cologne Communists.

Since the London weekly How do you do? has slanderously linked M to the Prussian min of the interior, F. von Westphalen (M’s brother-in-law), M visits the weekly’s office accompanied by Freiligrath, W. Wolff, and Ziegenhainer, and demands redress from the pub’r L. Drucker and editor H. Beta.

M sends E a load of gossip about the London 6migr6 world. Through Ulmer, Rumpf, and Liebknecht, M is in contact with a small opposition group in the ranks of the right-wing Democrats and the Willich-Schapper-controlled GWEA.
In a German 6migr6 flysheet pubd in London, E. Meyen writes that M is now completely isolated politically whereas in the first period of the emigration he had a dominant position.
The Basel pub’r Schabelitz visits M a few times and fills him in on the doings of the London German emigration, Kinkel’s 6migr6 club, Ruge's group, etc.
M writes E a long letter with a detailed summary of the contents of Proudhon’s book.
E begins reading and annotating Proudhon’s book (cf #E196) (—► :46).
M proposes to Hoffmann & Campe (Hamburg pub’r) to print his planned brochure against Proudhon’s book.
H&G reply with a refusal.
M reads Idee g6n6rale de la revolution au XIXe sidcle, sees it as a direct polemic against communism, and plans to publish a critical brochure against it.
M receives a proposal from Charles A. Dana that he (also Freiligrath) write articles for the NY Daily Tribune (KMC dates receipt of letter as Aug c.5).
M informs E of Dana’s proposal, and asks him to write an article on the German situation by the 15th.
M suggests that E write a series of articles on “Germany from 1848 on.”
E begins work on the series later known as Revolution and counterrevolution in Germany (#E699) [- :46).
M learns from E. Jones’s letter that M’s 1848 article on the June revolution in Paris (#M425) has been translated in Notes to the People.
M gives a close reading to Dureau de la Malle’s work [«- :33].
E informs M that he is under constant surveillance by the Manchester police, and suggests that political documents be kept in a safe place.

M&E read in the press about the arrest of Paris members of the Willich-Schapper group and the start of the investigation into the so-called German-French plot (which will be featured in the Cologne Communist witch-hunt). Many German papers echo the Prussian government’s fiction that M is responsible for Willich-Schapper documents.
M sends E a long criticism of an article by Techow, “Outlines of the approaching war [and revolution].”
E returns an equally long analysis.
M’s friend Weydemeyer sails from Le Havre for America [-* :46].
A Cologne correspondent of the Augsburg AZ pubs the tale that the police investigation was helped by an alleged indiscretion by M in connection with a Baroness Beck [-» :45].
Dronke (in Geneva) writes M on the politically ambiguous role of Sazanov and on Swiss political affairs; also, he and two Frenchmen have translated half the Com Manifesto, Sazanov the other half.
Freiligrath writes M that pub’r Löwenthal (in Frankfurt) has finally rejected the publ of M’s opus.
Mrs. M’s cousin Werner von Veltheim (Ostrau) sends M £14, 15 shillings.
M writes a statement (#M849) denouncing the Baroness Beck tale [«- :42j; it is pubd in Germany on Oct 9,18.
Karl Blind and his wife visit at M's house, along with Freiligrath, F. Wolff, Liebknecht, and Pieper.
Bermbach sends M an extensive report on the Prussian government’s investigation into the arrested Cologne Communists.
Pieper (in Frankfurt) reports to M on his findings in Cologne.
Dronke arrives in London.
M receives a request from Ewerbeck (in Paris) for biographical material on M&E for Ewerbeck’s French book on Germany. (M&E will agree, Oct M, to send him a few lines.)
M writes a recommendatory letter to Dana for Weydemeyer, and gets Freiligrath to do the same.

Since on Oct 8 Pieper is going to Frankfurt as a private tutor in the Rothschild family, M commissions him to get info on the arrests of Communists when he passes through Cologne, by contacting Mrs. Daniels.

M sends A. Cluss (Washington, D.C.) his views on the “German-American revolutionary loan" which Kinkel is collecting in the US; M suggests that Cluss participate in the Kinkel congress being held in Cincinnati.
M proposes to Weydemeyer (in NYC) publ of the Macfarlane English trans of the Com Manifesto as a pamphlet. (This will not be done.)
Bermbach reports to M on his failure to find a German pub’r for M’s Poverty of philosophy (#M681).
E’s first two articles in the NYDT series on Germany (#E699) are pubd under M’s name.

M proposes to Weydemeyer that he publish a "pocket library" of pamphlets reprinting major articles from NRZ (incl W. Wolff’s “Silesian billion,” Weerth’s feuilletons, #E461, #M95, and so on), or else M&E’s anti-Heinzen articles of 1847 (#M531, #E152), or even new articles, and also that he take orders for NRZ-Revue copies. (This will not be done.)
E sends M his ms notes on Proudhon.
E resumes work on his critique of Proudhon’s new book [«-:37].
M writes E that Ebner has another pub’r prospect for the Economica, a Dessau bookdealer. (Nothing will come of this.)
Pieper reports that Ebner has had no success with publishers.
Ebner sends M a report on his (alleged) efforts to find a pub’r for the Economica, and requests M to write him on London 6migr6 matters.
M commissions Pieper (see «- :45) to see Ebner (in Frankfurt) about finding a pub’r for the Economica or for Poverty of philosophy (#M681).
M works himself deeply into debt [—► :53].
Reinhardt, Heine’s secy in Paris, writes M conveying Heine's best wishes.

E continues his study of Russian and other Slavic languages, also Slavic history and literature. He reads Bowring’s Specimens of the Russian poets, and he excerpts Lomonosov, Derzhavin, Sumarokov, Bogdanovich, Kheraskov, Karamzin, Zhukovsky, Krylov, and other Russian writers. He reads some classic works in the original, incl Pushkin and Griboyedov, and translates some of Eugene Onegin into prose.
read: Bowring_Sir John,Lomonosov,Derzhavin_Gavriil Romanovich,Sumarokov_Alexander Petrovich,Bogdanovich_Ippolit Fedorovich,Kheraskov_Mikhail Matveyevich,Karamzin_Nikolai Mikhailovich,Zhukovsky,Krylov,Pushkin_Alexander Sergeyevich,Griboyedov_Alexander Sergeyevich,Onegin_Eugene

text: K. Schramm, who was arrested in Paris (Sep A) and then expelled, is once again working in close assoc with M.
Pieper writes M on his meeting with Miquel and on Miquel’s proposals for new methods in presenting communist propaganda.
M asks Cluss (in the US) to help Weydemeyer, who has recently emigrated [<- :42].
NYDT pubs four more articles in E’s series on the German revolution (#E699).

M writes E that he has again gone through E’s notes on Proudhon [*- :46] and proposes to combine E's with his own critique to make a brochure on Proudhon, to be pubd. Some days ago (M relates) he had read Proudhon’s earlier Gratuity du credit in the library, and found it worthless.
From Cluss’s letters M learns that the first articles sent in have begun appearing in NYDT [«- :46).
See —► :53 on M’s visit to E.
Pieper and Ebner (in Frankfurt) write M on various unsuccessful attempts to get a pub’r.

M&E exchange ideas on questions involved in M’s opus, esp in re Proudhon vs Bastiat. E supports, and M rejects, a suggestion by pub’r Lowenthal that the opus begin with the history of polit eco—to be followed, adds E, by volumes on “the Socialists," the “critique of polit eco,” and “the famous positive part—what you ‘really’ want.” E urges that the main point is to appear in print “with a big book."
M visits E in Manchester, also meeting Weerth and W. Wolff; he discusses his Economica with E.
Having been haled into court for his debt to one Gohringer, M is ordered to pay up. He is kept afloat by small sums sent by E and Weerth, and by £20 drummed up by Freiligrath.
After returning from Manchester, M sends E his first letter addressed no longer to “Lieber Engels“ but to “Lieber Frederic” [—► 56:10].

To break the press “conspiracy of silence” about the arrests of the Cologne Communists, M sends letters to Paris for publ in the French press; W. Wolff is doing the same for America and England; M asks E to work up letters to the Times and the Sun.
—M meets with some newly arrived German refugees who are in opposition to the Willich-Schapper leadership of the GWEA.
Louis Bonaparte executes his coup d’6tat and declares himself emperor as Napoleon III.

Writing to M, E comments on the coup as a parody of Napoleon's “18th Brumaire” (Nov 9, 1799). E thinks this event makes it advisable to postpone efforts to get press publicity on the Cologne Communists.
Reinhardt (in Paris) sends M valuable letters reporting on the situation in France.
In a letter to E, M admits he is “quite bewildered” by the French events, but makes some analytical remarks.
M begins work on his essay The 18th Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte (#M267).

E receives a letter (Dec 1) from Weydemeyer (in NY) asking for articles for his forthcoming weekly Die Revolution; E sends it on to M (rec’d Dec 17) suggesting that M write an article on Bonaparte’s coup.
M writes Weydemeyer about the articles he expects to send shortly, and asks him to announce a series of articles on Proudhon, a “critique by KM” [*- :51).
M&E discuss the writing of articles for Weydemeyer with W. Wolff, F. Wolff, Weerth, Freiligrath, Eccarius. M begins work on his essay (see Dec 16 above).
M asks Freiligrath to write a New Year’s poem for Die Revolution.
M receives his first news from Dana on the appearance in NYDT of the articles sent in [«- :51], for which he receives £1.
M rejects Lassalle’s plan to set up a joint-stock company in Germany to publish the opus.
M, accompanied by Freiligrath, visits Marie Schmidt-Dohnhardt, wife of Max Stimer.
E visits M in London.
M attends the London CL branch meeting; a letter from Cologne reports on the government’s continued delay in bringing the Cologne defendants [«- 51:24] to trial.
—E. Jones visits M, and they discuss support to Jones’s Notes to the People as against Harney’s Friend of the People, in which M’s opponents are collaborating.
The French 6migr6 Madier visits M.
M writes Freiligrath with critical comments on the latter’s anti-Kinkel poem; Freiligrath revises the poem.

On the basis of info received Jan 24 from Bermbach (in Cologne), M requests E to draft a letter to the Times on the treatment of the Cologne Communist prisoners. E sends his draft on Jan 28; M sends it to the Times, dated Jan 29, signed “A Prussian” (#ME180). E sends a similar letter to the Daily News. Neither is pubd; efforts to get protests into the English press on the Cologne witchhunt are fruitless.
The group in GWEA opposing the Willich-Schapper leadership sets up a new German workers* society, with Stechan as chairman; M supports them and helps formulate their statutes.
M sends Ch. 1 of The 18th Brumaire (#M267) to Weydemeyer for publ in his magazine.

The first issue of Weydemeyer’s Die Revolution appears in NYC. It reprints a part of the “Review / May to Oct” (#ME136) under M’s name, and runs the announcement requested by M [«- 51:56) for his planned critique of Proudhon.

Mrs. M sends Ch. 2 of The 18th Brumaire to Weydemeyer, also M’s request that Weydemeyer write up the case of the Cologne Communists, about which the German-American press under Kinkel’s influence is silent.

M receives Weydemeyer’s letter of Jan 5 and learns about the publ of his first number, and about other German-American papers in NYC, esp the Tum-Ztg, in which Weydemeyer has just pubd (Jan 1) an article titled “The dictatorship of the proletariat.” (The Tum-Ztg begins publishing E’s Peasant war in Germany, #E579, from Jan 1852 to Feb 1853.)
E writes two articles for Die Revolution on England (#E241); unpubd.
M sends Ch. 3 of The 18th Brumaire, with other material for publ.
M inquires from Weydemeyer about a possible American publisher for his opus.
M is ill in bed for two weeks, continuing his work on The 18th Brumaire (#M267) only with great difficulty.
Freiligrath sends M £10 raised among his friends.
Weerth, in London for a few days, visits M.
M is visited by several French revolutionaries, incl Massol, Villiferes, Bianchi, Sabatier.

M is visited for the first time by the Hungarian officer Bangya, who gives him info on the mutual relations of Kossuth, Mazzini, Kinkel, and the anti-Kossuth Hungarian 6migr6s. Bangya also offers the collaboration of Szemere and Perczel on Weydemeyer’s Die Revolution.

M receives from Ewerbeck (in Paris) some copies of his book L’Allemagne et les Allemands [«- 51:45), in which M is praised as a critical genius who has drawn the final revolutionary consequences from the Hegelian dialectic.

M receives from A. Cluss (in the US), dated Jan 20, a report and materials on A. Goegg’s “Revolutionsbund” (League of Revolution) in America, and on Heinzen’s attacks on M’s communism in his paper Janus.
M writes Weydemeyer with info on the case of the Cologne Communist prisoners and asks him to get material into the German-American press.
Reinhardt (in Paris) sends M info on the situation in Paris, which M uses in part for his 18th Brumaire. (M will send excerpts from Reinhardt’s letter to Lassalle, Feb 23.)
M receives a report from Weydemeyer on his activity in America, also requesting CL documents.
At the CL meeting, M moves to exclude W. Hirsch, who has been shown to be a Prussian police agent; the place and time of CL meetings are changed [-» :13J.
M receives an invitation to a banquet for the fourth anniversary of the Feb Revolution held by the right-wing French emigration; he does not attend.
Writing to Lassalle, M refers to the “definitive rejection of my Economics by the bookdealers.”
M sends Schabelitz (in Basel) Pfänder’s anti-Willich statement for publ in Schweizerische National-Ztg.
M sends Ch. 4 of The 18th Brumaire (#M267) to Weydemeyer.
M receives from Weydemeyer (dated Feb 6/7, with addendum by Cluss) the news that Die Revolution has suspended publ.
M suggests to Weydemeyer that The 18th Brumaire be pubd in separate fascicules.
Mrs. M sends Weydemeyer Ch. 5 of The 18th Brumaire, also an article on Hungary by Bangya.
M gets E. Jones to write a criticism of Heinzen for Die Revolution (in expectation of its resurrection). Jones sends the article on Mar 5.
M asks E to sharpen his criticism of the Frankfurt Assembly Left in his next NYDT article in the series on Germany (#E699).
Notes to the People pubs the first part of E’s article on the French workers’ apathy in Bonaparte’s coup (#E653).

In a letter to Weydemeyer, E discusses the political and economic situation in England; he promises another article on England. (This was either not written or was one of those that got lost—cf #E241.)
—NYDT pubs one article this month in E’s series on Germany (#E699).
E is overwhelmed by work in his firm, and has little time to write.
M has to pawn his overcoat and cannot go out to the library; the household cannot buy on credit from the butcher; M’s eyes hurt from the strain of working at night.
M falls into esp deep financial straits, and is unable to write.

In a letter to Weydemeyer, M gives him advice for his political polemic against Heinzen, incl a notable statement about his (M’s) special contributions on the class struggle and on the “dictatorship of the proletariat.”
M receives from Cluss (Mar 1) a report on the right-wing emigration in America, Kossuth, Kinkel, Goegg, Heinzen, et al, and a request for advice on how to fight them.
At a regular CL meeting, M reports on Cluss’s and Weydemeyer’s activity in America, esp against Heinzen and Kinkel; the meeting approves.

M writes Weydemeyer on Jones’s plan for a new Chartist paper; also about a deal in which Die Revolution would publish Szemere’s pamphlet against Kossuth and add Bangya as an editor, this Hungarian alliance to bring him $500 (from Szemere’s wing of the Hungarian emigration).
Besides spending time with Bangya, M makes the acquaintance of the Hungarian, Col. Szerelmey.
Sorge, stopping in London en route to NYC, visits M.

From an anonymous letter signed “A.” (dated Feb 29), M learns that W. Hirsch [«- :7] sent the Berlin police a spy report on the London CL meeting of Jan 15, thereby causing the house search of Mrs. Daniels in Cologne.
M writes E that his letters are being opened by the police.
Kölnische Ztg pubs M’s statement (sent Mar 3) refuting a calumny in the Cologne Communist case (#M850).
M writes pub’r Wigand (in Leipzig) about publishing his opus.
Wigand replies in the negative, referring to the “risks to be run from the state.”
M receives from NYDT payment (£9) for the first nine articles in the series on Germany (#E699). Four articles in this series are pubd this month.
M sends Weydemeyer Ch. 6 of The 18th Brumaire (#M267), plus articles by others.
M sends the concluding Ch. 7 of The 18th Brumaire to Weydemeyer.
Jones’s Notes to the People pubs the second part of E’s study on worker apathy in the Bonaparte coup (#E653).
At Bangya’s request, M writes some “pen sketches“ of the right-wing leaders of the Democratic emigration: he gives them to Bangya for forwarding to Paris.
M is planning to write an article against Mazzini’s attacks on socialism, for Weydemeyer’s magazine.
Writing to M, E mentions that his firm in Manchester may be liquidated and that he may move to Liverpool, where he will be burdened with less work; E also describes his progress in studying Russian.
M receives £3 from Lassalle.
M proposes to invite Bangya to a CL meeting; Bangya declines.
M writes Cluss (in the US) about the Harney-Jones conflict in the Chartist movement.
Dronke arrives in London from Paris.

M sends Weydemeyer material for his article in the NY Tum-Ztg on Kinkel and his “revolutionary loan" campaign, which held a congress in London yesterday; included is info on factional fights in the Kinkel camp.
Szemere (in Paris) sends M, via Bangya, the German ms of his pamphlet on Kossuth, Görgey, and Batthyny, for publ by Weydemeyer in America.
NYDT pubs three articles in the series on Germany (#E699).
Jones’s Notes to the People pubs the final third part of E’s study of worker apathy in Bonaparte’s coup (#E653).

M receives Weydemeyer’s news (of Mar 30) that he has no money or pub’r to put out The 18th Brumaire (#M267) as a pamphlet or to continue publishing Die Revolution. M writes Weydemeyer to try to get Dana to publish The 18th Brumaire in English; failing this, to return the ms immediately, for publ in London in German or English.
M hears from Weydemeyer (Apr 9) that a German worker, a tailor from Frankfurt, has contributed his savings of $40 so that The 18th Brumaire can be pubd; work will begin immediately.
Bangya proposes that M write an anonymous pamphlet of “character portraits” of the German 6migr6 leaders, for a German bookdealer with whom he claims contact.
M writes E about Bangya’s proposal, the pamphlet to be written by both of them, using excerpts from past letters and other materials. (This will become The great men of the emigration, #ME72.)
E spends several days with M in London (KMC dates this Apr 11-13, the Easter holiday).
M's child Franziska dies of bronchitis.
Franziska’s funeral: M has to borrow money for this from a neighbor, a French 6migr6.
M receives Bermbach’s letter (May 3) from Cologne with the news that the Cologne Communist trial is scheduled to begin in June or July.
M corrects the German trans of Szemere’s pamphlet [«- :17).
K. Schramm moves to America, bearing a “cautiously worded” recommendatory letter by M.
M helps E. Jones in his work on the new Chartist organ The People's Paper, on both business and editorial aspects and by supplying foreign news items; the subscription list grows.
E writes M on the latest report from Ebner about the possibility (indefinite) of lining up Löwenthal as pub’r of the opus.
M&E work at collecting material for The great men of the emigration; they solicit Dronke, W. Wolff, Cluss, Freiligrath, Weydemeyer, et al for biographical material on émigré leaders.
M receives Dana’s proposal (Apr 20) that he write NYDT correspondence on current English politics.
Bangya presses M to finish The great men of the emigration (#ME72).
Weydemeyer pubs Die Revolution in NYC as an irregular periodical, containing M’s 18th Brumaire (#M267) and Weydemeyer’s reply to anti-M attacks by Teilering and Heinzen.
M starts drafting a NYDT article on Gen. Klapka’s program (#M346.5); not finished.
M visits E in Manchester, where they work on The great men (KMC dates this May c.26 to June c.26).
E’s personal situation is improved as a result of a new business agreement between the partners of Ermen & Engels; he can now increase his financial aid to M; he sends M £10 at once.
See <— :22 for M’s visit to Manchester.
M asks Bangya for an advance payment for the pamphlet, a payment which Bangya was supposed to have given Mrs. M.
Bangya writes Mrs. M that he is not in a position to pay.
Returning to London from Manchester, M dictates (alternately to his wife and Dronke) a clean copy of the pamphlet (#ME72), to be sent to Bangya.
M&E hear from Weydemeyer about die formation of a CL branch in NYC.
Helped by Freiligrath, who vouches for him to Panizzi, director of the British Museum Library, M renews his library card, which he has not used since the end of 1851 [-► :30].

From Bangya M gets info bearing on the Prussian government's case against the Cologne Communists: on the role of the agent-provocateur Cherval-Kramer who as a police agent led a Willich-Schapper group in Paris and figured in the "German-French plot" with which the Prussian police are trying to link the Cologne defendants.
M makes the acquaintance of Eduard Vehse, who comes from Paris with a letter from Reinhardt.
M devotes “a great deal of running around" to raising money for the funeral of the wife of CL member Klose.

M receives a letter from Cluss (July 4) on the activity of Kossuth and Kinkel in America, incl news of Kinkel’s public statement that "M&E are rascals who have been thrown out of the London pubs by the workers.” M sends an inquiry about this invention to Kinkel, who is now in London.
Kinkel refuses to respond except to challenge M to sue. M replies with a sharp denunciation of Kinkel’s dishonesty.
Ebner (in Frankfurt) writes E that his efforts to get a pub’r for M’s opus are still fruitless.
NYDT pubs one article this month in the series on Germany (#E699).
M gives Bangya the ms of The great men of the emigration (#ME72) for publ [<— :24J.
M resumes work in the BM Library [<— :26], studying general history, history of political institutions, culture, and the position of women. (For details, see-* :56,57.)
E studies and makes notes on Görgey’s book and other writings on the Hungarian revolution.

M&E follow the struggle going on inside the German emigration around the money collected by the German-American "loan" (fund) organized by Kinkel [«- :17]. Their source of info is Imandt (a CL member since July), who is urged by M to send reports to the German-American press.

M receives from Cluss (July 22) a secret June 2 circular of Kossuth’s urging German-Americans to campaign in the US presidential election for US armed intervention in Europe to provoke revolutionary changes; Cluss has had this printed in the NY Herald. To air this irresponsible proposal, M has Jones publish it in his People’s Paper (Aug 7) with a critique.
Weydemeyer writes E that his NYC branch of the CL has five members.
M receives a letter (July 9) from Bermbach reporting on the situation of the Cologne defendants and on house searches by the Cologne police looking for letters from M.
M&E learn that the Cologne Communist trial, set for July 28, has now been postponed for three months.

M makes the acquaintance through Bangya of the Hungarian 6migr6 Gustav Zerffi, recently arrived from Paris. Through Zerffi, M sends The 18th Brumaire (#M267) and a letter to Szemere (in Paris), whom he asks to write for Jones’s PP.

M offers Leipzig pub’r Brockhaus Die Gegenwart, a work (to be written) on "modem literature on polit eco in England 1830-1852," discussing the "general works" on the subject and "special works" on "population, colonies, the bank question, protective tariff and freedom of trade, etc.’’; also a work on "the present state of the parties [in England]."
Brockhaus rejects these proposals.
M writes his first article for NYDT, about the English elections, and sends it to E for trans.
M writes another NYDT article on the English elections. Again E translates it and divides it into two, dated Aug 20 and 27 (#M189, 758) [—► :36].
NYDT pubs one article this month in the series on Germany (#E699).
M’s first articles (#M272,138) are pubd in NYDT.
M writes Bangya, pressing for publ of the Great men pamphlet (#ME72) [«- :29].
E translates it and breaks it into two articles, dated Aug 6 and 10 (#M272, 138).
M has Pieper translate the first chapter of The 18th Brumaire (#M267) into English, believing he has a bookdealer lined up to publish it [—* :36].
M inquires from Lassalle, Ebner, Streit, and Naut about the possibility of publishing The 18th Brumaire in Germany—in vain.
M runs across literature on military affairs in the BM Library and sends E a list.

M mobilizes his supporters to back Jones at two Chartist meetings where Jones is attacked for the revolutionary policy of his People's Paper, by moderate Chartists (Holyoake et al) who want to concentrate on universal suffrage, dumping the rest of the Chartist program. Jones is upheld.
The Cologne Communist trial is finally set to begin on Oct 4.
Bermbach sends M the passages in the indictment of the Cologne Communists in which M’s name figures.
Through Bangya’s good offices, M talks with an Orleanist agent who travels between Paris and London, and gets info on Orleanist plans in France.
Weerth, in London, stays with M.
From Zerffi (in Paris) M receives a piece by L. Hafner on some leaders of the German emigration.
M writes to Bermbach, using the address of the Cologne merchant Kothes, and urges him to send news on the trial.
NYDT pubs M’s articles on England (#M189, 758) [«- :33).
NYDT pubs one article this month in the series on Germany (#E699).

At M’s request, E revises Pieper’s English trans of The 18th Brumaire [«— :33). But efforts to obtain English publ are vain. Also vain are efforts to get it pubd in Germany, after writing to Lassalle, Ebner, the bookdealer F. Streit (in Coburg), and Naut (in Cologne). Bookdealers turn the proposal down because of M’s subversive reputation at a time when an anti-Communist witch-hunt is getting under way.
M sends Zerffi one of his NYDT articles on England, for publ in France. Zerffi offers it to Girardin’s La Presse, which rejects it.
The fear by bookdealers of publishing writings by M (see «- :36) equally militates against the possibility of getting M’s opus on polit eco pubd, even if it were finished (cf —> :53).

(or Oct) In Manchester, E moves from 70 Great Ducie Street, Strangeways [«- 50:44] to no. 48 on the same street. (Note: Sometime between now and 1858, E moves to 34 Butler Street, Greenheys; see—> 58:4.)
M gets £4 from E.
He gets £2 from Freiligrath.

The M household is in financial trouble: there is no money for a doctor or medicine for Mrs. M, daughter Jenny, and Helene Demuth, who are ill; they can afford to eat only bread and potatoes; M cannot write his NYDT articles because he cannot buy newspapers.

The Cologne CL members who were arrested in May 1851 are finally put on trial. From now until the end of the trial (Nov 12) M and his friends labor to help the defense expose the government’s evidence, by sending documents and other materials to Cologne by various channels.  NOTE: References here to the charges and issues at the Cologne trial can be fully understood only by reading a detailed account of it: for example, M’s pamphlet on the trial (#M762) or the explanatory intro to ST/ME12 (CCT).
M sends a critique of the government’s indictment, for the use of chief defense counsel Karl Schneider, to Bermbach via the merchant Kothes.
Kothes is arrested in Cologne and interrogated; he deposes that he passed M’s letter to Bermbach. (He will be released Oct 20.)
Bermbach is arrested and interrogated, his house searched, then he is released.
M sends (via Dronke) various materials on the prosecution witness Hentze to defense counsel Schneider.

M sends the German press a statement charging Police Chief Stieber with perjury for his Oct 18 testimony about Cherval; M threatens to publicize Stieber’s 1848 letter to NRZ [«— 48:85] in which Stieber claimed Democratic views. M’s statement (not extant) is not pubd by any German paper; the Prussian post office sends it to Stieber.
Bermbach is again arrested, at Stieber’s instigation.
Kölnische Ztg pubs Stieber’s testimony of Oct 23 on the (fake) minutes book of the CL/CC (called the “Original-Protokollbuch” by the police agent W. Hirsch).
M is under police surveillance in London and the English government is opening his mail: so he writes to E.

M, with the help of friends (E, Weerth, Steinthal, Freiligrath, Ebner, Dronke. Liebknecht, et al), draws up a detailed letter to defense counsel Schneider, giving info on Cherval, to refute Stieber’s testimony; it also discusses the political differences between the Willich-Schapper league documents cited by the prosecution and the documents of Marx’s CL. M sends several copies of this letter, plus supplementary documents, to Schneider by various routes, to ensure receipt. (This letter is not extant; its content is given in M’s letter to E, Oct 28.)

M sends Bürgers' defense counsel Hontheim, via Ebner, material for the defense, incl mss by W. Hirsch and Stieber’s 1848 letter to NRZ. M receives from Schneider an urgent request to supply evidence to expose the fake “Protokollbuch.”

M has a London magistrate’s court certify various documents disproving the “Protokollbuch” and sends them to counsel Schneider, along with other documents refuting Stieber’s testimony, plus instructions to Schneider, addressing them by different routes.
Kölnische Ztg reports the testimony of Oct 27 by a police inspector about a (forged) letter by M accompanying the “Red Catechism."
Several London papers publish a statement on the Cologne trial (#ME31) signed by M, E, Freiligrath, W. Wolff.
—M signs an affidavit at the Marlborough Street police court that he had nothing to do with the “Red Catechism" [-♦ :45J.
M proposes to E the publ, after the trial ends, of a circular “for the info of the public" to expose the Prussian trial. He asks E to contact pub’r Campe (in Hamburg).
M now proposes not a mere circular but a pamphlet, not for political discussion but to attack the Prussian witch-hunt; he asks E to raise money.
L. Hafner writes M defending himself against the rumor, said to be spread by the police, that he is a police spy.
M is visited by the Hungarian, Col. Pleyel, who presents a recommendatory letter from Bangya; M gives him a similar letter to E.
Heine sends his regards to M, via Reinhardt.
M asks Weerth (in Bradford) to get info via Franz Duncker on the bookdealer Eisenmann (in Berlin) who was supposed to have ordered the pamphlet.
E urges M to demand an accounting from Bangya.
Weerth writes M that Duncker says that Bangya’s “Eisenmann” does not exist.
As E urges, M makes remonstrances to Bangya. In a letter to E, Oct 29, Bangya says the brochure will either appear in Nov or he will return the ms [-► :49].
Disturbed by the delay in publishing the Great men pamphlet (#ME72), M&E try to find out more about Bangya’s claims.
The People's Paper republishes M’s four NYDT articles on the English elections (#M272, 138, 189, 758).
—NYDT pubs the last two articles in the series on Germany (#E699); a final article written by E for the series is not pubd.
M writes Cluss (in the US) with suggestions for articles against Kinkel and Heinzen, and sends material.

NYDT pubs M’s article (#M533) on Bonaparte’s relations with supporters of Kossuth, based on info from Bangya and Zerffi. (It will be reprinted in other US papers and evokes a storm of indignation from pro-Kossuth papers.)
M receives from Cluss 130 copies of the brochure edn of The 18th Brumaire (#M267) pubd in NYC by Weydemeyer.
M’s landlord threatens the bailiff to collect the rent; to buy writing paper M has to pawn an overcoat.
M receives £2 from E.
M receives about £15 from Dana in payment for NYDT articles.
(rec’d 3): Defense counsel Schneider (in Cologne) acknowledges the safe receipt of the letters and documents sent by M from Oct 25 to Nov 1, partly in three copies.
M’s statement on the “Red Catechism" (#M943) [<- :39] appears in the London press; M sends it to Schneider.

M and friends make an investigation and prove that W. Hirsch fabricated the “Original-Protokoll-buch” [«- :39] on orders from the spy Fleury acting for Police Lt. Greif, who was assigned by the Prussian embassy in London.
M tells E that he thinks all the Cologne defendants will be acquitted.
The Cologne trial ends with seven of the defendants given three to six years in jail, four acquitted.
M learns this news from the German press of Nov 13.
M presents the London CL with the proposal to dissolve, since the League has ceased de facto to exist in Germany as a result of the police suppression; the proposal is adopted.
M asks E to write an article on the trial for NYDT [—* :54).
The Morning Advertiser pubs a statement on the trial (#ME58) signed by M, E, Freiligrath, W. Wolff.

M works on a pamphlet on the Cologne trial (#M762) [<-:40], incl new material on the evidence. He contacts Schabelitz (in Basel) for publ [—► :50). The Prussian police hear of the coming pamphlet, give advance orders for its seizure, and try to line up the Belgian and other police to do the same.

M drafts an appeal for material support to the Cologne prisoners and their families, and forms an aid comm with Freiligrath as treasurer. The appeal is signed by 20 people, incl E. Jones [-» :50]. (For text, cf MEW 8:602.)
M meets with Vehse [<- :27], who leaves London on the ninth.
M meets with Weerth, who is going off to the West Indies.
M has several meetings with K. Blind, who has moved from Belgium to London.
NYDT pubs four articles written by M, on the looming economic crisis, English political affairs, etc. (#M645, 670, 62, 672).
One of the articles on England that E wrote for Weydemeyer [«- :4] is pubd in the NY Tum-Ztg (#E241).
Weerth writes M that another bookdealer named by Bangya, Collmann of Berlin, is not traceable [—► :51J.
The pub’r Schabelitz (in Basel) asks M to send him his pamphlet on the Cologne trial [«- :47|.
M finishes dictating a clean copy of his Revelations concerning the Communist trial in Cologne (#M762).
M sends the ms to Schabelitz for publ.
M sends a copy of the ms to Cluss (in the US), also a copy of the appeal for aid to the Cologne victims [«-:47], now dated Dec 7 [-* 53:4).
Scbabelitz writes M that the printing of the pamphlet has begun |—> 53:5].

M writes Bangya demanding an accounting on the delay in publishing the Great men pamphlet (#ME72) [«- :42], and asking for info on the various (nonexistent) publishers named by Bangya. Bangya replies the same day, promising clarification; “trust me."
M writes to Zerffi about the Bangya problem.
Zerffi replies that Bangya has long had relations with the Prussian police and prob gave them the ms.
M writes Zerffi that he prefers not to expose Bangya right now, before the publ of the Cologne defense pamphlet.
Szemere, in his first letter to M, warns against both Bangya and Zerffi, who “at most are good only to get something from the enemy camp.“ Szemere praises The 18th Brumaire (#M267).

NYDT pubs a letter to the editor by M (#M435) on the piece pubd Oct 19 (#M533) re relations with Bonaparte by Mazzini and Kossuth supporters. M denounces attacks by the “crypto-Royalists” and stresses he was not attacking Kossuth but warning him.
M sends a letter to NYDT (#M740) quoting Kossuth’s reply; pubd fan 4.
M receives from Cluss (in the US) an open letter by a self-styled secy to Kossuth, attacking M.
M sends his original piece (#M533) to Kossuth (in London, via Bangya) and requests his stand on the “secretary.” Kossuth replies he has no secy in America and thanks M for the warning.
M writes (to Cluss) that the Cologne trial has totally eliminated the possibility of getting a publisher for his opus (cf +- :37).
M writes an article for NYDT on English politics (#M635) and has it translated by Pieper; pubd Dec 28.
In two issues of his People’s Paper, Jones promises publ of M’s 18th Brumaire (but it will not be pubd).
E’s article on the Cologne trial [«- :47), sent Dec 1, is pubd in NYDT (#E423).
M asks Lassalle to send money to Herwegh (in Zurich), who is in financial straits.
E visits M in London (KMC dates: Dec c.23 to Jan c.10).
M corresponds with Cluss and Weydemeyer (in the US) about collecting a material-aid fund in America for the victims of the Cologne trial.

M makes the acquaintance of the Prussian ex-lieutenant Steffen, of Cologne, whom Freiligrath gave a recommendatory letter on Jan 2. (M will see Steffen often until July D; he performs various services for M. When Steffen moves to Chester in Aug, M will remain in correspondence with him for the following year.)
Cluss sends out to the German-American press the appeal for aid to the Cologne victims which M has sent [«— :50). (It will be pubd in a couple of papers.)
M corresponds with Cluss (in the US) on the possibility of an American edn of the Cologne defense pamphlet [-» :15).
M’s reply to Kossuth’s “secretary” (#M740) («- 52:52) is pubd in NYDT on Jan 4. NYDT pubs two other articles on English politics this month (#M228, 868).
Schabelitz (in Basel) completes the printing of the defense pamphlet (#M762).
The pamphlet comes off the press in Basel.
M studies the theory of money and other questions of polit eco, also the history of culture, and history of the Slavs. (For details, see —> :49-55.) For E’s studies, see «- 52:2.
Through E. Jones, M gets an invitation from the Chartist exec to attend a public Chartist meeting on Feb 22.
M is visited a number of times by Zerffi, who tells of Bangya’s activity as a spy [<-52:51).
Five articles pubd this month, as follows.
Two articles on English politics and economic conditions (#M674, 230).
Another, with an important section on “The Duchess of Sutherland and slavery” (#M271).
Another ditto (#M135), the first article for NYDT written by M in English, on Jan 28.
First article on the insurrection in Milan (#M423).

In view of the sharpening antagonisms between Russia and the Western powers over the Balkans and the Middle East (the “Eastern Question”), M&E exchange letters discussing their opinions. At M’s request E writes articles which will appear in NYDT during Apr (#E654, 874).

E calls M's attention to a book by Urquhart he has just read, Turkey and its resources (1833). E gives a thumbnail sketch of the book's cranky ideas on Islam, etc., and calls Urquhart “this crazy M.P. who claims that Palmerston is paid by Russia” [-► :15).
NYDT pubs three articles on Continental affairs and English politics, incl two dealing with the Milan insurrection and the role of Kossuth (#M59, 641, 320).

Pub’r Schabelitz (in Basel) writes M that 2000 copies of an extra order for the Cologne “Revelations” pamphlet (#M762), printed for Germany, have been seized by police in a border village between Switzerland and Baden.
People's Paper reprints M’s article on Sutherland and slavery (part of #M271) [<- :8).
M hears from Cluss (Mar 6) that the “Revelations” pamphlet (#M762) will be pubd in the Boston Neu-Engfand-Ztg [-►    :15].
M is ill with a bad liver inflammation.
M writes E: “I came near to croaking....”

E writes M that he is financially “in a tight fix”; that he will move to cheaper lodgings in about a week, and reform his lifestyle to cut down expenses, at least until his father comes to Manchester.

M hears from Cluss (Mar 24) that the police agent W. Hirsch will publish his “Confessions of a mouchard,” claiming that M gave the ms of The great men of the emigration (#ME72) to the police, distorting M’s relation to Bangya.
M writes an expose of Hirsch (#M374) and sends it to a NY German-American paper [-► :19).

Writing to Cluss (in the US), M approves his and Weydemeyer’s connection with Die Reform, an “honest” workers’ paper. (M will maintain this association for the rest of the year; some of his London circle will contribute to Die Reform, which will reprint some of M&E’s NYDT articles.)
