Writing to Kugelmann, M mentions a German univ. lecturer in polit eco who has written M that Capital wholly convinced him but his position forces him to be silent “like other colleagues." This “cowardice of the mandarins of the profession” plus the press “conspiracy of silence" has harmed the book’s sales. Meissner is still 200 talers short of his production costs.

After the interruption due to illness, M resumes work on Capital; he studies questions of credit and bank circulation, also commercial mathematics, in books by J. L. Foster, F. E. Feller, and C. G. Odermann, making many excerpts.
Lafargue (in Paris) writes M that Blanqui lends M’s Poverty of philosophy (#M681) to all his friends and has “the greatest esteem" for M, whereas he has only contempt for Proudhon.
De Paepe (in Brussels) writes M that he has failed to find a publisher for a French edn of M’s 18th Brumaire (#M267).
M vainly pursues the effort himself.
E stays in London with M; they visit Beesly.
E pays the first quarterly installment (for Jan-Mar) of M’s new annuity [«- 68:67] (cf E to M, Feb 25).
GC sessions: M attends Mar 2. 9. 23; absent Mar 30.
At GC: M reports on anti-TU police actions in Nuremberg.
M calls the GC’s attention to a pamphlet pubd on the condition of life insurance companies.
M nominates GC speakers for the Sunday League meeting of Mar 16.
At GC: M reports on the German bookbinders’ union.
In connection with the Sunday League’s drive for Sunday observance, M argues that the best guarantee against Sunday labor is factory legislation, not religious observance.
For action on the Bakunin Alliance, see —► :18.
S. Meyer (in NYC) sends M his first report on the German-American movement.
At GC: M proposes rescinding the GC resolution for an address to the Spanish Cortes [*- 68:61, 68] because of events in Spain.
Eccarius receives the Feb 27 communication from Bakunin’s Alliance and informs M.
M drafts a reply (#M344) for submission to the GC. and sends it to E, who approves it Mar 7.

At GC: M presents his draft reply; it is adopted and ordered sent out to sections as before. The decision accepts the dissolved Alliance into IWMA sections, and states that sections may shape their own theoretical programs as long as these do not run counter to the IWMA’s [—> :40].
Bebel warns M, on the eve of the GGWA congress at Barmen-Elberfeld, not to be taken in by Schweitzer’s maneuvers.
At the GGWA congress, where Liebknecht has been invited to present the Bebel view, a large number of delegates abstain in the vote of confidence in Schweitzer: a moral defeat for the latter.
M declines an invitation to be a speaker at a memorial meeting for E. Jones.

Hearing of Liebknecht’s plan to publish E’s Peasant war in Germany (#E579) in his paper, E writes M that he would prefer it be pubd as a separate brochure; he proposes that the paper run his Prussian military question (#E644) instead.
Meissner writes M that commercial considerations require postponing publ of The 18th Brumaire (#M267) [<- :8].
E suggests publishing a larger book containing both The 18th Brumaire and the three articles comprising M’s Class struggles in France in the NRZ-Revue (#M148).
M thinks this suggestion undesirable for various reasons.
M reads Castille's Les massacres de juin 1848, and Vermorel's Les homines de 1848; he sends Beesly his annotated copy of the Vermorel.
In spite of bad health M continues his IWMA activity and work on Capital.
Daughters Jenny and Eleanor go to Paris to visit the Lafargues [—► :35|.
M plans to visit Laura, who is ill in Paris, but he has to put off the trip since the French police learn of his intention.
E takes up the study of the Dutch-Frisian language.
GC sessions: M attends Apr 13, 20, 27; absent Apr 6.

At GC: M reports on the first socialist speeches made in a parliament: made in the North German Reichstag by Schweitzer and Fritzsche (GGWA) and by Bebel (who speaks as an IWMA member as well as for the UGWA).
M proposes that the inheritance question be put on the agenda of the coming congress, as requested by Geneva.
M brings up, and the GC discusses, the problem of the London French branch, which is again compromising the movement.
M criticizes the IWMA’s Geneva comm for getting involved in “every little strike” without effective preparation.
After a report from Hins (in Belgium) on the massacre of strikers in Seraing, M is assigned to write an address on “The Belgian massacres.”
M reports that since “fresh outrages” have occurred in Belgium, the GC address should be taken up next week to get new info; other measures should be taken in the English movement [—► :30]
M reports on Gen. Cluseret’s reply to Bonapartist slanders.
On the basis of Liebknecht’s report (Apr 3) on the GGWA congress [<- :19], M&E discuss Schweitzer’s setback with satisfaction.
F. W. Moll sends M a report on the anti-Schweitzer tendency inside the GGWA and on the Solingen section of the IWMA.
E. Werner writes M for the German bookbinders’ union (Leipzig) asking info on bookbinders’ unions and publications in other countries.
H. Hillmann writes M for the Elberfeld socialists in opposition to a compromise between Bebel’s UGWA and Schweitzer’s GGWA.

In response to J. M. Ludlow’s article on Lassalle in the Fortnightly Rev, M sends Capital to Ludlow, points to its preface’s passage on Lassalle, stresses that he rejects Lassalle’s politics and that he (M) showed the “historical necessity” of TUs when all economists and socialists were still condemning them.
M rereads Diderot’s Le neveu de Rameau, one of his favorite books, a “unique masterpiece” (cf M to E, Apr 15).
M suffers from a liver ailment and is unable to work.
GC sessions: M attends May 4,11, 18; absent May 25.

At GC: M presents his address on “The Belgian massacres” (#M75) [«— :25], and discusses the issues. The GC decides to publish it as a flysheet and circulate it widely in Continental languages; it is pubd through May in English, French, and German.
M reads the GC an appeal issued by the Working Men’s Union of NY on behalf of the striking horse-car conductors.

At GC: Referring to Eccarius’ Bee-Hive report on the GC address on the Belgian massacres, Lessner criticizes Eccarius for suppressing M’s name and putting himself forward instead; M takes part in the discussion.
M presents his draft of an address to the National Labor Union of the US (#M7), calling on the workers to stop the threat of an Anglo-American conflict; pubd May 15-22 in English and German.

At GC: M reports on the police background of the leader of a Brussels “Revolutionary Committee” (with a name similar to the IWMA’s) which advocates killing, etc. (This group had been disavowed by the GC on May 11.)
M reports on a debate in Antwerp between a capitalist and an IWMA workman.
M discusses the warmongering tendency in the US government.
E. Gogarten (in Radevormwald) writes M asking for help in establishing a philanthropic-social weekly.
Moll, for the Solingen socialists, asks M to get shareholders for the Solingen producers’ cooperative and to raise financial support for it.

E. Werner [«- :26) asks M to establish a link between the Leipzig bookbinders and the English union; he also reports on the founding of a Leipzig section of the IWMA, consisting of members of the GGWA, the local workers’ assoc, and the TUs. In response, M sends him info from Manchester about the English unions.
M gets a visit from Eichhoff.
M receives a letter from S. Meyer (in NYC) with much info on the US workers’ movement; also a letter from Harney (who has moved to America) asking for a copy of Capital.
M gets the Urquhartite Diplomatic Rev to publish a series of articles on Russian policy by Borkheim.
M reads the official British reports on child labor in agriculture.
Harney’s letter from America (see <— :32) says he wants to find a translator and a NY pub’r for an American edn of Capital.
M reads the galley proofs of the second edn of his 18th Brumaire (#M267) [—► :38).
Mrs. M goes to visit the Lafargues in Paris; she returns with daughter Eleanor [♦- :23].
E sends money to M for the families of the victims of the Belgian massacres.
M hears from Vienna that Peter Fox has died there after a short illness. He writes Fox’s rich mother to make sure she gives financial support to Fox’s widow and children.

M stays with E in Manchester, accompanied by daughter Eleanor; they make a three-day excursion to the Yorkshire village of Bolton Abbey, where M meets the geologist John Dakyns, who has applied to join the IWMA and who agrees with M’s hostility to Comtism.
GC sessions: M attends June 15, 22; absent June 1, 8, 29.
Looking to the coming IWMA congress, De Paepe (in Brussels) writes M asking him to draft a resolution on the collectivization of landed property, as against the position of the Proudhonists |—► :40).
At GC: M attends, but no participation is recorded.

At GC: M reads out a letter from Solingen criticizing the “so-called free religious communities” of the Friends of Light movement. —M reports on Werner’s requests for the Leipzig bookbinders [«— :31).
M attends a TU mass meeting in Exeter Hall, in support of the bill to extend TU rights, where Beesly makes an “excellent speech” recalling the June 1848 days in France.
M writes, and dates, the preface (#M268) to the second edn of The 18th Brumaire (#M267) [-► :43].
M stays in Manchester [«— :35], until June 14.
GC sessions: M attends all four—July 6, 13, 20, 27.
At GC: M reports on IWMA progress in Holland, esp Amsterdam.
GC resumes precongress discussion of the land question (begun June 29). M takes part, with two talks on the issue, esp criticizing the Proudhonist view (#M598).
At GC: M reports on the German cigarmakers’ strike, on the basis of letters from Fritzsche (July 11) and Liebknecht (July 7).

At GC: M opens the GC’s precongress discussion on the right of inheritance: he refutes Bakunin’s line (abolition of inheritance as a basic programmatic plank), and agrees to present a resolution at the next meeting.
At GC: M reports that Bakunin's Alliance has accepted the GC’s conditions [«- :18], and proposes it be admitted.
In response to De Paepe’s request (<— :36], M sends him a longish letter (not extant) criticizing the Proudhonist doctrine on landed property.

M declines Liebknecht’s invitation to attend the Eisenach congress of workers' assocs called by the Bebel UGWA [—► :48). He urges Liebknecht to drop his past policy of alliance with the bourgeois-liberal People’s party, which should be opposed as he opposes the Lassallean sect; and he presses for carrying out the Nuremberg resolution [«- 68:49) on integration with the IWMA (cf M to E, July 3).
(rec’d c.17) Liebknecht asks M to draft a sociopolitical program for the coming Eisenach congress of the new party, and also to issue a statement against Schweitzer.
M protests, in a letter to Liebknecht, against the assertion in Demo Wochenblatt that the GC has sided with its tendency against Schweitzer.

In a letter to Bebel, M criticizes J. P. Becker’s proposal to structure the IWMA according to language rather than nationality, and warns against affiliating the new Eisenacher party to Becker’s “German-language group of the IWMA” in Geneva instead of directly to the GC.
The letters between M&E come under police surveillance—first some, then all are read by the police (source: MEW Daten).
Elisee Reclus visits M and gets a copy of the 18th Brumaire (#M267) autographed.
(summer): E begins work researching for a history of Ireland (cf #E352, 353).
The new (second) edn of M’s 18th Brumaire (#M267) is pubd in Hamburg. (This is KMC dating; cf E to M, July 25.)
E revises his unpubd draft [<-68:41) of a biographical article on M (#E405) [—+ :50].
M reads with great interest the book by G. Klemm, Die Werkzeuge und Waffen (1858).

With the June 30 end of his contract with Ermen & Engels, E ceases to work in the Manchester firm: “Hurrah! ... I am a free man!” He celebrates, with his guest Eleanor (M’s daughter), by taking a long walk in the fields.

M stays with the Lafargues in Paris, under the name A. Williams. He makes no political visits, but does much city walking, observing Paris’s “Haussmannization” and its decline in female pulchritude. (M’s letter to E, July 14, says he arrived in Paris “Tuesday [July 6) evening”— even though he was present at the GC that evening.)
M suffers from a painful abscess which interferes with his working.
GC sessions: M attends Aug 3, 10, 17, 24; absent Aug 31.
At GC: M reports on the coming Eisenach congress (see —► :48) which will establish a new party; also on his rejection of J. P. Becker’s scheme for IWMA language groups [«-:41).
M reads his draft of the GC report to the Basel Congress on the inheritance question (#M744); adopted.
M makes proposals for the agenda of the coming Basel Congress, to stress the “education question” over the “credit question.”
Writing to E, M comments on the Aug 3 GC session: he would gladly see the GC transferred to another city if there were capable people there; “the thing is getting boring.”
At GC: Discussing the education point on the congress agenda, M argues that free compulsory education need not be “governmental,” i.e., run by the state, even if state-superintended (cf #M590).
M makes proposals on the presentation of the GC financial report to the congress.
M reports a telegram announcing formation of the new Eisenacher party in Germany (see —* :48).
M proposes that the woman pres of the Lyons silk workers, Philomfcne Rozan, be given special credentials to the coming congress so that she can attend.
M reads the GC an "amusing article” by a French government organ slandering the IWMA as wanting “la dictature universelle.”
M urges Jung to attend the meeting of the carpenters’ union, where delegates to the Basel Congress will be discussed.

At GC: In the continued discussion on the education question, M reaffirms the IWMA position in favor of combining education with labor and technological training, but not in the form distorted by the bourgeoisie; he argues for excluding religion from the public schools (cf #M590).
M is assigned to send membership cards to Vienna.
Discussing the existing English and Continental peace societies, M declares he is “against having anything to do with peace societies”; they are “against the working man.”
At GC: M is assigned to draft the GC’s annual report to the congress.
At GC: Lafargue explains that M is absent because of illness, and that he has not yet finished the GC report {—*■ :53].

In Eisenach, the Bebel tendency (UGWA) unites with a group of oppositionists splitting from the Lassallean GGWA and with groups of independent trade-unionists, to form a new party, the Social-Democratic Workers party (SDWP). This party will be commonly known as the “Eisenacher party.“
M is informed of the founding of the SDWP by a telegram from Liebknecht.
E. Werner writes M of the intention of the Leipzig section of the IWMA to join the new party, and asks his advice.
M is informed by letter of the Eisenach congress’s decision to affiliate with the IWMA.
Elisäe Reclus visits M, and accompanies him to that evening's GC session.
Writing to E, M reports that Polish building workers in Posen have won a strike through help by Berlin unions, and sees the class struggle as a force doing away with national prejudices.
M expresses special regret over the sudden death (July 27) of W. Sylvis, pres of the National Labor Union (US). (The GC session of Aug 17 had decided to send an “address of sympathy” to the NLU.)
Max Friedländer writes M asking him to write for the Vienna Neue Freie Presse.
E’s biographical sketch of M (#E405) |<- :43] is pubd in German papers.
E sends M £100 to cancel old debts due to mishandling of funds by Mrs. M.
E goes on a trip to Germany, where he spends a few days with relatives in Engelskirchen.
GC session: M’s draft of the GC report to the congress (#M747) is taken up and adopted.
M sends to Basel his GC report and the draft resolutions on education and on inheritance.
The Fourth Congress opens in Basel (until Sep 12); M does not attend.
The congress hears the GC report (#M747), read in French by F. Robert.
Lessner sends M reports from Basel on the course of the congress. (KMC lists his letters of Sep 7, 8, 9, 11.)
The new GC is elected, incl M.

M’s draft on the inheritance question (cf #M744) is read to the congress and the question is discussed, but Bakunin’s position (abolition of inheritance) gets a plurality vote, though no resolution is carried.

GC session: All corr secretaries are reelected, incl M for Germany. M is named to a comm on cooperation with the National Labor Union (US), as proposed by A. C. Cameron to this session. (Lafargue sends M a report of this session, Sep c.20.)
GC sessions: M is absent (on a trip—see —► :56).

M travels, accompanied by daughter jenny, to visit Kugelmann (in Hanover). On the way they stop at Bruges and Li≥ spend a day at Aachen, with M’s cousin Karl Philips; travel up the Rhine to Cologne; visit Dietzgen in Siegburg; go to Bonn; spend a day with Paul Stumpf in Mainz; and then head for Wiesbaden, from which they travel to Hanover, arriving on Sep c.17.
M and Jenny stay with the Kugelmanns in Hanover [-► :59).
In Hanover, M meets with a delegation of metal workers' union men, led by union treasurer ]. Hamann, discussing problems of TU/party relations [—► :66].
E prepares a second edn of his Peasant war in Germany (#E579) |-» 70:57].

Prob around this time: a Russian trans of the Com Manifesto (#ME33) is pubd in Geneva as a pamphlet, without an imprint, prob done by Nechayev (not Bakunin); the trans is garbled and distorted [—* 70:29).

E, accompanied by Lizzie Burns and Eleanor M, takes a trip through Ireland, visiting Dublin, Killamey, Cork. E takes special note of the soldiery, decimation of the population, general distress, and the consequences of English colonial rule.
E writes M (in Hanover) describing his impressions of his Irish tour; he asks M to negotiate with Meissner for publ of a book on the history of Ireland, on which he has begun work (cf #E352).
In Hanover [«— :56] M is visited by members of the Brunswick Exec Comm of the SDWP (Eisenacher party), Bracke, Bonhorst, and Spier.
M is in Hamburg, where he meets with pub’r Meissner.
M arrives back in London.
E, in London, visits M (KMC dating for E’s visit: Oct 12-C.18).
M has a bad case of the grippe.
GC sessions: M attends Oct 19, 26; absent Oct 5, 12.

At GC: M is present for the first time since the congress. Toward the session's end Lucraft asks M to “say something on anything he pleased.” M reports briefly on progress in Germany, TU organizn in Vienna, and the admission of women as members of the bookbinders* union in Leipzig (organized by the Eisenachers).

At GC: M takes part in the discussion evoked by the great pro-Fenian demonstration in London (Oct 24); he is optimistic about the possibilities of action and the trend against anti-Irish prejudice; he is named to a comm to draft a resolution for the release of the Fenians.
M reports on the Dutch workers* congress in Arnhem on Oct 19, and reads a letter from the Leipzig bookbinders (E. Werner).
E works on his planned history of Ireland (#E352) [<— :58], researching the historical literature and original sources in Gaelic.
M, together with his wife and daughters Jenny and Eleanor, attends the great demonstration in Hyde Park in defense of the Fenians.
At GC: See «— :60.
M devotes time to studying the Irish question (for his reading, see—» :75). During this period M is active in the GC in mobilizing support for the Irish national struggle.
Bonhorst, of the Brunswick Exec of the SDWP (Eisenachers), writes M for advice on activity among the German peasants.
In a letter to E, M criticizes Liebknechts weakness and incompetence in the face of the German press campaign against the Basel Congress’s decision in favor of land collectivization.
M examines the ms, received from Paris, of a French trans of Ch. 2 by Charles Keller; he writes his comments on it, and returns the ms to Paris via Lafargue.
Lafargue informs M that Keller has reached Ch. 3.
From Danielson (in St. Peterburg) M receives Flerovsky’s work Polosheniye rabochevo klassa v Rossii, on the condition of the working class in Russia.

M begins to learn Russian, in order to read Flerovsky’s book and also the economic works of Chernyshevsky. M also uses Herzen’s Tyurma i ssylka as a learning text, from Nov to Jan 9 (cf Mrs. M to E, Jan c.17,1870).
GC sessions: M attends Nov 2, 16, 23, 30; absent Nov 9.
At GC: M inquires about steps to establish a British section of the IWMA.
M questions the inactivity of the corr secy for Belgium, M. Bernard.
At GC: A letter from M (who is absent) is read, proposing discussion of the Irish question and volunteering to open it.

At GC: M opens a discussion on the Irish question, specif the attitude of the British government, with a long talk, esp attacking Gladstone; he proposes a resolution in favor of amnesty to the Fenian prisoners (speech and resolution, #M834).
M reads the GC a letter from De Paepe (Nov 13) proposing to remove the inactive corr secy for Belgium, Bernard; Jung and Dupont are to see Bernard.

At GC: Discussion on the Irish question continues; Odger and Mottershead attack M’s view from a pro-Gladstone stance; M sums up, in favor of “speaking out boldly’’; he challenges Odger to submit amendments, for action at the next meeting (cf #M610).
M reports on the metal workers’ strike in Lüneburg, on the basis of letters from Hamann and Bomm (see -» :66).

At GC: M’s resolution on the Irish question is adopted unanim, though Odger’s objections (to soften criticism of Gladstone) lead to discussion by M et al. (Resolution, #M834, is pubd Nov 21, 28, in English press, later on the Continent.)
M announces he will bring up the case of Bee-Hive before the GC.
M reports on an economists’ congress at which a Belgian businessman approved the massacre of strikers at Seraing; also on the election of an IWMA worker to the Geneva cantonal council.

Re Bonhorst’s request [«- :62], E points out to M that the Basel Congress resolution for land collectivization is having a good effect; the movement must differentiate small peasants from big landowners; it does not demand the former’s collectivization.
Hamann [*-:56] writes M that the metal workers’ union has broken with the Lassalleans and invites him to attend the new union’s congress in Brunswick.
Liebknecht urges M to write on theoretical subjects for the Volksstaat (organ of the Eisenachers).
Bomm, the metal workers’ secy, writes M about getting aid for the Lüneburg strikers (see «— :65).
Hamann’s report of his conversation with M [«— :56], somewhat garbled, is pubd in Volksstaat (reprinted from the October number of the union paper). (See ST/14, 2:580.)
The Address of the Land and Labour League (founded Oct 27, for land nationalization) is drafted by Eccarius and edited by M, before publ as a pamphlet.
M gets a membership card in the new league, so dated (prob at the GC meeting).

M works on the section about ground rent and differential rent. He reads Carey’s Principles of social science, Johnston’s Notes on North America, and other works; and corresponds on these problems with E, who also reads Carey.
M is ailing with carbuncles.
GC sessions: M attends Dec 14; absent Dec 7.
M sends the GC resolution on the Fenians (#M834) [«-:65] to Isaac Butt, head of the Irish Home Rule movement.
At GC: The GC takes up the stream of attacks on it made by the pro-Bakuninist organ L’Egalitä (Geneva) and Le Progrös (Le Locle); M and others refute the points raised [—► 70:4].
M stresses the crucial importance of the Irish question “as the solution of the English [question], and the English as the solution of the European.”
Re the conflict in Germany of Lassalleans vs Eisenachers, M points out that Liebknecht, but not Schweitzer, is an IWMA member and accepts the GC as arbiter.
M sends a detailed letter to De Paepe, for the Belgian federation, on the disorganizing work of the Bakuninist Alliance in the IWMA.
M and Jung visit R. Shaw, a founder of the IWMA, the day before his death [—► 70:3].

M writes an eight-page memorandum (not extant) on the reasons for the land-collectivization decision of the Basel Congress, for use by Applegarth, who asked for it (GC, Nov 30) to justify the position before certain parliamentary figures.
The London GWEA, via Speyer, invites M to its Christmas social affair.
M gets a visit from Strohn.
Juch invites M to write an article for the first number of the Londoner Deutsche Post.
Gutsmann (in Breslau) writes M asking the GC to issue appeals for funds for the striking miners of Waldenburg.
M strives to raise money for the Solingen producers’ cooperative, through Menke (in Hamburg).
M informs E that Keller [«- :63] is interrupting his French trans of Capital to start translating The 18th Brumaire (#M267). (Keller will not accomplish this task.)
E goes to Germany, on the way visiting M in London; he stays with family people in Barmen.
GC sessions: M attends Jan 1, 4; absent Jan 11, 18, 25.
At GC: special meeting on the Bakunin problem; see —► :4.
At GC: M proposes R. W. Hume as a US correspondent, Serraillier as corr secy for Belgium, Pfänder as a GC member.
M reports on a letter from Bracke, for the Eisenachers’ Brunswick Exec, requesting loans to aid the striking miners of Waldenburg, Silesia [«- 69:72].
M defends the demand for reduction of the workday, against Bakuninist criticism; and announces that the Sub-Comm has replied to the charges of L’Egalitö (see —* :4).
M is named to a GC delegation to attend the funeral of R. Shaw [<— 69:70] and proposes a letter of condolence.
M moves to adjourn the GC’s Irish discussion; he announces the death in prison of the Fenian, Richard Burke.
M attends Shaw’s funeral with the GC delegation.
M meets with Cowell Stepney in the Reform Club.
M writes an obituary for Shaw (#M587); pubd Jan 15.
The Sub-Comm meets at M’s house.
At GC: In M’s absence, Jung reports that M has received a letter (dated Jan 12) from the Hanover metal workers’ Exec about contact with English unions.
M drafts the GC’s reply (#M345) to the recent stream of attacks on it by the Bakuninist center in Switzerland [«- 69:70).
A special meeting of the GC takes up this document and adopts it, for circulation to IWMA sections.

M puts some finishing touches on the piece, for Jung to send it out. M himself sends it to the Brussels section, along with a letter to De Paepe on the problem, esp written for the Belgians (not extant), which also deals in detail with the work of the IWMA.
The reply (#M345) is signed by the GC members and sent out to the IWMA sections as a “confidential communication’’ headed “The GC to the Federal Council of Romance Switzerland.”
In another letter to De Paepe, M summarizes the facts about the destructive work of the Bakuninists and transmits testimony from Geneva on their authoritarian character.
In his letter to De Paepe (see <— :4), M asks for info on books dealing with landownership and the agricultural economy in Belgium.
M finishes reading Herzen’s Tyurma i ssylka in the course of his learning Russian [«— 69:64).
Another grandchild for M: daughter Laura (Lafargue) gives birth to a baby girl (who, however, will die soon) [—► :16).
M is ill, with carbuncles and a cold.
E continues work on his history of Ireland (#E352); he studies Old Irish laws, and reads books by Wakefield, Prendergast, Murphy, and others.
E returns to Manchester from his German trip [<- 69:74).
GC sessions: M is absent from all (Feb 1, 8,15, 22).

The Sub-Comm takes up the appeal of A. Richard, a Bakuninist who has been expelled in a conflict in the Lyons section. Writing to E today, M says this case has been produced by the anti-Bakunin fight in Lyons, but although Richard is a Bakuninist, there is no case against him “and I will see to it that no injustice takes place” [—> :18).
M sends De Paepe a letter full of material on the atrocities of the English government’s treatment of Irish (Fenian) political prisoners, to be used for an article.
De Paepe prints M’s account as-is, in two parts (#M287), in L’IntemationaJe (Brussels).

With M’s help, daughter Jenny (using the pseudonym J. Williams) writes a series of eight articles on the Irish question for La Marseillaise (Paris), attacking the cruel treatment of Fenian prisoners (pubd Mar 1 to Apr 24 H :20); the text is in ST/ME28 [IIQJ 379, in English).
M is visited by Dakyns.
Neumayer (in Vienna) asks M to send material on the land question which he needs for his defense in court.
After a hiatus of some years, Imandt writes to M, on personal matters.
E sends money to the Solingen workers who have formed a producers’ cooperative [«— 69:72).

E, having received (Jan 28) Liebknecht’s request of Dec 20 for permission to republish the Peasant war in Germany (#E579) and his request for a new introduction, writes a new preface (#E580) by this date, and sends it for comment to M, who heartily approves (Feb 12) [—► :29).
M, having read to page 150 of Flerovsky’s book [«- 69:64), writes E about it with great admiration.
Laura’s baby («- :7] dies at about two months of age.
GC sessions: M attends Mar 15; absent Mar 1, 8, 22, 29.

At GC: M attends for the first time since Jan 4. In response to the application for affiliation by a Paris group of “proletarian Positivists” (Comtists)—an application already accepted by the GC on Feb 8—M and others establish that the group cannot belong as a Positivist branch of the IWMA but only as individual members constituting a section (cf M to E, Mar 19).
GC approves the affiliation of a Russian section in Geneva, which has asked (Mar 12) that M represent it in the GC.

M sends a communication (#M343) to the Russian section in Geneva informing it of the GC action and agreeing to represent it; he refers admiringly to the writings of Chernyshevsky and Flerovsky and to the issue of Polish liberation (pubd Apr 15).
Having received a request for membership from the pub’r of Het Volk (Rotterdam), Phillipp von Roesgen von Floss, M sends a query about him to Coenen (in Antwerp).
In M’s absence, the GC votes to send him its sympathy on his illness.

The Sub-Comm meets for the second time [«— :10] on the case of Richard (in Lyons), and although Richard is a Bakuninist, votes to clear him completely of the charges and to reverse his expulsion by the Lyons section.
At GC: The report of the Sub-Comm is unanim adopted; pubd Mar 27 in L'Internationale.

M warns Germany against the Bakuninists: as corr secy he sends the Eisenacher party Exec a “Confidential communication" (#M172), via Kugelmann, containing the Jan 1 circular (#M345) [«— :4] plus a summary of the Bakuninist problem.
M warns France: he writes Lafargue (in Paris) about the problem and asks him to keep an eye on Bakunin’s supporters in Paris.

M writes Liebknecht protesting against the publ in VoJksstaat of Nechayev’s reply (edited by Bakunin) to Borkheim’s anti-Bakunin article in Zukunft; he also criticizes evidences of the “Lassalle cult" in Volksstaat.
M sends 3000 IWMA membership cards to the Eisenachers’ Brunswick Exec.
M requests the Brunswick Exec to send its quarterly report on the movement in Germany, in accord with IWMA Rules.
M’s “Confidential communication” (#M172) to Germany: see«— :18.
E follows the debates in Parliament on the Irish question, specif the bill for police measures in Ireland and Gladstone’s Land Bill for Ireland (source: MEW Daten).
The first five articles in daughter Jenny’s pro-Fenian series [<— :11J are pubd (the third article is a collaboration with her father).
Writing to the Lafargues, M states his basic view on the importance of the Irish question as a key to the English revolution, which in turn is a key to world revolution.
M sends E an account of the background of Jenny’s articles and their reception.
E reports that in his work on the history of Ireland, he is now dealing with the 19th century.
M gives his views on the Irish question to Pigott, editor of the Irishman.
M’s preface (#M268) to the second edn of The 18th Brumaire (#M267) is pubd in Volksstaat.
M resumes work on the opus; he finishes his first revision of the ms for Vol. 2. (source: KMC; but KMC’s references do not seem to justify the date).
M receives the news of the death of Laura’s baby [«-:16].
M suffers from a cough and carbuncles.
GC sessions: M attends Apr 12,19,26; absent Apr 5.
At GC: With this session M resumes more or less regular attendance.
M sends Sorge (in the US) 15 copies of the report of the Basel Congress.
M announces he will raise the question of Bee-Hive.
M, on Lafargue’s recommendation, proposes IWMA credentials for Henri Verlet, editor of La Libre Pensde (Paris).
M and Dupont are named to draft an address denouncing the French government’s arrests of striking Le Creusot miners [-* :31).
As M sends Verlet’s credentials to Lafargue, he warns against establishing any branch with “sectarian labels," either communistic labels or (as in Verlet’s case) “freethinker.”
At GC: M opposes the proposal sent (Mar 26) by Hume (in the US) requiring the naming of different French, German, etc., representatives for American workers.
At GC: M proposes that the GC break with the now bourgeoisified Bee-Hive; he is named to draft a resolution |-* :31).
M proposes postponing the address on the Le Creusot strikers.
M reports on the joint congress of the Dutch and Flemish sections of the IWMA at Antwerp.
In a long educational letter to the Lafargues, M summarizes Bakunin’s ideas and his operations in the IWMA.
Lafargue sends M an extensive report on the activity of the Bakuninists and Proudhonists in Paris, esp Paul Robin [«- :18).

In a letter to Meyer and Vogt (in the US), M makes a statement on the key political importance of the Irish question for a revolutionary perspective (cf <- :20] and on propaganda about the issue in America.
M&E exchange letters on the lessons of the Poor Law Inspectors’ reports for 1870, esp on tenancy.
M is visited a number of times by Flourens, with whom he discusses the machinations of the Democratic 6migr6s and the London French branch.
M twice visits the dying Karl Schapper (Schapper dies Apr 28) [-» :32).
In a letter to Bracke (of the Eisenachers’ Brunswick Exec). E writes about the importance of getting workers’ representatives into the Reichstag. (An excerpt will be pubd May 14 in Volksstaat.)
E’s new preface (#E580) (♦- :14) to the Peasant war in Germany (#E579) is pubd in Volksstaat, which also begins serial publ of the work itself (five chapters, until June 25).
M receives from Geneva six copies he has ordered of the Russian trans of the Com Manifesto («- 69:57]; he sends one to E.
E again accepts election to the Board of Directors of the Schiller Institute (Manchester) [«- 66:60), but he is no longer active in its work.
GC sessions: M attends May 3. 17; absent May 10. 24. 31.

At GC: M reports on the French government’s persecution of the IWMA to promote its Bonapartist plebiscite; wholesale arrests Apr D. He proposes a declaration denouncing the charge of conspiracy, which is impossible for a real working-class organization. The declaration (#M222) is pubd May 4 and after.
M presents a resolution (#M751) on breaking with Bee-Hive [«- :24]; it is pubd in the press during the month. NB: The GC Minutes erroneously include this item under May 17.
Liebknecht writes M that the Eisenacher party invites the IWMA to hold its 1870 congress in Germany.
Bracke sends the official invitation for the party Exec.

At GC: In M's absence, Jung proposes M’s draft resolution (#M752.5) publicly disavowing the so-called London French branch (now calling itself the French Federal Branch), which had been expelled two years before but is still using the IWMA’s name.
M&E exchange letters on the place for the next congress.
At GC: M presents the invitation from the Eisenacher party to hold the next congress in Germany; he proposes Mainz.
See under May 3 for an erroneous entry.

At GC: M is absent. As a result of a to-do in the English and French press over the GC’s decision to hold the next congress in Germany, for the first time a GC member, Harris, echoes the charge made by IWMA enemies that the English GC members are only a “tool” of M and the German members.
M visits Borkheim, who is ill.
M asks E for material for an obituary on Schapper [«-:27].
In a letter to M on France after the plebiscite, E derides Bonaparte as an ass without historical perspective, while the French workers are showing that action (not theory) is their element.
M receives from Sorge newspapers and statistical publications on the situation of American workers (sent May 10).
In a letter to Liebknecht, M bids him take a stand in Volksstaat against Bakunin and his supporters.
M and daughter Eleanor stay with E in Manchester.
E works on drafting his history of Ireland (#E352) on the basis of his researched material (#E353); he leaves the work unfinished before ending the second chapter.
GC sessions: M attends June 28; absent June 7, 14, 21.
Liebknecht and the German party write M and the GC proposing to postpone the coming congress in Mainz to Oct 5 because of the Reichstag elections in Sep.

M&E write to the Brunswick Exec of the German party asking for energetic preparations for the congress, and warning against Lassallean attempts to disturb its work (#ME184); this letter is pubd in Volksstaat on June 26.
At GC: M. though absent, is assigned to draft an address in support of locked-out building-trades workers in Geneva.
M writes the German party Exec his strong opposition to postponing the congress.
At GC: M reports that Mainz has offered its Marble Hall for the IWMA congress.
M is instructed to write NY that the GC cannot afford to send a delegate to the congress of the National Labor Union (Cincinnati, in Aug).

Since the Federal Council of Romance Switzerland (Geneva) has asked the GC to take a position on the Bakuninist split at the Apr 4-6 congress in La Chaux-de-Fonds, M proposes that the GC recognize both committees, one as the Federal Council, the other (Bakuninist) as a local council only. The resolution (#M752), dated June 29, will be pubd July 23-24.
M proposes that the GC seat be transferred from London to Brussels.
M and daughter Eleanor return to London from Manchester K:34).
In a letter to Kugelmann, M discusses some recent notices of his writings in Germany, esp Lange’s dim view of Hegel and the dialectical method.
GC sessions: M attends all four—July 5, 12,19, 26.
At GC: M takes part in discussing the situation in France, where the government’s crackdown on the IWMA has put its leaders on trial (June 22 to July 5).
An appeal drafted by M on behalf of the locked-out Geneva building-trades workers [«— :36] is adopted (#M478).
After some discussion of the transfer of the GC seat out of London |«- :36], M agrees to continue the discussion, even though the proposal has been passed.
M reports on the organizational problems of the American section.
Sub-Comm meeting: M participates in working up the agenda of the coming congress.

At GC: The Sub-Comm’s points for the congress agenda are discussed, and elucidated by M. A point is added: a declaration against war. M explains that the “representation of labor question“ has been dropped because the political question of working-class parliamentary representation is presently applicable only to England.
M defends the GC action on the London French branch [<— :31] against F. Le Maitre, and proposes to ask the Paris section’s opinion.
M summarizes the question of moving the GC’s seat away from London [«- :39); there is an ensuing discussion with Hales.
In accord with the GC decision on moving the GC seat, M sends a communication (#M173) to the sections asking their opinion.
M sends Jung a revised version of the agenda for the coming congress, esp intended for Swiss and Belgian papers (#M696).
GC sessions: see —> :40.
Eugen Oswald writes M inviting him to sign a statement against the war that is being got up by a group of French and German 6migr6s [—► see below, July 26].
France declares war on Prussia.
M writes the First Address on the war (#M318).
M reports on France (from a letter by Lafargue), esp re the absence of war feeling and the French section’s antiwar manifesto.
The GC assigns M to write an address on the war. M insists on a GC discussion first, since the address must be focused internationally; a discussion ensues.
M gets an offer from N. L. Thieblen of the Pall Mall Gazette to go to Prussia as its war correspondent or do other writing on the war.

Writing to E, M expresses his first thoughts on the war, which he calls a “farce’’: the “French need a thrashing,” and Prussian victory would be useful for the advancement of the German workers’ movement (but cf —> below, July 28).
In a letter to M, E predicts Bonaparte will be defeated in the war.
Sub-Comm meeting: M presents his draft of the address on the war (#M318), which is adopted.
At GC: M’s address on the war (#M318) is read and approved; pubd July 28 in PMG.
M reports the refusal to vote war credits in the North German Reichstag by Bebel and Liebknecht, and their antiwar declaration.
M reports on the police persecution of the IWMA in France, and the arrest of Tolain.

Writing to Oswald [«- see above, July 18], M replies that he has already signed the IWMA’s address on the war and that only the working class can be a real antiwar force, but he does not close the door to signing [-» :45].

In a letter to the Lafargues, M gives his second thoughts on the war: “I should like that both, Prussian and French, thrashed each other alternately ...” but that Prussia win only ultimately, since Bonaparte’s defeat is likely to provoke revolution in France. He notes that “On both sides it is a disgusting exhibition.” Reporting that English workers are saying a plague on both their houses, he adds: “For my own part, I do everything in my power, through the means of the International, to stimulate this ‘neutrality’ spirit....” In a letter to E, M remarks that “fortunately” war feeling in Germany stems only from the middle class, not the working class, except for the Lassalleans.
M sends Liebknecht the First Address on the war (#M318) for publ in Volksstaat, and informs him of the GC’s approval of his and Bebel’s antiwar protest in the Reichstag.

At the request of M’s daughter Jenny, E writes a note (#E528) for a preface to a collection of Irish songs by J. Riss6 of Hanover (who, however, will not use it). Jenny sends it off via Kugelmann, July 17.
M informs E of Thieblen’s offer I«- :40 (July 20)] and suggests that E might use this opportunity to write for PMG.

After making arrangements with PMG, E begins writing his long series of articles “Notes on the war” (#E531), on military aspects of the fighting, which he will continue until Feb M, 1871. The first article appears in PMG on July 29. (See the Register for the table of articles.)

M is twice visited by Lopatin (recommended to him by Lafargue); they discuss the Russian revolutionary movement, esp Chernyshevsky’s banishment, and problems of the Russian trans of Capital, which Lopatin is working on.
M has continuing attacks of his old liver ailment.
GC sessions: M attends Aug 2; absent Aug 9, 16, 23, 30.
Since a number of corr secretaries have gone to France, M is burdened with almost all of the GC’s international correspondence.
At GC: M reports on antiwar statements in Germany, and has the Sub-Comm take up the case of a jailed antiwar protester in Paris.

In a communication to the Brunswick Exec of the German party (#M928), M explains why the congress must be postponed and asks for support. He sends the same request to J. P. Becker (in Switzerland), and answers an inquiry about Bakunin’s past political course, esp in 1848-49.
The GC decides to print another 1000 copies of the address on the war (#M318); few copies are left.

As against a Belgian proposal to shift the 1870 congress of the IWMA to Amsterdam, M proposes to consult the organizn on holding a conference instead of a congress, postponing the latter because of the war.
M suggests to Jung that he send the GC resolutions on the Bakunin Alliance to the Swiss federal comm in Geneva (Perret) for publ.
M receives okays on the congress postponement from the German party and J. P. Becker's comm in Switzerland, and gives them to Jung for the GC.

In his PMG series [«— :41) E pubs 15 “Notes on the war” (nos. II to XIV, plus two articles with separate titles) (#E531). In article no. XII, pubd Aug 26, E analyzes the French retreat and predicts the disaster of Sedan.
M finally agrees to sign Oswald’s antiwar statement I«- :40), reluctantly, and with two provisos. E's name is added on the same terms (Aug 5-7).
The IWMA address on the war (#M318) is pubd in Volksstaat, with passages on Prussia and Bismarck omitted to avoid suppression.
Writing to M, E expresses his conviction that Bonaparte’s fall is looming, and sends reports on the latest fighting.
M revises Liebknecht's German trans of the address (#M318), and Eccarius sends it for publ in the Aug issue of Becker’s Vorbote (Geneva).

From the Brunswick Exec of the German party, M receives a request for a statement of policy on the war in view of the dispute between the Exec and Liebknecht-Bebel over the defensive element in the war.
M&E exchange letters on war policy and the situation created by Prussia’s victories over the French armies.
While M is visiting in Manchester M&E write a letter to the Brunswick Exec on war policy in answer to their request (#ME88) [—► :48].
M collects clippings from the French press in his notebook (cf #M573).
The Oswald antiwar statement [*- :45] is pubd in Volksstaat.
M gets £40 from E for a trip to Ramsgate, for his health.
M and daughter Jenny go to Ramsgate.
Mrs. M and Eleanor come to Ramsgate too. M is suffering from severe rheumatic pains and insomnia.
M stays in London to consult a physician.
M visits with E in Manchester.
M returns to London.
While in Manchester, M works with E on an article on Karl Blind (#ME106), an expose of his politics, mostly drafted by E; it remains unfinished.

Writing to Sorge, M predicts that the present Prussian victory over France will lead inevitably to a war between Germany and Russia which will be “the midwife to the inevitable social revolution in Russia.’’
E writes M on the new situation in France created by the military defeat: he expects a “government of the left.’’
In Germany the Brunswick Exec of the Eisenachers issues a flysheet with the party’s position on the war; it quotes an excerpt from M’s letter (#ME88) [«— :45] (reprinted in Volksstaat on Sep 11).
At four in the morning M receives a telegram from Longuet (in Paris) on the fall of the Bonaparte Empire and the proclamation of the Third Republic.
M is active in pushing the GC into the lead of the developing movement in England for the defense of the new French republic, esp for its diplomatic recognition by England.
M receives several telegrams from the Paris Federal Comm urging the GC to do everything possible to force England to recognize the Third Republic.
M writes Prof. Beesly asking for aid to Serraillier’s destitute family and for support of the movement to recognize the French republic.

GC session: M reports on Serraillier’s going to Paris, where he has joined the National Guard; his wife should be granted a £1 stipend. M also reports on the requests from Paris for pressure on the English government.
The GC session ends when, summoned by a telegram, its members hasten to a TU meeting to swing the vote for a resolution supporting the French republic.
M sends IWMA campaign directives in defense of the French republic to Belgium, Switzerland, and the US.

M writes to Prof. Beesly again, urging him to break through the silent treatment of the IWMA, its manifestos and its activity, in the English press, and to write an article on the IWMA for the Fortnightly Rev. (Beesly’s article will be pubd Nov 1.)
M gives Applegarth ideas for a delegation to Gladstone to press for recognition of the French republic.

GC session: M reports on the German party’s request for advice on war policy («— :45] and his reply; on the Paris section’s address “To the German people” issued Sep 4-5; and on the organizn of antigovernment meetings by the German workers. After a discussion in which M attacks German annexationism in Alsace-Lorraine, M is named to a commission to draft an address to the German workers. (For his writing of the Second Address on the war, #M813, see —► :52.)
M meets with Serraillier (who is leaving for Paris the next day as the GC’s representative) and discusses how to help the Paris sections.

E discusses the French situation with Dupont (who is preparing to go to France). Writing to M, E criticizes the chauvinistic aspects of the Paris address “To the German people,” also criticizes the weak bourgeois leadership of the Third Republic, which will capitulate to the Germans; a guerrilla war by the French is unfortunately not likely.
In Germany, the members of the Brunswick Exec of the Eisenacher party are arrested by the government and imprisoned, for issuing the party’s manifesto on the war [->71:17].
In a letter to M, E stresses that the French workers must not allow themselves to be used as the French bourgeoisie’s tools to fight the Prussians; their chance comes after peace is signed.
M&E exchange letters on the news of the German government’s arrest of the Eisenachers’ Exec.
M sends a communication (#M597) to English periodicals, protesting this German arrest (pubd in PMG on Sep 15).
M collects clippings from the French press in his notebook (cf #M573).
M writes E to have Dupont reply to the chauvinistic manifesto sent out by the Marseilles section of the IWMA. (This is the last letter in the M-E correspondence before E moves to London.)
E’s article “How to fight the Prussians” is pubd in PMG, as part of the series #E531; seven other articles in this series are pubd this month.
GC session: M reports on the German arrest of the Eisenacher party leaders and on police suppression of other antiwar activities in Germany.
GC session: M reports on government repression of the workers’ movement in Germany and the advance of reaction in France.
In a discussion of English foreign policy, M attacks the English adherence to the 1856 Treaty of Paris, which limits England’s naval power and strengthens Russia.
For most IWMA work, see <— :50.
GC sessions: M attends all five—Sep 6, 9, 13, 20, 27.
During this period, esp Sep AB, because of the absence of other corr secretaries in France, M often works as late as 3 a.m. busy with IWMA work.
At GC: M criticizes the NY activity of Hume, the GC-appointed representative; the GC is to inquire into this.
M seconds the nomination of the Russian Lopatin as GC member.
M proposes E (who has moved to London—see —► :53) as GC member.
M takes part in further discussion of how to improve Hume’s work in America.

header: 52.  The Second Address on the War.
text: M works on drafting the Second Address on the war (#M813), using E’s material on Alsace-Lorraine.

header: 52.  The Second Address on the War.
text: At the GC session, after discussion (see <- :50) M is named to a commission to draft an address to the German workers.

header: 52.  The Second Address on the War.
text: M receives a letter from the Paris comm of the IWMA urgently requesting a new GC manifesto on the war situation; M replies with a discussion of what the French might do.

header: 52.  The Second Address on the War.
text: M writes E of his plan to write a Second Address on the war, esp directed against German annexationism, and asks E for comments on the military side of the question, for inclusion.

header: 52.  The Second Address on the War.
text: A special GC session adopts M’s Second Address (#M813); pubd as a leaflet Sep 11-13.

header: 52.  The Second Address on the War.
text: M sends the text of the Second Address on the war to correspondents in various countries.

header: 52.  The Second Address on the War.
text: M translates the Second Address into German, for publ in the IWMA German press.

header: 52.  The Second Address on the War.
text: At the GC session, M proposes that the First and Second Addresses (#M318 plus 813) be pubd together in a single pamphlet (this is done Sep D). At this point the IWMA, shortly to become world-famous as a mighty red octopus swallowing up the world, has only £5 in its treasury.

header: 52.  The Second Address on the War.
text: M’s German trans of the Second Address (#M813) is pubd in Volksstaat.

Having finally settled all affairs connected with the termination of his work in the firm of Ermen & Engels, E moves from Manchester to London, into M’s neighborhood, at 122 Regent’s Park Road, N.W. (KMC dates the move Sep c.18).
V. A. Sleptsov (in St. Petersburg) invites M to write on polit eco for the Russian journal Znaniye, appearing Oct 1, which he edits (KMC dating: c.Sep; MEW dates receipt Oct).
GC sessions: M attends all four—Oct 4,11,18, 25. E attends from Oct 11 on.
At GC: E is elected as GC member.
M discusses the campaign for recognition of the French republic by the English government, Gladstone’s evasions, and “the Prussianism of the [English] middle class and their government.”
At GC: E attends for the first time.
M reports on continued antiwar meetings and government arrests in Germany, and on the Lyons rising of Sep 4 and the farcical Bakunin putsch of Sep 28, which the Rouen IWMA has protested.
At GC: M reports on news from Serraillier (in Paris).
M criticizes the Belgian section’s suppression of the Second Address r*M813) by failing to publish it in its press.
At GC: M reports on Brussels (which has now partially pubd the Second Address), on Bordeaux (Lafargue’s work), on NY, and on Schweitzer’s slandering of the IWMA.
M proposes P. Robin (a Bakunin follower) as GC member; he supports E for financial secy, but E declines the job.
M proposes that GC sessions discussing internal matters be closed to non* members of the IWMA.
M continues his correspondence with Prof. Beesly [<-:49] with a letter about Bakunin’s Sep 28 putsch in Lyons and his farcical “abolition of the state.”
E’s Peasant war in Germany (#E579) is pubd as a brochure by the VoiJcsstaat press, with a new preface (#E580) l«- :29).
In his PMG series of “Notes on the war” (#E531), E pubs 11 articles.

E begins studying the work of the German historian G. H. Pertz, Das Leben des Feldmarschalls Grafen Neithardt von Gneisenau, for his series “Notes on the war” (#E531). He will use this material in the article “Prussian franc-tireurs” on guerrilla warfare, pubd Dec 9.
GC sessions: M&E attend Nov 1, 8, 15, 29; both absent Nov 22.

At GC: M reports on letters from the US, esp Bolte’s (Oct 12) on the American movement, and reads part of an address on the war adopted by a joint meeting of the French and German branches in America. He also reports on Lafargue’s letter (Oct 28) about the movement in Bordeaux.
For the US, M opposes the formation of a CC over the “Yankee element” (native-born) as long as the IWMA there is mainly French and German.
At GC: M&E attend, but no participation is recorded.
At GC: M reports on NY agitation in favor of the French republic (letter from Sorge, Oct 30).
M points to Russia’s repudiation of limitations in the 1856 Treaty of Paris and suggests a GC discussion on the treaty [«- :50].
E reports on the movement in Vienna.
At GC: M reports on Germany: more government persecution of the imprisoned SDWP leaders and more antiwar demonstrations in the country.
M proposes Dupont as IWMA representative in Manchester, for better ties with the local Trades Council.

In connection with the charge of treason against the imprisoned SDWP leaders in Germany, M at Bracke’s request makes a notarized deposition at the London Lord Mayor’s office that the SDWP never requested to be a branch or section of the IWMA though many members were admitted as individuals—this for use by defense counsel in the German court trial.
For M’s report on Germany at GC, see «— :59.
E pubs 11 articles in the PMG series “Notes on the war” (#E531), incl “The fighting in France” (pubd Nov 11) denouncing the barbarous conduct of the Prussian army against the French irregulars.
GC sessions: M&E attend all three sessions—Dec 6,13,20.
M sends Sorge (in the US) various GC publications.
At GC: M&E move to ignore Collet’s request that the GC help to get aid to Garibaldi from liberals “by putting socialism in the background.”
M&E propose a checkup on GC members’ recent attendance.
At GC: M reports the founding of a new section at the Hague.
M takes part in the discussion of how to help strikers of the Elastic Web-Weavers Union.
M&E propose keeping a record of GC members’ absence without cause.
At GC: M reports on the formation of a CC for US sections (letter from Bolte, Dec 6).
E is assigned to write the GC address to the sixth congress of the Belgian federation (Dec 25-26); he sends it (#E864) on Dec 23 (pubd Jan 1).
The GC attendance record for the four months Sep-Dec shows that, save Eccarius, M&E have the best record (one absence).
M cautions against pressing Belgian and other sections for dues payments at this time.
On M’s proposal, a comm (incl M&E) is set up to take any necessary action on the case of the imprisoned German party leaders, before the next meeting on Jan 3.
M asks IWMA members in Netherlands and Flanders to send the GC local IWMA papers (notice pubd Dec 18 in L’Internationale).
M hears from Lopatin (in St. Petersburg) who i.a. reports on the seizure of a Russian paper for an article quoting from Capital, and on the state of the publ of the Russian edn of Capital.

Writing to Kugelmann, M discusses the consequences of the German war victory: self-exposure of the German bourgeois republicans and “our professors”; the turning of English public opinion against Germany. But the war “has given the French proletariat practice in arms, and that is the best guarantee of the future.”

M and his family make the acquaintance of the Russian revolutionary Elizaveta L. Tomanovskaya (pseud.: Dmitriyeva), who comes to London on behalf of the IWMA Russian section in Geneva to discuss the work of the section. M also discusses with her questions about the development of the Russian village community. (She will become friendly with the family, and see M frequently, until Mar M, 1871, when she will become one of the leading women militants in the Paris Commune.)

Sending money collected in England for the families of the imprisoned German party leaders, E writes to Mrs. Natalie Liebknecht with praise for the victims—Bebel, Liebknecht, Hepner— who have just been arrested (Dec 17) in Leipzig for their antiwar activities.
E pubs 10 articles in the PMG series “Notes on the war” (#E531).
M reads Chernyshevsky’s writings on common property in land in Russia.
Marx renews his BM library card [not in Chronicle; from Higgins 2017, n42)

M obtains confidential info on the difficulties of the German army in France (through J. Miquel) and sends it (via E) to Lafargue (in Bordeaux) since it may be useful for organizing popular resistance to the German invasion.

GC session: M discusses the Dec 30 statement issued by a group of Comtists plus some GC members, on the French situation, mostly favorably; he remarks that Beesly and his Comtist (Positivist) friends are the only (bourgeois) elements who support the campaign for recognition of the French republic; but he criticizes the concluding call for England to declare war on Prussia in aid of France.
GC session: M proposes to query the IWMA status of the German Swiss paper Felleisen which is supporting the annexation of Alsace-Lorraine; i.e., he implies a threat of expulsion.
M gives a talk on Jules Favre’s political record, to counteract Odger’s support of Favre at mass meetings on Jan 6, 10.

Writing to Meyer (in the US), M reports on the English workers’ movement for recognition of the French republic—which, however, unfortunately “thinks it can conduct a revolutionary war without a revolution.”

GC session: E proposes that the GC discuss the attitude of the English workers on the present phase of the war. M&E discuss the advisability of publishing the material in M's Jan 17 talk on Favre (see above).

E gives a long talk (cf #E545) initiating GC discussion of the topic raised Jan 24, on IWMA policy in the present phase of the war situation: he favors the campaign to defend the French republic in England (a campaign for recognition) but opposes the drive by the Comtist group to bring about an English declaration of war against Prussia; he discusses English foreign policy in this period. Boon states his disagreement with E’s flat opposition to military intervention by England, for it may be feasible for the workers to “compel the government to make war for liberty abroad.” While debate is adjourned, E presents some tentative resolutions (which are pubd Feb 4).
GC sessions: M&E attend all four—Jan 3, 17, 24, 31. See <- :2 for some business.
E’s GC address to the Belgian sections (#E864) [<- 70:62] is pubd in Brussels.
At GC: M&E participate in a discussion on Hales’s expulsion from his union.
They propose an appeal for financial aid to the families of the imprisoned German socialist leaders, Bebel et al.
E is appointed corr secy for Belgium.
E reports on the slack state of the Spanish IWMA (letter from F. Mora, Dec 14).
At GC: M reports sending money for the German political prisoners.
Eccarius informs M that the Eastern Post is willing to publish IWMA material (GC reports, etc.).
Writing to Meyer (in the US), M makes proposals for the activity of the CC of the American sections, and reports on the IWMA’s situation in various countries.
Writing to Harney, M deplores the fact that most of the TU leaders in the GC look on it “only as a means of furthering their own petty personal aims,” esp to get into Parliament.
At GC: M discusses the formation in the American IWMA of a CC of foreign-language sections.
Again urging aid to the German prisoners, M reports a letter (Jan 18) from Mrs. Natalie Liebknecht on prison conditions.
At GC: M reports on the paper RevoJuciön Social in Palma, and criticizes its Bakuninist leaning; the GC decides to send it its documents on Bakunin’s Alliance.
E is appointed temporary corr secy for Spain.
M asks Harney (in the US) to get him some documents on the disposal of public lands in the US, from Washington, for Vol. 2. (Harney will reply in Feb that these documents are out of print.)
M sends £5 in the name of the GC to the wives of Bebel and Liebknecht, and warns against printing articles by Nechayev in Volksstaat.
M sends a communication to the liberal Daily News (#M330) on Bismarck's police-state regime in Germany and the persecution of the German socialists; pubd Jan 19.
M&E are active in organizing the GC’s financial aid to the families of the imprisoned German socialists (see «- :3).
Reinhardt (from Paris) visits M; M has him send money to the families of Bebel and Liebknecht. (In the ensuing months M meets with Reinhardt a number of times.)

M receives a letter from E. Tomanovskaya (Dmitriyeva) with data on czarist agricultural policies, also a copy of Narodnoye Delo (pubd by the Russian section of Geneva) with an article on agrarian reform and common property in land in Russia.
Writing to Meyer (in the US), M reports on his progress in studying Russian and praises the works of Chernyshevsky and Flerovsky.
E pubs seven articles in the PMG series “Notes on the war” (#E531).
M suffers severely from a chronic cough.

In long letters to Lafargue and Kugelmann, M gives a condemnatory analysis of the French “Government of National Defense” which is preparing to capitulate to the Prussians instead of carrying on a revolutionary war against them.
GC session: Debate continues [4- :2J on E’s statement about war policy; some GC members, incl Eccarius, frankly come out in favor of war, as against E. (M&E do not take the floor at this session.)
M hears from Lafargue (letter of Feb 9) on the results of the elections to the French National Assembly.
GC session: M reports on Serraillier’s speech in Paris.
Debate resumes on war policy: M gives a long talk in support of E’s position.
M is visited by Serraillier (returned from Paris today), who reports on the situation in France.
GC session: M states that the account of his Feb 14 talk at the GC given in the Minutes and in the Eastern Post is so error-filled as to be impossible to correct; he gives some examples.

GC session: Further debate on war policy, with M&E participating, takes place. E reports on developments in France. Serraillier (who has been in France since last Sep 7) gives a long report on his experiences. M comments on Odger’s support to Favre and the French government.
GC sessions: M&E attend all four—Feb 7, 14, 21, 28. See :9 for some business.
On behalf of the GC, E writes a communication “To the Spanish Federal Council” (#E866) in reply to the council’s letter of Dec 14.
At GC: M reports on developments in Vienna and in Prussia.
At GC: Near the conclusion of the GC discussion on war policy, E suggests another such discussion on another topic: the program of the bourgeois-liberal Land Tenure Reform Assoc.
At the request of Morley, editor of the Fortnightly Rev, M invites Johann Jacoby to write an article on German affairs for the magazine. (Jacoby declines, Feb 12.)
M has a new grandson: a third child is born to daughter, Laura Lafargue [—► :38).
E pubs three articles in the PMG series “Notes on the war” (#E531).

header: 14.   France and the War: On the Eve.
text: GC session: M reports on France, incl Tolain’s move to the right.

header: 14.   France and the War: On the Eve.
text: On war policy: M returns to the question of the 1856 Treaty of Paris [4- :2), discusses British naval and foreign policy, and opines that pacifism acts “always in favor of the greatest military power.”

header: 14.   France and the War: On the Eve.
text: GC session: M tells of press reports that the French IWMA has expelled all Germans except M, Liebknecht, and Jacoby; the GC will write for info. M reports on other canards about the IWMA in the Paris press.

header: 14.   France and the War: On the Eve.
text: The adjourned debate on war policy [4— :9] resumes, with M discussing the London Black Sea Conference just taking place (}an to Mar). E gives a summing-up talk. The only proposition acted on is one urging England to renounce the Treaty of Paris.
Revolution breaks out in Paris, after a confrontation on the butte Montmartre; the CC of the National Guard is installed in City Hall. (The news reaches England on Mar 19.)

M immediately begins to follow the French and English press on the events in Paris, filling notebooks with excerpts and notes from the papers. One set of notebooks covers newspapers of Mar 18 to Apr 30 (#M572) [-* :20).

GC session: Serraillier reports that letters make clear that the so-called Montmartre affair of Mar 18 was not a mere mob action. E gives a long “description of the state of things in Paris” based on letters and the press; Serraillier supplements.
M sends letters to the Times and to German papers (signed by M&E, drafted by E) denouncing the forged “Marx” letter being spread from Paris to the European press (#ME181); pubd Mar 22 in the Times.
Serraillier reports that the Paris-Joumal has pubd a forged “Marx” letter.
M presents a statement denouncing the press reports about anti-German expulsions in the Paris IWMA (#M859); pubd Mar 23 et seq.
M proposes a GC delegation go to tomorrow's “republican meeting” (founding of the Central Republican Assoc) to have the audience express sympathy with the “Paris movement.”
M sends a communication to Volksstaat (#M920) denouncing the forged letter and citing the Mar 21 statement (#M859); pubd Mar 29.
H. Scheu (in Vienna) writes M urgently requesting reliable info on the Paris events and the IWMA's position.
M has a talk with Serraillier before the latter returns to Paris.
GC session: M proposes that the GC issue an address to the people of Paris; M is assigned to write it. (This will be #M143.)
M announces that Serraillier has gone back to Paris.
Jung reports to M the content of a brief letter he has just received from E. Tomanovskaya (Dmitriyeva) from Paris.
Leo Frankel, the Commune's commissioner for labor and commerce, writes to M asking his views on what social measures the Commune should take [—► :20).
In response to a request from P. Coenen of De Werker (Antwerp), M sends this paper a denunciation of the forged “Marx” letter (#M922); pubd Apr 8.
M sees reports from Serraillier on the situation in Paris: these are his letters to his wife of Mar 29, 30.
M begins sending out letters to various IWMA sections urging aid to the Commune—"several hundred” such letters by May.
GC sessions: M&E attend all four—Mar 7, 14, 21, 28. See «— :15 for most of the business.

At GC: M reports on the request of the NY comm to be considered the CC for the whole US; M favors only a CC of the foreign sections (to prevent domination of native branches by foreign-language sections) [«- :3].
E reports on the demise of the Palma paper [«- :3].
At GC: M reports on the IWMA in NY and its new Irish section; and on the German elections: Bebel is the only socialist elected to the first Reichstag of the new German Empire.
M&E oppose calling a London Conference at present because of IWMA disorganization on the Continent.
M supports making the next GC debate treat the Irish question.
At GC: M reports on the imprisoned German socialists, Bebel et al.
At GC: M reports on government repression of the IWMA in Prussia and Vienna.

In a discussion of the new English republican movement, E argues that IWMA people in it should ensure its working-class character if it is not to become a mere clique; M says a serious republican movement must have a social program; the present “wirepullers” have no such aim.
The GC attendance record for Jan-Mar shows that M&E and two others have a perfect record.
Coenen, editor of De Werker (Antwerp), writes M asking IWMA support for striking cigar workers.
M sends Mrs. Natalie Liebknecht some info of use to the defense of the imprisoned socialists.
Writing to two IWMA members in Solingen, K. Klein and F. Moll, E praises the “model conduct” of the German workers’ movement in the war period.
The German government releases Bebel, Liebknecht, and Hepner [«- 70:50) pending their trial [-♦ 72:16).
Charles van Rodenback writes M from the Hague asking for British support to his paper De Vrijheid.
E pubs his last article on the war in the PMG series (#E531; see #E42).

M continues to send a stream of letters out to IWMA sections for aid to the Commune [«-:15). He maintains some communication with Commune leaders in Paris through a “German merchant” (prob N. Eilau) who travels between Paris and London all year round, often with oral messages rather than written; and thus provides some info to his Commune contacts (supplied to M by J. Miquel) on questions such as how to sell certain securities on the London Exchange (to finance the government), or the secret Bismarck-Favre agreement [—► :23).
M gets frequent visits from Fox Bourne, editor of the London Examiner, to discuss the Paris events; and these conversations positively affect the paper’s treatment of the Commune.

M continues [«- :15] to fill notebooks with excerpts and notes from the press on the Paris events. Besides a notebook covering Mar 18 to Apr 30 (#M572), M fills a notebook (#M573) with French press excerpts covering Apr 1 to May 23.
M receives FrankeFs letter of Mar 30. (His reply is not extant.)
M writes a letter to the Times refuting the Paris press slanders about IWMA fomenting the Commune (#M916); pubd Apr 4, 6.
GC session: E tells the GC that in M’s opinion, an address on the Commune would now be “out of place,” because of the Apr 3 defeat of the Commune forces.
Writing to Liebknecht, M briefly discusses the main mistake being made by the Commune leadership, failure to take the revolutionary offensive against Versailles.

Writing to Kugelmann, M again discusses the mistakes of the Commune, along with enthusiasm over its revolutionary heroism. He underlines the political lesson that in a revolution it is necessary to smash the bureaucratic-military machinery of the state.

In another letter to Kugelmann, M argues that if the Paris workers had not fought in this situation, their demoralization would be a greater misfortune than the consequences of defeat; and he stresses that with the Commune the proletarian struggle “has entered upon a new phase.”

GC session: M reports that Serraillier has been elected to the Paris Commune. As the question of writing an address is raised again, M opines that an address on “the general tendency of the struggle” is possible, perhaps preceded by issuance of a general resolution.
In response to the Paris IWMA’s expulsion of Tolain (who has sided with Versailles) M&E say it should be confirmed by the GC if the facts are verified.
GC session: M gives a long talk on the Commune, along the lines of the address he is preparing; he promises the draft for the next meeting.
Leo Frankel [«- :15] sends M an inquiry about the Commune’s selling French securities on the London Exchange.
Tolain’s expulsion in Paris having been verified, E offers a resolution confirming the expulsion (#E678); pubd Apr 29.
M reports the election of both Serraillier and Dupont to the Commune and the right-wing attack on them.

M replies to Frankel’s inquiry, also writes about the attacks on Serraillier in Paris, the coming GC address on the Commune, and the utilization of M’s emissary (the “German merchant”) for messages [-* :23].
Schily (in Paris) writes M that if he wants to do research on French agriculture he can now work in the Paris libraries since the Commune is in control. (Schily is not joking.)
M begins writing the first draft of his address on “The civil war in France” (#M144) [-* :23].
M gets reports on the situation in Paris from Serraillier’s letters to his wife of Apr 12, 15.
GC sessions: M&E attend Apr 4,18, 25; E attends also Apr 11, but M is absent (for the first time since last Nov 22).
For most of the GC’s business, see <-:20.
At GC: E reports on the lockout of the Antwerp cigarmakers, who need help (letter of Coenen to M, Mar 29); E proposes measures.
E reports on the release of Bebel, Liebknecht, et al, from their German prison, awaiting trial (letter of Liebknecht to M, Apr 1).

E sends a communication (#E569) to Volksstaat calling for German support to the Antwerp strikers; in a letter to Coenen, he reports on GC steps to support the strike, and asks Coenen to send De Werker regularly.
At GC: E reports on events in Spain, and on the current press canard that M had once been Bismarck’s private secy.
At GC: E reports on Madrid’s appeal for strike aid, and on pro-Commune mass meetings in several German cities.
M reports that the Prussian police had been prepared to arrest him if he came to Germany (info supplied by Miquel, via Kugelmann’s letter of Apr 15).
E sends Eccarius info on the textile strike in Barcelona, urging GC help among the Manchester workers.
At GC: E reports on economic conditions in Spain.
E studies the letters and press reports received from Spain on the Barcelona strike.
M communicates Sorge’s report of Apr 2 on the IWMA sections in NYC.
Volksstaat reprints E’s 1868 review of Capital (#E689).
Writing to Liebknecht, M asks that Bebel send regularly the stenographic reports of Reichstag proceedings; he gives a biting portrait of Karl Blind in his present German-chauvinist phase.

In letters to Liebknecht and Kugelmann, M reports that the Commune has pubd official documents confirming that Karl Vogt had been paid from the secret funds of the Bonaparte regime in 1859—just as had been charged at that time. (Liebknecht pubs this info in Volksstaat on Apr 15.)

M advises Liebknecht that he and E will see about a new preface to the Manifesto, but cautions against reprinting from the NRZ-Revue (e.g., #M148) without new prefaces. He urges Liebknecht to reprint excerpts from Capital, esp on primitive accumulation.
Liebknecht proposes to M writing a new preface for a republ of the Com Manifesto.
For M’s letters in aid of the Commune and for his notebooks of press excerpts, see «— :20.
M&E reject a proposal by E. Oswald and J. K.  Kern to take part in a discussion of how to mediate between Paris and Versailles.
Tomanovskaya’s letter of Apr 24 from Paris arrives in Jung’s hands and is shown to M.
Reinhardt writes M from Paris.
M is ill and cannot attend GC meetings.

GC session: E explains, in M's absence, that M has not yet finished the address on the Commune. Eccarius proposes to suspend the rule requiring the signing of all GC names to official documents in the case of this address; E and others object.
GC session: E explains that M is seriously ill, but the address on the Commune will be ready in four days, for action by the Sub-Comm. E gives a report on the events in Paris.
M works on the second draft of the address on the civil war in France (#M145).
M again meets with the “German merchant” [<— :20] who is his go-between with the Commune, and gets info on the situation in Paris (KMC dating: May c.9-13).
Mrs. M writes a moving letter to Kugelmann on M’s and the family’s suffering over the plight of Paris; she fears Paris is on the eve of a massacre.
M sends a letter, via his emissary, to Leo Frankel and L. E. Varlin of the Commune, with info and advice.
GC session: E reports that M is still ill, the address still unfinished.

GC session: M attends, and says he hopes to have the address by the next meeting; he discusses the meaning of the Commune at this point when it appears to be succumbing. M&E take part in a discussion of the looming refugee problem and the future persecution of the IWMA and the Communards.
GC session: M presents his draft of the address “The civil war in France” (#M143); it is adopted unanim without further discussion.
M meets with the Russian Peter Lavrov, who has come from Paris on behalf of the Commune to establish direct relations with the GC.
M begins drafting the final version of the address “The civil war in France” (#M143).
GC sessions: E attends all five—May 2, 9, 16, 23, 30; M is absent May 2, 9, 16. For most of its business, see «-:23.
At GC: E reports on strikes in Spain and Belgium, and on a letter from New Zealand.
E supports sending a GC representative to an Owen centenary meeting, with a glowing tribute to Owen; he defends Owen’s contribution against Mottershead.
At GC: M is provisionally named corr secy for Holland.
E participates in discussing nominees for gen secy, to replace Eccarius, who has resigned.
M sends Liebknecht a summary of the evidence on Karl Vogt’s subsidization by the Bonaparte regime [<- :22] and replies to Vogt’s denial.
E writes an article for Volksstaat on the Vogt expos6 (#E571) and sends it to Liebknecht; pubd May 10. E also asks the German movement to help the Antwerp and Brussels strikers.
Danielson writes M asking him what changes he wants to make in the Russian trans of Capital.
Daughters Jenny and Eleanor arrive at the Lafargues’ (in Bordeaux) for a month-long visit [-► :32].

M&E begin the task, for the rest of the year and more, of organizing relief work for the Communard refugees and their families who have fled to London (and elsewhere). This involves a great deal of activity, noted below only partially. Until Sep, M will be an active member of the GC’s refugee-aid comm, helping to get funds, provide jobs, and obtain passports and other papers for Communards still hiding in France.
GC sessions: M&E attend all four—June 6,13, 20, 27.
