Hepner asks M for notes on his Sep 8 speech in Amsterdam (#M835) about the use of force, for use in Volksstaat, since quoting the text pubd in La Liberty of Sep 15 would subject Volksstaat to prosecution [—► :56].
M’s GC Report to the Congress (#M745) is pubd in French in La Liberty.
M&E begin preparing for publ the congress resolutions and documents (#ME132) [-► :56). For M’s miscellaneous notes, see #M518.
The London French periodical La Föderation carries a series of articles by V6sinier attacking “M. Karl Marx.” (Although KMC dating is Sep, it cites the issues of the paper for Aug 24 to Sep 14.)
Hales carries on a campaign against M in the British Federation and various English branches, utilizing M’s statement at the congress [«- :49] that English TU leaders have sold out.
E sends Sorge texts of the Hague decisions and also the address list of organizations of the IWMA.
Terzaghi (in Turin) writes M asking for articles for L’Emancipazione del Proletario.
In letters to IWMA members in various countries, M&E explain the significance of the Hague decision on independent working-class political action.

E proposes, to the British Federal Council and a number of English TUs, immediate action against the export of English strikebreakers to Lisbon, in view of info received from the Portuguese Federation on the strikes in Lisbon [—*• :55j.
The first part (first five fascicules) of the French edn is pubd. On the first day 234 copies are sold.

M sends this first part to a number of friends and correspondents, incl. Allsop, Beesly, Collet, Danielson, Dietzgen, Imandt, Keller, La Cécilia, Mongin (or Mougin), Rochat, Thieblin, Urquhart, Vaillant, van der Willigen
interaction_with: Allsop_Thomas,Beesly_Edward Spencer,Collet_Collet Dobson,Danielson_Nikolai,Dietzgen_Joseph,Imandt_Peter,Keller_Ernst Friedrich,La Cécilia,Mongin,Rochat_C.,Urquhart_David,Vaillant_Edouard,Willigen_Pieter van der,Thieblen_N. L.

text: E is active in the affairs of the British Federal Council and the Manchester section in fighting against the reformist leadership policies, which are opposed to the Hague Congress decisions, esp on political action.
E meets with McDonnell and De Morgan to discuss the state of the Irish section.
E sends a report on the Hague Congress to the NY Section 6, which had mandated him.

Sorge, now GC secy in NYC, writes M asking him to send advice, explanations, etc. (This inaugurates a long period of correspondence between M&E and Sorge, to whom they supply info on European developments, ideas, and other aid.)
E sends a communication (#E817) to the British Federal Council calling its attention again [«- :53] to the need for aid to the Lisbon strikers.
E writes a report to the GC (in NYC) on the IWMA in Spain (#E671) [—* :60].
E receives from Cuno a copy of the Hague Congress minutes and a letter.
In response to Bignami's request [«— :39J, E writes an article “On authority” (#E538) against the basic theory of anarchism, and sends it off. (But see —► :61.)
M’s GC Report to the Hague Congress (#M745) [«-:52) is pubd in England, Belgium, Spain, etc.
E writes an article for Bignami’s La Plebe on the Hague Congress (#E381); pubd Oct 5.

Volksstaat pubs a somewhat bowdlerized version [cf «— :52] of M’s Sep 8 speech in Amsterdam (#M835) about the use of force in revolution (bowdlerized from the report in La Libertö) in order to avoid prosecution in Germany.
E writes another article for La Plebe, “Once again on the Hague Congress” (Letters from London, II), against the Bakuninists (#E449); pubd Oct 8.
Volksstaat pubs the second installment of E’s article on the Hague Congress (#E555) [*-:52).
In a letter to Voiksstaat (#M927), M corrects some errors in its Oct 19 report of the congress, esp on the case of Schwitzgu6bel; pubd Oct 26.
M&E are finished [«- :52] with preparation of the Hague Congress resolutions and documents for publ (#ME132).
E writes an article attacking the conduct of the Alliance factionalists at the Hague Congress and their use of “imperative mandates” (#E369); pubd in Spain, Oct 13.
These resolutions and documents (#ME132) are pubd as a pamphlet in a French edn [-♦ :67J.
E writes Part III of his essay on “The housing question” (#E358) [<-:33;-»:67].
Bignami writes M asking for authorization to issue an Italian trans. (The putative translator is apparently La Cécilia, but this plan is going to fall through.)

La Emancipación pubs a Spanish version of M's preface to the first German edn and of M's letter to Lachâtre (#M131) in the French edn, under the title "Marx's Capital", and also carries news of the publ of the next serial fascicule of the French edn.
M writes to Anna V. Korvin-Krukovskaya about the French trans of Capital she was supposed to have made.  (This will turn out to be a false report.)
M's daughter Jenny is married to Charles Longuet.
E informs Sorge (NY GC) of the formation of new Italian sections in Lodi and Aquila, sends him contact addresses for Spain, Italy, and Portugal, and encloses his Oct 31 report on Spain (#E671).
E receives the request from the Manchester Foreign Section to represent it in the British Federal Council [«- :55).
E writes to the new Lodi and Aquila sections welcoming them into the IWMA. His letter to Lodi (#E813) is pubd in La Plebe on Nov 17.

In a letter to Sorge, E reports on the Blanquist pamphlet Internationale et revolution, on the Spanish IWMA, on the British Federal Council, etc. For M and himself, he urges the GC to declare that the Bakuninist Jura Federation, by the resolutions of its St. Imier congress, has excluded itself from the IWMA.
La Emancipaciön pubs the first Spanish trans of the Com Manifesto, translated by J. Mesa with some help from E, preceded by the 1872 preface (#ME36); pubd in six installs, Nov 2 to Dec 7.
Bignami writes E acknowledging receipt of E’s article “On authority*' (#E538) [«- :56]. (But Bignami is going to lose this ms when he gets jailed Dec AB [see —► 73:19).)
Bignami writes E again asking for articles for his planned AJmanacco Repubblicano [4- :39); he asks for articles from M too [—* :67].
E writes an article on the Nov 3 Hyde Park demonstration organized by the Irish IWMA members for the release of the Fenian prisoners (#E450); pubd in La Plebe as “Letters from London, III,’* Nov 17.
M&E criticize Volksstaat for taking too accommodating an attitude toward the Lassalleans (source: KMC, referring to letters to E from Liebknecht).
M asks Danielson (in St. Petersburg) to send a reliable address for further correspondence.
M stays with the newly wed Longuets [see <- :59] in Oxford, in part to go over the French trans of Capital with Longuet.
Liebers (in The Hague) sends M a report on the congress of the Dutch sections, which has rejected support to the Bakuninists.
E sends Sorge a letter reporting on the situation of the IWMA in Holland, Spain, France, and England.

E sends Sorge the English version of the Hague Congress resolution (#ME132), in the International Herald, and reports on Bignami’s arrest in Italy (Dec AB), following the Nov 21 confiscation of La Plebe for publishing a GC address.
Danielson (in St. Petersburg) informs M that Lyubavin [<— :42) is willing to have the Nechayev letter made public.
The GC (in NYC) names M as the curator of the archives of the old GC, incl the GC Minutes.

A split in the British Federal Council develops as a wing, led by Hales, rejects the decisions of the Hague Congress, esp on independent political action (for these labor leaders are moving to get into bourgeois reform politics).
A letter by Hales, virulently attacking the previous GC and M (dated Nov 6), is pubd in the organ of the Bakuninist Jura Federation.
On M’s advice, Riley makes his International Herald independent of the British Federal Council, as of this date. M&E plan to do a weekly supplement for the paper on international affaire.
The Hales group pubs a secessionist circular rejecting the Hague Congress. The Manchester Foreign Section urges M&E to write a reply (esp in a letter by Wegmann to E, Dec 16).
M&E write a reply (#ME177) to Hales’s attack of Nov 6 (see Dec 1, above); pubd in International Herald, Dec 21.
E writes a circular (#E465) for the Manchester Foreign Section in reply to the Hales group's secessionist circular of Dec 10; it is pubd Dec 23, signed by three members of the section.

M writes an address to the membership (#M6) on behalf of the loyal Federal Council, explaining the politics and splitting tactics of the Hales group and its connection with the Bakuninist operation; pubd as a flysheet, Dec 31.
In response to Bignami’s request [«- :61] M works on a polemical article against anarchist antipolitics (#M404) H 73:9].

E writes an article for La Plebe, as a fourth “Letter from London” (#E451), on continued demonstrations in Hyde Park, policemen’s strikes in England, and a survey of the European movement after the Hague Congress; pubd Dec 14.
The Resolutions of the Hague Congress (#ME132) are pubd in English in the International Herald.
Part II of E’s “The housing question” (#E358) is pubd in VoJJcsstaat, in four installs.

M writes Danielson on several matters, incl the Hague Congress and the role of the Lyubavin letter. Having received news of Lopatin's attempted flight from exile (in Danielson's letter of Dec 3), M indicates that he has a plan to help Lopatin escape. M also asks for Russian reviews of Capital, and for data on Chernyshevsky, on whose behalf he wants to "arouse sympathy in the West"; also for N. I. Ziber's book on Ricardo's theory. M says he will study the forms of Russian landed property for Vol. 2 of Capital.
M's two sons-in-law, Longuet and Lafargue, stay at M's house in London.
Marx renews his BM Library card (not in Chronicle; from Higgins 2017, n42)

E organizes an aid fund for the families of the editors of La Plebe arrested in Lodi; in this connection he corresponds with IWMA people in Spain and Austria, the German party Exec, the NY GC; and he forwards money from England.
M reads the stenographic report of Nechayev’s trial in Pravi-telstvennii Vestnik in anticipation of his and E’s work on the brochure (#ME6) directed against the Bakuninist Alliance [—* :23).
E continues in correspondence with Mesa (Spain), sends him GC documents, and gives financial aid to La Emancipaciön.

E writes a series of reports on the activities of the IWMA on the Continent, for publ in the International Herald (#E675); the first of these is pubd Jan 11 [—*• :14). Perhaps in connection with these reports, cf E’s notes #E529.
M writes a letter to the Times (#M918) against a fabrication in the press about M and the IWMA; pubd Jan 3.
Sorge, for the NY GC, sends E credentials as plenipotentiary representative of the IWMA for Italy, subject to final decision by the GC. (The credentials are pubd in La Plebe, May 10.)

The imbroglio around the British Federation of the IWMA [«— :66] continues. (MEW dates it Jan to May.) E in particular is involved in helping members of the British Federal Council fight the Hales group.
E sends Sorge (NY GC) an account of the split in the British Federal Council, with documents, etc.
The International Herald pubs Hales’s reply to M&E’s letter of Dec 21 (#ME177).
The International Herald pubs a rejoinder to Hales by Lessner, written after discussion with M&E.
E writes to the British Federal Council requesting help for the striking clockmakers of Geneva; it is read at the Council on Jan 23.
At the London congress of the secessionist (Hales’s) British Federation, Jung gives a long speech against M.
M writes a reply (#M110) to a new circular by the Hales group of secessionists, esp discussing the decisions of the Hague Congress; pubd in the International Herald, jan 25.
E receives news of Bebel’s victory in the supplementary Reichstag election, even though he is under fortress imprisonment; also news of the increase in Volksstaat subscriptions.
M sends Bignami his article on “Indifference to politics” (#M404) [«- 72:67], to be pubd in Almanacco Repubblicano —► :58].
M negotiates with Meissner for publ of a collected edn of his writings. (E mentions this to Liebknecht, Feb 12.)
Volksstaat ends the publ of Part II of E’s “The housing question” (#E358) [<- 72:67]. During Jan, E writes Part III H :14].
For #E675, see <- :6, Jan to Feb M.
Bolte (in NY) asks M&E to write articles for the NY Arbeiter-Ztg and for a projected English-language paper [-> :11 ].
E writes an article, “The ‘crisis’ in Prussia” (#E195), on revolutionary possibilities in Germany and the societal incompetence of the bourgeoisie; pubd in Volksstaat, Jan 15.
M finishes the Afterword to the second German edn (#M130), and sends it to Meissner.
E sends a memorandum (#E480) to Sorge, for the GC, with a number of informational items and queries on the international movement.

M writes Bolte (in NY) explaining why it was a mistake to suspend the Jura Bakuninists instead of merely recognizing their exclusion [«— 72:60]; he also reports on the congress of the secessionist British Federation [«- :7]; and he agrees to write for the papers Bolte has proposed [<— :9].
M&E help Lessner and Vickery write a rejoinder to the report of the Jan 26 congress of the secessionist British Federation.

Writing to Liebknecht, E sharply challenges signs that Volksstaat, Liebknecht, and some other party leaders wish to soft-pedal any opposition to Lassallean influence and even to Bakuninism. (KMC refers E’s letters to Feb-Mar. MEW Daten refers to letters to Liebknecht and Hepner over the period Feb to June.)

In a letter to Mesa (not extant), E discusses the nature of the revolution going on in Spain and proletarian policy in it, and stresses the task of forming an independent political party of the working class (source: MEW Daten).
The last three articles in E’s series on IWMA activities (#E675) [«- :6] are pubd in International Herald.
Volksstaat pubs Part III of E’s “The housing question” (#E358) [«- :9] in four installs.
Re M’s collected writings, see <— :9.
At De Morgan’s request, E translates a letter from Garibaldi to De Morgan on the republicans’ struggle against clericalism and the monarchy, for publ in International Herald, Feb 15.
M mentions (in a letter to Bolte) that up to this point Meissner has pubd the first eight (out of nine) fascicules of the second German edn [«— 72:32; —> :29].
M reads a couple of satires by Saltykov-Shchedrin, sent him by Danielson.

M reads books, received from Danielson, by A. A. Golovachov (on “ten years of Reform,” 1861-71) and Ziber (on Ricardo), and begins studying the five-vol. work by A. Skrebitzky on the peasant question under Alexander II.

E sends Sorge (NY GC) an informational report on the IWMA in England and on the Continent; he urges that the GC resolution on the self-exclusion of sections not recognizing the Hague decisions be implemented in Spain, the Jura, etc.

M&E take part in the second anniversary commemoration of the Paris Commune, held by the British Federal Council and Communard refugees, which adopts a statement made up of passages from The civil war in France (#M143).
In a letter to Mrs. Natalie Liebknecht, E inquires about the prison conditions of Liebknecht and Bebel and the possibility of improving their personal circumstances.
E finishes a second version of his article “On authority” (#E538) [*-72:61], and sends it to Bignami [-» :58].
M corresponds with Bignami on the publ of an Italian edn. (This will not be accomplished, because of the government’s harassment of Bignami.)
La Emancipaciön pubs a Spanish trans of the section of Vol. 1 on the transformation of money into capital.
M, still working on the French trans, consults Lafargue on some trans problems.
Writing to Danielson, M asks for info on Chicherin’s views on the historical development of common property in land in Russia, and on the dispute between Chicherin and the historian I. D. Belyayev.
M and daughter Eleanor are on holiday in Brighton “for a few days” around this time: so writes E on this date.

In accord with decisions of the Hague Congress, E and Lafargue work on a pamphlet (#ME6) to be pubd by the GC exposing the roots and operation of the Bakuninist Alliance, esp inside the IWMA; M collaborates with them; M&E write the “Conclusion.” But note: even before Apr, M&E collected materials and documentation used here (cf #ME7, 96; #M518) [-* :36).
M asks J. P. Becker to start preparing for a Swiss delegation to the next IWMA congress, in Geneva, to protect the organizn against the Bakuninists.
E sends an informational report to the NY GC, mainly on IWMA periodicals and publications (#E850).
E collaborates with Vickery, British Federal Council secy, on preparations for the second congress of the British Federation in Manchester.
E works on editorial preparation of the minutes of the Hague Congress for publ in French; the project remains unfinished.

E writes a letter to Hepner refuting the distorted article on the IWMA pubd Apr 27 by the Lassallean paper Neue Social-Demokrat. Though it was not written for publ, part of the letter appears in Volksstaat, May 7 (#E543).

At Riley's request, E sends the International Herald notes on the workers' movement in various countries; on these notes by E (not extant), Riley bases items for the paper’s column on TU news, pubd Apr 12,26, May 3,24 (source: MEW Daten).
M sends the last corrected proof sheets of the second German edn to Meissner.
M studies agricultural conditions in Russia; reads articles on the question in the journal Sovremennik, incl an article by Chernyshevsky and a review of Chicherin by A. Severtsev.
Danielson, as requested, sends M brief biographical data on Chernyshevsky.
E’s mandate as GC plenipotentiary for Italy [«-:6] is pubd in La Plebe.

E writes an article for Volksstaat (#E380) replying to the Apr 27 attack on the IWMA in the Lassallean Neue Social-Demokrat; pubd May 10. E’s letter to Hepner (#E543) [<- :23], on the same subject, appears in Volksstaat May 7.
M discusses the agenda of the second congress of the British Federation (Manchester, June 1-2) with Dupont and Serraillier, who are on the Federal Council.
M&E exchange correspondence on the strengthening of reaction in France, as MacMahon succeeds Thiers (May 24).
Meissner pubs the last fascicule of the second German edn, thus completing publ in serial parts [«- :15] (for book publ, see —► :35).
Despite deteriorating health, M continues working on his revision of Roy’s French trans; a part of the text, he finds, he has to translate afresh.
Danielson, as requested, sends M a collection of materials on Russian landed property, esp on the obshchina (village community) and on bibliography.

”In bed this morning, the following dialectical ideas on the natural sciences came into my head”: thus begins E’s letter to M. This more or less inaugurates the period of several years during which E will work on notes on the “dialectics of nature” (cf #E221). M shows E’s letter to the chemist Schorlemmer, who annotates his agreement with a number of points.

In discussions with Samuel Moore in Manchester, M maintains that it is (theoretically) possible to determine the “main laws of crises” by mathematical analysis of economic movements and their zigzags (tables of prices, discount rates, etc.); in fact M has at various times in the past tried to calculate these “ups and downs” as irregular curves (so he tells E, May 31).

Since M’s health is bad (“cerebral congestion,” insomnia, cough, headaches), esp because of overwork on the French trans of Capital, E convinces him to go to Manchester to consult Dr. Gumpert. But when M arrives in Manchester, Gumpert is away in Germany. M awaits his return on June 2, meanwhile spending time with his friends Sam Moore (see «— :31) and Schorlemmer.
M visits Dronke in Southport.
M travels with Moore to Buxton, returning to Manchester on June 2, when he sees Dr. Gumpert. Gumpert puts M on a strict regimen incl a four-hour working limit [-* :38].
M receives a report from Wilmart (Buenos Aires, May 27) on his activity for the IWMA.

On behalf of the GC, E translates its May 23 statement against the Bakuninists into English and French, and sends copies to the Federal Councils in Britain, Spain, and Portugal, and to La Plebe in Italy.
E writes a short report to the NY GC on miscellaneous items of IWMA business (#E851).
E writes an article reporting IWMA developments in various countries, for Volksstaat (#E307); pubd July 2.
Bolte sends M info on the state of the IWMA in America.

In an important letter to Bebel, E stresses political principles: the party should face toward the masses outside the movement, not toward recruiting from rival groups; one should not be fooled by cries for “unity” raised by splitters and sectarians; principles should not be sacrificed for short-range successes; etc.
The second German edn is pubd in book form [«- :29] in Hamburg, with the imprint date 1872.
M is still working at revising the French trans.
E helps Larroque, a French IWMA 6migr6 in Spain, establish ties with the Spanish IWMA, and from him E receives info on the movement in Spain and Bordeaux.
E’s article-report on the IWMA (#E307) [«- :33] is pubd in Volksstaat.
M&E finish, and date, the “Conclusion” of the anti-Bakunin pamphlet (#ME6) [—► :44].
E telegraphs Sorge (NY GC) that Serraillier has agreed to attend the coming IWMA congress in Geneva as the GC representative.
E sends Sorge an informational report on IWMA affairs in various countries.
M asks Perret (in Geneva) to find a book deal er to handle the sale of this forthcoming pamphlet.
Studying the history of common property in land in Russia, M reads works by V. I. Sergeyevich, F. Skaldin, K. A. Nevolin, N. Kalachov, et al.

In a letter to Kugelmann, who has written (June 29) in great perturbation about reports that M is dangerously ill or even dead, E recounts M’s health problems [«- :32] and says he has improved. Kugelmann sends Volksstaat a note denying the pubd reports; pubd July 13. However, despite Dr. Gumpert’s injunctions, M continues to work long hours at the BM.
NY Section 1 sends M a mandate as its delegate to the IWMA congress in Geneva.
M&E (the latter in Ramsgate) exchange letters on the question of going to the Geneva Congress; they decide not to attend; Serraillier [«- :36] and Hepner should likewise not go [-» :43].
M sends Danielson the last pubd fascicule of the second German edn [«— :29).
M receives a letter from Danielson regretting he cannot send full biographical info on Chernyshevsky; he cautions that it would be premature for M to align himself with Chernyshevsky in the press.
E takes the waters in Ramsgate, but goes to London for a day to organize the distribution of the anti-Bakunin pamphlet (#ME6).
E drafts the text of a letter, for Serraillier’s signature, addressed to the IWMA Geneva Congress, explaining why he is not attending (#E819) [♦- :39).

In a letter to Sorge (NY GC), M summarizes why the Geneva Congress was a fiasco; it is necessary to “let the formal organizn of the International recede into the background for the time being”; events will ensure “the resurrection of the International in improved form.”
E writes a study “The Bakuninists at work” on the Spanish uprising of the past summer (#E59), for Volksstaat [-► :49).
The Engels-Lafargue-Marx pamphlet exposing the Bakuninist Alliance (#ME6) is pubd in French.
E draws up a short presentation of this pamphlet for Volksstaat (#E111.5); it is pubd in four installs, titled “Cagliostro Bakunin.”
M sends copies of the second German edn to Darwin and Herbert Spencer [-► :48].
M is still ailing and is still under doctor’s orders to limit his working hours.
A first child is bom to the Longuets (M’s daughter Jenny), Charles F6licien, in London—at this point, M’s only surviving grandchild [-» 74:27].
M makes the acquaintance of Edward Aveling.
Eugen Jaeger, author of Moderne Sozialismus, writes M asking for full biographical info, for use in his second edn.
Darwin and Spencer, resp, send M polite acknowledgments of Capital [«- :45],
Meissner sends M 1000 talers as payment for the second German edn.

E makes notes for a projected historical work on Germany. For miscellaneous mss from this period, see #E530. According to MEW Daten, E’s synopsis of a history by G. von Gülich (#E181) was also done in this period; likewise notes on C. E. Langethal. Re the dating of the Gülich synopsis, see <— :4.
E’s “Bakuninists at work” (#E59) begins publ in Volksstaat [«-:44; —► :51].
E sojourns in Engelskirchen because of his mother's death.
M (also E after his return from Germany) meets several times with Utin, who is visiting London and gives new info on Bakunin's activities.
Vo Iks stoat finishes publ of E’s “Bakuninists at work” (#E59) [<- :49]. (The pamphlet edn will appear either later this month or Dec D; see Register.)

E works at revising S. Kokosky’s poor German trans of the anti-Bakunin brochure #ME6, for pamphlet publ by the Volksstaat press (which will take place in 1874) under the title, in German, A plot against the IWMA.
M and Utin (see «- :51) visit Beesly.
Lopatin, who has come from Paris to London to see M (who is out of town—see —► :55), meets with E, then returns to Paris on Nov 28.
E informs M by letter of Lopatin’s visit and his previous adventures.
M is visited by the journalist Thieblen.
M gives the BM Library some of the serial parts (fascicules) of the French edn of Capital (source: MEW Daten).
E reads the ms of the French trans of Capital (source: MEW Daten).
In a letter to E, M, having just read Sainte-Beuve’s Chateaubriand et son groupe littöraire sous 1 'Empire (1861), sets down an analysis of why he detests Chateaubriand and his style.
E returns from Germany [<- :50] to London.
M and daughter Eleanor, both ill, go to Harrogate to take the waters.
M makes a day’s trip to Manchester to consult Dr. Gumpert, who forbids him to work for the time being [-► :60].
Kugelmann informs M that Miquel, on being asked, told him that M can return to Germany, prob without police harassment, if he refrains from behaving demonstratively.

In a letter to E, M comments on the table of contents of a book by De Paepe (as announced in L’Internationale, Nov 23, 30, but in fact never pubd) in which De Paepe, purporting to expound M’s polit eco, shows he does not understand it.
M informs pub’r Lachätre that he intends to speed up the work on the French trans.
Kugelmann’s letter (see +- :56) reports a review of Capital by someone named Baron, in the journal Im neuen Reich.
Bignami’s Almanacco Repubblicano for 1874 appears, with articles by M (#M404) and E (#E538) directed against anarchism.

E, writing to M, makes biting comments on a new book by R. Benedix which denounces “Shakespearo-mania"—yet “there is more life and reality in the first act of the Merry Wives than in all of German literature.” Really!
M naturally agrees: if people like Benedix understood Shakespeare, how would they get the nerve to put their own stuff on the boards?
M, returning from Harrogate («— :55), goes to Manchester for another medical visit to Dr. Gumpert; on the 17th he returns to London.
M suffers from carbuncles.
M renews his BM Library card (not in Chronicle; from Higgins 2017, n42)
In the Reichstag elections the SDWP (Eisenachers) elects nine deputies.
M’s comment on the election, in a letter to Kugelmann, is that it “serves Mr. Bismarck and his middle-class tail right.”
E comments (to Liebknecht) that this victory ‘‘puts the German proletariat at the head of the European workers’ movement_”
E contributes money to the election fund of the German party, collected by the London GWEA.
M gives Barry help and advice toward writing an article on the German election for the London Examiner.

M collects and studies material bearing on Vols. 2 and 3; he investigates the problems of land ownership, comparing ancient authors with the latest researches, (source: MEW Daten; cf M to Kugelmann, May 18.)

Writing to Liebknecht, E mentions his work on the history of Germany [<— :2), and says he has in mind articles for Volksstaat, perhaps a booklet, perhaps even a book, so deeply is he involved in “economic and statistical studies” for it.
Bernhard Becker writes M about party electoral work in Germany, esp in Brunswick, and about his forthcoming book Die Arbeiteragitation Ferdinand Lassalles [—» :29).
E writes an article for Volksstaat on the militarism of the Bismarck government (#E371) [-> :13J.

E writes an article (#E245) for Volksstaat on the English parliamentary election just held, welcoming the election of two mine-union secretaries, and criticizing the running of workers’ candidates as mere tails to the Liberal party instead of through an independent working-class party; pubd Mar 4.
Liebknecht repeatedly proposes to M&E that the Volksstaat press be permitted to publish the Poverty of philosophy (#M681) and the Holy family (#ME76); M agrees [-* :38].
book: The Poverty of Philosophy,The Holy Family

text: M continues his study of plant physiology and land fertilization, as part of his investigation of agricultural economics, and reads J. Au's book on J. v. Liebig's Lehre (etc.), as well as other works on agrochemistry.
M’s health worsens again, with headaches and insomnia; he is unable to work part of the time.
E’s article on the militarism of the Bismarck government (#E371) [<— :8] is pubd in Volksstaat.
E writes an article for Volksstaat on Moltke and German military policy (#E744); pubd Mar 25.
M&E are apprised of the dangerous influence of Prof. Dühring in the movement, by an article in Volksstaat (Mar 13, 20), “Ein neuer ‘Communist,’ ” by Bebel (unsigned).
M is visited by Lavrov, editor of Vperyod, who has recently arrived from Zurich in order to continue publ of the periodical in London.
M&E meet regularly with Lopatin, who shows them an article on M’s economic theory by Ziber pubd in Znaniye, no. 1,1874. M&E give Lopatin a recommendatory letter to J. Mesa (Spain).
Volksstaat pubs E’s article on the English election (#E245) [«- :9].
M begins to study the last several years of the English Blue Books, on English economy and economic policy; he has bought them from a wastepaper dealer.
M’s business dispute with Le Moussu [see <— :4] may have come to a head this month.

M, unable to work because of headaches and insomnia, goes to Ramsgate to take the waters. Dr. Gumpert advises him (via E) to stop working altogether and go to Carlsbad for mineral-water treatments [—► :31].

E writes an article (#E592)—the first of a series on “Refugee literature" in the Volksstaat (#E660)—on the Polish address, stressing the theme that support of Polish freedom is necessary to free Germany from Russian influence and to prepare revolution in Russia: “A people which oppresses another cannot emancipate itself” (pubd June 17).

In response to the Russian czar’s visit to England, the Polish revolutionary emigration (Wrö-blewski, Jan Krynski) issue an “Address of the Polish refugees to the English people." Wröblewski has E read it May 4-5.
M sends Lachätre the galley proofs he has finished, up to the three last fascicules.
After the long interruption due to illness, M resumes work (May betw 5-12) on the French trans.
M works on the three last fascicules.

Writing to Kugelmann, M remarks that in the US, “the greatest obstacle is the professional politicians, who immediately try to distort every new movement and turn it into another ’business proposition.’ "
In letters to Liebknecht, W. Bios, and Hepner, M&E warn against Prof. Dühring’s influence in the party and criticize his book Kritische Geschichte der National-Ökonomie und des Socialismus.
E hears from Liebknecht on the persecution of the Volksstaat editors by the government.

M&E write to Bracke in order to get him to raise the question in Volksstaat of changing the party program, in accord with a commission elected at the 1873 party congress, on program revision. (Bracke will raise the question July 1.)
E answers a letter from A. Wegmann (in Rio de Janeiro), and informs him of the state of the IWMA.
M is visited by Georg Weber, of Kiel.

E writes the second article in this series (#E621), analyzing the program pubd by the 6migr6 group of Blanquist Communards; it makes a fundamental criticism of the Blanquist-type sect and its conception of revolutionary dictatorship (pubd in Volksstaat, June 26).
E’s first article (#E592) in the series “Refugee literature" [«-:11) is pubd in Volksstaat.

E hears from Liebknecht on the successful work of the party congress in Coburg, July 18-21; Liebknecht stresses that unification with the Lassalleans is out of the question, except for “tactical unity." (KMC’s erroneous dating is Aug 28.)
Preparing a “third printing" of his Peasant war in Germany (#E579) for publ, E writes a supplement (#E581) to the preface of the 1870 second edn. (This will be pubd in 1875.)
E writes the third article (#E661) in the series “Refugee literature" for Volksstaat; it criticizes Lavrov’s conciliatory attitude toward Bakunin [-> :37].
M’s grandson, Jenny Longuet’s 11-month-old child Charles [«- 73:46], dies of cholerine. M is very hard-hit.
M is convalescing in Ryde; his daughter Laura, on a visit to England, stays in Ryde July 11-13. M&E exchange letters (July 15, 21), chatting about European political affairs.

In a letter to Sorge surveying the international scene, M comments on the decline of the IWMA in England, the TUs in France, the impotence of the anarchist “super-socialism" in Spain, Italy, and Belgium, and the role of Bismarck in Germany; he sees a “general European war" lying ahead.
Sorge resigns as gen secy of the GC in NY.
Sorge writes about this step to E (who receives it Aug D) [—► :33].

In his letter to Sorge (see «- :28), M complains that Volksstaat is peppered with fanciful articles about the future socialist society by half-educated philistines and academics; he comments that B. Becker’s booklet about Lassalle (<— :8] is useful for finishing off the Lassallean sect.
E approves a proposal by Bios to publish a Cologne daily called Neue Rheinische Ztg. (But the plan is not carried out.)
M applies for British citizenship.
M accompanies his daughter Jenny to E, who is staying in Ramsgate. Jenny then stays on with E and his family (Lizzie Bums, and her niece Mary Ellen).
The Home Ministry rejects M’s application for citizenship, on the (confidential) ground that “The man had not been loyal to his King” [of Prussia]-’’
M is unable to continue working on the French trans of Capital because of his persistent liver ailment.
E and Jenny go on a trip to Jersey [—► :34].
On Dr. Gumpert’s orders, M, accompanied by his daughter Eleanor, travels to Carlsbad to take the waters.

M and Eleanor sojourn in Carlsbad, at the Hotel Germania on the Schlossberg, together with the Kugelmann family. M spends time also with Max Oppenheim (Mrs. Kugelmann’s brother), Simon Deutsch (a bibliographer), Otto Knille (a painter), and a number of physicians incl Dr. Gans Jr and Dr. Kraus.

M and Eleanor remain in Carlsbad for the first three weeks of the month. M’s personal relations with Dr. Kugelmann are drastically cooled by M’s and Eleanor’s revulsion at the way Kugelmann treats his wife; there is an open falling-out on Sep 6, which does not go so far as breaking off relations.
M and Eleanor leave Carlsbad.
They stay in Dresden.
In Leipzig, M meets with Liebknecht, Bios (who has just been released from prison), and others of the Leipzig party.
In Berlin, M and Eleanor visit Edgar von Westphalen.
In Hamburg, M visits Meissner and meets with Ceib and Auer on party affairs |—► :35).

E writes a long letter to Sorge, approving his decision to resign as GC gen secy [«— :28]; the IWMA, E says, became unviable by becoming successful enough to be fought over; the next International will be directly communist and based on M’s principles.
E returns with his family and Jenny [«— :30] from Jersey, arriving in London at 2 a.m.
M and Eleanor return to London.
The Lassallean group makes a unity proposal to the SDWP (Eisenachers), in a note by Tölcke to Liebknecht.
Liebknecht informs M&E of the unity proposal, remarking that it should be considered with great reserve. (M is also informed by H. Ramm, a Volksstaat editor.)
Volksstaat pubs the third article (#E661) [«- :26] in the series “Refugee literature,” a criticism of Lavrov.
At the request of Lopatin (in Paris), E sends him this article (#E661), which Lopatin immediately forwards to his friends in St. Petersburg.
Volksstaat reprints M’s 1852 pamphlet Revelations concerning the Com trial in Cologne (#M762), naming the author; it runs in 13 installs (-* 75:8].
book: Revelations Concerning the Cologne Communist Trial

text: Geib (in Hamburg) reports to M on progress in the unity negotiations between the SDWP (Eisenachers) and the Lassalleans (GGWA), and on the forthcoming congress.
Liebknecht again [«— :10) urges M&E to permit republication of the Poverty of philosophy (#M681) and the Holy family (#ME76).
book: The Poverty of Philosophy,The Holy Family

text: M sees the official announcement of the planned unification of the Eisenachers and Lassalleans (SDWP and GGWA) in the Dec 11 issue of Volksstaat.
M reads Chernyshevsky’s work Cavaignac and again studies his Pisma bes adressa, pubd in Zurich during 1874. (MEW Daten dates this: end of 1874.)
Marx renews his BM Library card (not in Chronicle; from Higgins 2017, n42)
notes: No idea how this is possible given that he's traveling

text: M&E speak at a meeting in the White Horse Tavern celebrating the 12th anniversary of the Polish uprising of 1863, chaired by Wröblewski, along with many ex-IWMA and Communard speakers (Frankel, Lissagaray, etc.).

M writes an Afterword (#M763) to his Revelations pamphlet on the Cologne trial (#M762), which Volksstaat has been reprinting [«— 74:37]; the Afterword is pubd in Volksstaat Jan 27. (Prob shortly thereafter, the whole work appears as a pamphlet pubd by the Volksstaat press.)
M, finishing work on the last three serial parts of the French trans, sends them to pub’r Lachätre.
E notes the worsening of Franco-German relations and the aggressively militaristic course of the Bismarck government, on which he will publish an article in Apr [—► :17J.

Liebknecht writes E urging him to take up Prof. Dühring’s writings in Volksstaat, since Dühring’s influence in party circles is increasing [—> :16]; Liebknecht also urges a reply to Tkachov (see —► :11).
Bebel writes M&E asking their opinion on the “unity business” being discussed by the two parties [-* :12).
E writes, as his fourth article in the “Refugee literature” series (#E662), a reply to Tkachov and a critique of Russian Populist ideology [—»:14j.

M reads Tkachov’s reply to E’s third article on “Refugee literature” (#E661) [«-74:37), and in a note on the pamphlet’s title page, M advises E to “go after him (Tkachov)” lustily (KMC dating: c.Dec 1874; MEW dating: Feb or Mar).

M, having read a batch of Russian 6migr6 publications sent him by Lavrov, writes him about the interesting material in it, esp the correspondence columns of Vperyod, most esp a report (by Lopatin) on a Siberian group, Ne Nashi, which opposes all existing social institutions.
Volksstaat and Neue Social-Demokrat publish a draft program for unification of the Lassalleans and Eisenachers (the “Gotha program”).
M&E see this draft program, but they have received no other info about it from Germany.

After discussion with M, and writing as “we,” E responds to Bebel's inquiry [«— : 10] with a sharp criticism of the draft program and the process of unification; he also charges that Liebknecht has deliberately kept M&E uninformed. E temporarily holds up mailing this letter since Bebel is still in prison (till Apr 1).
Bracke writes to E along the same lines as Bebel.
On the receipt of Bracke s letter, E sends Bracke the letter he has written to Bebel. (It is usually labeled letter of Mar 18-28.)
M gives Barry advice and material for the latter’s articles in the Standard, the Hour, etc.

Dilke and Morley ask M to write a reply to the article by McDonnell, “KM and German socialism" (Fortnightly Rev, Mar 1), which calls M’s economic analysis “rather childish” and his views “pessimistic” (source; KMC, which refers to a Mar 5 letter by Dilke).

M gets several requests from Glaser de Willebrord to write for his planned Belgian weekly La R6forme Sociale, which is to represent the now divided non-Proudhonist socialist tendencies. M approves, but adopts a wait-and-see attitude.
Volksstaat pubs an article by E (#E283) on the Jan 23 Polish meeting, reporting the speeches made there by both M&E.
Volksstaat pubs the fourth article (#E662).

E finishes writing his fourth article in the “Refugee literature” series (#E662) [«- :11J, this one against Tkachov. Perhaps he also begins work on his fifth article in the series (#E754), a continuation of the polemic against Tkachov’s populism, for which, see —► :17.
The M family moves [<- 64:12] to 41 Maitland Park Road—M’s last residence.
M works on his critique of the draft unity program (“Gotha program”) [—► :20].
Liebknecht again [<- :10] urges E to write a critique of Prof. Dühring [-* 76:28].
Liebknecht writes letters to E attempting to justify his course on the unity proceedings and on the draft program, in response to E’s criticism.
Volksstaat completes publ [«- :14] of E’s fourth article in the “Refugee literature” series (#E662). E writes his fifth article (#E754) this month if he did not already begin it in Mar.
Hepner (in Breslau) invites M to have M&E’s “lesser writings” reprinted in a collected edn, through his press.
Volksstaat pubs E’s fifth article in the “Refugee literature” series (#E754), continuing the polemic against Tkachov’s populism [—> :24).
Volksstaat pubs E’s article (#E730) [<- :10] on Bismarck’s aggressive militarism; prob written this month.
M&E visit Pfänder, who is ill.

M writes an Afterword (#M132) called “Avis au lecteur” to the French edn, pub in the last fascicule [—* :41); it stresses that this edn possesses independent scientific value apart from the German edn.
M sends his “critique of the Gotha program” (#M207) [«- :16] to Bracke, with a covering letter, for the German party leadership, incl Auer, Geib, etc., besides Bebel and Liebknecht.

At the Gotha unity congress, the new united party is established as the Social-Democratic (S-D) party of Germany; the program is adopted May 25 (pubd May 28); M’s criticism are almost entirely ignored, and are even kept from Bebel’s knowledge by Liebknecht’s machinations.
M informs Lavrov of a “safe address” in Berlin (C. A. Schramm) through which they can correspond.
Dupont sends M&E letters on his activity in Ajnerica, and asks for 1WMA material.
M is visited by Max Oppenheim.
M reads Haxthausen, Die ländliche Verfassung Russlands.
M carries out a large number of calculations illustrating the difference between the rate of surplus value and the rate of profit (later used for Ch. 3 ofVol.3).
E’s fifth article in the “Refugee literature” series (#E754) («- :17] is pubd as a pamphlet titled “Social questions in Russia,” with a new preface by E (#E755).

E, who since the Hague Congress has remained in contact with the NY GC, receives from it copies of a confidential circular on the calling of a conference in Philadelphia for the purpose of spreading IWMA sections in Europe [- :28].
A letter by M to Lavrov shows the importance M ascribes to recently pubd experiments by the chemist M. Traube on the laboratory creation of an artificial cell.

Hermann Schumacher, biographer of J. H. von Thiinen, is moved by reading Capital to send M a copy of Thünen’s book Der isolirte Staat; he asks M’s opinion of his own preface to that work. (The book arrives while M is traveling, and his answer is delayed; see —> :33.)

M addresses a letter to the anonymous author (actually Matilda Betham-Edwards) of an article on the IWMA in Fraser’s Magazine (three installs, July-Sep), correcting a number of factual misstatements; M also warns that the announced condensation of Capital in English would violate his copyright, and comments pessimistically on the accuracy of translators.
E reports to the GC on the steps he has taken to distribute the circular on the Philadelphia conference [<— :25], and describes the situation in the European IWMA sections (#E445).

At Liebknecht’s request, M (helped by E) does some partial revision of a condensation of Capital pubd in a booklet by J. Most in 1873 (see ST/51); but M stipulates that his name is not to be used [—► 76:12].
E is on holiday in Ramsgate.
M leaves London for Carlsbad, to take the waters.

On the way, between Cologne and Frankfurt, M gets into a conversation with a Catholic priest about Bismarck’s Kulturkampf. M stops in Frankfurt, visits the Frankfurter Ztg editorial office and has a long discussion with the editor L. Sonnemann; he also meets Guido Weiss.
In Carlsbad, M stays at the same hotel as before [«— 74:31]. (For this stay, see-» :32).
In Carlsbad M sees much of the Russian historian M. M. Kovalevsky. He comes under the surveillance of the Austrian secret police.
M leaves Carlsbad.
M stops in Prague, where he visits Max Oppenheim.
M returns to London.
Responding to Schumacher’s letter [«- :26], M asks him to send his 1868 biography of Thünen; M points out the difference in their concepts of wages.

M again intensively takes up polit eco, esp the study of Russian agrarian relations. He reads and excerpts some books pubd in 1875 in Berlin by Russian liberals, Y. F. Samarin, A. I. Koshelyev, K. D. Kavelin.

Lavrov writes E about the publ of a pamphlet by “Nechayev’s supporters” replying to the IWMA anti-Bakunin pamphlet by Engels-Lafargue-Marx (#ME6), a reply titled Quelques mots d’un groupe socialiste r6volu-tionnaire russe (etc.) [—► :38].
Imandt (in Dundee) sends M that day’s issue of the Dundee Advertiser, which contains an unsigned article replying, on behalf of the IWMA, to the Fraser Magazine piece [«-:27).
M replies that he suspects the author is Barry.
Carl Hirsch and Kaub (from Paris) visit M.

In similar letters to Bracke and Bebel, E analyzes what is wrong with the program adopted at the Gotha congress [«- :20], stresses that this unity contains the germ of a future split, but assures that he and M will not come out against the program publicly because the public construes the program in a communist sense.
Writing to Bebel, E conveys M’s criticism of a recent boner in Volksstaat; in this connection E explains the sectarian anti-TU viewpoint of all socialist groups before M.
M reads Slavophile brochures by Samarin and Dmitriev, and by Koshelyev.
In his letter to Bebel (see «- :36), E discusses the trend to revolution in Russia, indeed the next revolution may start there.
M writes Lavrov that in his opinion “this schoolboy piece” does not deserve a reply.
M&E read the pamphlet Quelques mots (etc.) [«— :35], sent to E by Lavrov Sep D or Oct A.
Bignami writes E proposing that M&E publish a volume of their writings in his Biblioteca Socialists series.

E and his companion, Lizzie Burns, travel to Heidelberg in order to place her niece, Mary Ellen Bums, in a boarding school there. E interrupts the trip in Rheinau, where he meets an acquaintance, the chemist Pauli. On the return trip, he stops in Bingen and Cologne, and returns to London via Ostend. (The niece will stay in Heidelberg till Mar 1877.)

The last fascicule of the French edn comes off the press, the first having appeared as long ago as Sep 17,1872. It contains M’s Afterword (#M132) («— :19). For M’s mail-out of copies, see —» :48. This edn is pubd in 10,000-11,000 copies, printed in Louis Lahure’s Paris printshop. The selling price is 5 francs complete (6 francs bound).

Pursuing the subject of Russian agrarian conditions for Vol. 2 of Capital, M studies and excerpts works on agrochemistry (e.g., A. N. Engelhardt) and on physics and polit eco esp as related to agrarian problems. He reads I. I. Patlayevsky’s book Deneshnyi rynok v Rossii ot 1700 do 1762g, an article by Engelhardt on questions of Russian agriculture, and a collection of military statistics pubd by the Russian general staff, fourth edn of 1871, on which he makes extensive notes.
Danielson sends M 10 vols. of Russian material on the work of the Tax Commission (—► :45|.
She writes her first article on the London theater, “From London’s theater world,” for the Frankfurter Ztg und Handelsblatt; pubd Nov 21 (-► 76:7].

(sent Nov 17): Having read Lavrov’s article of Sep 15 on “Socialism and the struggle for existence,” E writes him, at his request, a longish letter on his views; E argues against the one-sided conception of seeing all society and history in terms of the “struggle for existence” rather than also cooperation.
M writes Lavrov explaining that because of an attack of furuncles he cannot speak at the Dec 4 anniversary meeting celebrating the Polish uprising of 1830.

E writes Wröblewski that he cannot attend the anniversary meeting because of a very bad cold. The letters of both M&E stress their belief that Polish liberation is a keystone to the emancipation of the European proletariat. The letters are read at the meeting and reported in Vperyod of Dec 31.

M studies the 10 vols. on the Tax Commission [<- :42], and a collection of material from the Russian government bureaus for peasant affairs, sent him by Danielson. M considers this material very important for the study of land ownership, ground rent, and agrarian relations in general, in connection with his plans for Vol. 3.
M informs Lavrov that because of the great length of the French edn, the subject index to this edn which had been prepared by Lavrov could not be used.
In a letter to Dietzgen, M expresses his intention of writing a book on dialectics after he has finished Capital.
E gives a speech (#E767) at a meeting celebrating the anniversary of the Polish uprising of 1863, chaired by Wröblewski.
M&E speak at the 36th anniversary meeting of the London GWEA; M treats the history of the assoc and the principle of internationalism.
E writes the essay “Prussian Schnaps in the German Reichstag’’ (#E645), a thrust at Junkerdom; section I is pubd in Volksstaat, Feb 25,27.
M drafts a passage on “Differential rent and rent as mere interest on capital incorporated in the soil” (which E will later insert into Vol. 3, Ch. 44).
(rec’d Apr A): Sorge writes M about the state of the US movement and his own activity.
Leo Frankel (in Budapest) reports to M on his arrest in Vienna and his coming trial for participating in the Paris Commune.
Volksstaat pubs section II of E’s “Prussian Schnaps [etc.)” (#E645) [«— :4); the entire essay is then pubd as a pamphlet (which the government bans).

The letter by Sorge (see ♦- :6) urges M to check over the trans of the Com Manifesto by Hermann Meyert which he had given M in 1872, and to write something supplementary so that it can be pubd in America (Sorge will repeat this request 1876-80, without success) [-► :11],
Mrs. M writes her second article of theatrical reportage, “The London season,” for Frankfurter Ztg und Handelsblatt; pubd Apr 4 [<- :43.5; -► :37J.
Schorlemmer visits E in London for a few days.
Pfänder dies in London.
M studies a number of works on physiology: Schleiden, Physiologie der Pflanzen und Tiere; J. Ranke, Grundzüge der Physiologie des Menschen; a work by Hermann; et al.

Replying to Sorge [«- :6] about his complaint against dirty dealings in the movement, M paraphrases Chernyshevsky from memory: “Whoever goes down historical roads must not be afraid of getting dirty” (Chernyshevsky: “The road of history is not the sidewalk of the Nevsky Prospekt.... Whoever is afraid of... getting his boots dirty should not meddle in social activity.”)

In his letter to Sorge (see «- :10), M agrees to prepare a new edn of the Com Manifesto but says the time has not yet come to add an “appendix,” i.e., a supplement to bring the Manifesto up to date. M also mentions that he possesses none of his NYDT articles, and asks for the hie which Weydemeyer left to the late Hermann Meyer.
M plans to study land ownership in Hungary, and obtains the relevant literature in German through Frankel [—► :14].
The second edn of J. Most’s condensation of Capital (ST/51) [«- 75:29] is pubd in Chemnitz (KMC dating: May A) [-* :18].

In his letter to Sorge (see <— :10), M requests American book catalogs from 1873 to the present, for his studies on American agriculture and landed property relations, as well as on “credit (panics, money, etc.),” for Vol. 2.
Liebknecht sends E the ms of an article by J. Most, submitted to Volksstaat, lauding Dühring, esp his philosophy; Liebknecht again urges E to write a critique of Dühring.
E (in Ramsgate) sends the Most ms to M, with some mordant remarks on Liebknecht’s incompetence as editor, and raises the question of whether the time has come to settle matters with Dühring.
M agrees that an all-out critique of Dühring is necessary.
E reluctantly accepts the task; in a letter to M, he outlines the course he will take.
M studies forms of Allmende (Ai-meinde)—common land—and reads works by the historian G. L. von Maurer (source: MEW Daten; cf KMC entry under June).
M receives a letter from Frankel [«- :12] with info on land ownership in Hungary.
E’s letter (see <- :13) incidentally notes that M is studying “ground rent in general and Russian agrarian conditions in particular.”

M is visited by the Danish socialist Pio. Before Pio leaves London May 22, M receives—by telegram and letter to Pio—an invitation to attend the June 6 congress of the Danish SDWP in Copenhagen. (M declines.)
Bracke writes E with a proposal for M: a new edn of Herr Vogt (#M372).
A new grandson is bom to M: Jenny Longuet’s Jean Laurent Frederick (“Johnny”), the first of M’s grandchildren who will survive childhood.
(or perhaps to June M) E and his companion, Lizzie Bums, are on holiday in Ramsgate.

M begins an intensive study of the forms of primitive communal property among various peoples, esp the Slavs; i.a. he rereads Maurer’s Geschichte der Fronhöfe and his Geschichte der Dorfverfassung [etc.] (cf 4-:14 for the MEW Daten entry) (source: KMC; see-* :40).

M sends Sorge his revisions of Most’s condensation of Capital (ST/51) [4- 75:29], mentioning that he has made changes in re value, money, wages, and many other passages, but since much is still wrong with it, he forbids any use of his name [—> 77:47].
E begins writing his series on Wilhelm Wolff (#E918) [-* :22].

E writes the study “The part played by labor in the transition from ape to man” (#E223), as introduction to a projected essay (see the Register); later the ms will be assigned to the work-in-progress Dialectics of nature (#E221).
E and his companion go to Heidelberg to visit Mary Ellen Bums [4- 75:40; —► :25].
Two days after Bakunin’s death, his funeral serves as the occasion for his colleagues (the anarchist rump of the IWMA) to talk of unity with the Social-Democrats.
M&E exchange letters lamenting Liebknecht’s political incompetence as usual, and stressing the dangers of accepting the anarchists into the organization.

Liebknecht writes E asking what M&E think of the Bakuninists’ attempts at rapprochement; but in Volksstaat (July 15) Liebknecht treats the idea favorably. E replies (letter not extant) warning sharply against falling for the anarchists1 solicitations.
E’s series on W. Wolff (#E918) [«— :19] is pubd in Die Neue Welt, in 11 installs.
M visits his wife, who is taking the waters in Brighton.
E and his companion, Lizzie Burns, sojourn in Ramsgate.
Night stopover in Cologne.
M and Eleanor depart for Carlsbad to take the waters (his third trip there).
A few hours’ stop in Nuremberg.
Ditto in Weiden, and arrival in Carlsbad.
M and Eleanor sojourn in Carlsbad, at the same hotel as before [<— 75:31].
M discusses politics with the physician Prof. Friedberg of the U. of Breslau, esp on Eduard Lasker’s Erlebnisse einer Mannes-Seeie (1873).
M receives from Lavrov his essay in Vperyod on “The state element in the future society,” which M puts aside to be read “in the future.”
M receives a request for an article from the NY Labor Standard.

Among other people whom M talks with in Carlsbad are the physicians Dr. Fleckles and Dr. W. A. Freund, also H. Graetz, author of a history of the Jews, with whom he has a long talk i.a. about Russian czarism [—► :26].
They leave Heidelberg.
They stop over in Cologne.
E remains in Ramsgate; on Aug 15 he goes to London and finds Schorlemmer visiting M.
They return to England via Vlissingen, changing in London direct for Ramsgate.
E and his companion go to Heidelberg to visit Mary Ellen Bums [«- :20].
They leave Carlsbad.
They stop over in Prague; M visits Max Oppenheim.
They stop in Bingen and in Kreuznach, to show Eleanor where her parents spent their honeymoon.
They stop in Lifege, visiting Utin; depart Sep 22.
M and Eleanor arrive back in London.
M and Eleanor are in Carlsbad (see <— :24 for contacts there).
Glaser de Willebrord sends M a report on the state of the movement in Belgium.

M writes Bracke proposing he publish a German edn of Lissagaray’s history of the Paris Commune, mentioning J. Grunzig as possible translator. (Lissagaray has authorized M to make arrangements for a German trans; the French edn is still to appear in autumn.)
In response to Bracke’s concern (letter of Sep 27) about a history of the Commune being written by B. Becker, M argues that it cannot be favored over Lissagaray’s firsthand account.
E begins working on the first part of Anti-Dühring (#E23) [<- :13; -* 77:4). For his preparatory writings, see #E24.
E returns to London.
Leo Frankel, now editor of the Budapest Arbeiter-Wochen-Chronik, asks M for advice on attitude toward the anarchists’ attempt at rapprochement with the Social-Democracy.

The anarchist international congress in Bern proposes calling a Universal Socialist Congress in 1877, i.e., uniting the disintegrating remnant of the anarchist movement with the growing socialist movement.

In view of the unity blandishments being offered by the anarchists [«— :21] in connection with their forthcoming Bern congress (Oct 26-30), to which the German party is sending Vahlteich as unofficial representative, M warns Liebknecht against rapprochement with this rump of the anarchist movement.

M writes Lavrov about the projected establishment of a new periodical on Russian affairs in English, to influence British public opinion, ed by P. D. Golochvastov and Prince Meshchersky. (M’s letter is partly pubd in Lavrov’s Vperyod Nov 1.)

In connection with the Serbian uprising, M spurs Liebknecht to write an article attacking Russia's role and Bismarck’s foreign policy, and gives him advice on it. (Liebknecht’s article appears in Volksstaat Oct 13.)
M replies to Barry’s request of Oct 11 for advice on his leading article on foreign affairs in Morning Advertiser.
M points to Laveleye’s critique of Capital in Revue des Deux Mondes (Sep 1, article on German socialism) as an example of “the idiocy of our bourgeois 'thinkers’ ” (letter to Lavrov).
about: Laveleye_Emile Louis Victor baron de,Revue des Deux Mondes

text: M will resume work on Vol. 2 in a few days—so E writes to Kugelmann. "If you wanted to correct all the silly things that circulate in academic circles about M, you would have your work cut out for you.”
M drops Grunzig as a possible translator of Lissagaray [«- :27], and later this month entrusts the trans to Isolde Kurz [-» 77:1].

E approves J. P. Becker's position on rejecting anarchist overtures [«— :29]; building a strong class party in a country is more important right now than international organizn; meanwhile, at this juncture of relative peace, M&E are giving priority to producing the necessary scientific works.
M asks Carl Hirsch (in Paris) to send him reports on the French movement.
M sends Collet, at his request, info on Gladstone’s Russian policy, for use in the Diplomatic Rev.
The last installment of E’s series on W. Wolff (#E918) [«- :22] is pubd.
M suffers badly from rheumatism and bronchitis.
Writing to his brother Hermann, E analyzes the situation in the Balkans and comes to the conclusion that a Russo-Turkish war is bound to break out.

In a letter to J. P. Becker, E criticizes both the current English TU movement, which is absorbed in petty economic issues, and the unity maneuvers of the Bakuninist remnant of anarchism—’’with them, no peace is possible.”
M gets several visits from Kovalevsky. On Dec 12, the two of them visit E.
(rec’d c.18) The NY Labor Standard (McDonnell) once more requests M to contribute articles.
Mrs. M writes her third article on the London theater [«- :7] for the Frankfurter Ztg und Handelsblatt, "Shakespearean studies in England”; pubd Jan 3.
M reads a number of works on common property and land ownership forms in Spain and other countries (for details, see-» :40).
J. C. Juta, M’s brother-in-law, and his son Henry, of Cape Town, visit M in London.
M renews his BM Library card (not in Chronicle; from Higgins 2017, n42)
In the Reichstag elections the German party's vote goes up 40%; the number of deputies increases from 9 to 12.

In three letters written today (to Bracke, Eh*. Fleckles, Dr. Freund) M expresses great satisfaction over this electoral victory, noting esp that the bourgeoisie in England and other countries is scared and impressed [—► :6].

On the basis of info from Utin (letter of Dec 17), M writes Kovalevsky (in Moscow) with a plea to help get a lawyer for the husband (I. M. Davydovsky) of E. L. Tomanovskaya (Dmitri-yeva); he is in danger of being sent to Siberia.
Vorwärts begins the serial publ of Part I (#E23) [—►:18],
E sends Liebknecht the last batch of ms for Part I.
Her third article of reportage on the London theater [<- 76:37] is pubd in Frankfurter Ztg und Handelsblatt [-> :8.5].
In connection with the Russo-Turkish conflict, M takes up intensive reading on the Eastern Question, e.g., Slade. .

M pumps his anti-Gladstone critique into Barry, who is now a correspondent of the Standard, and uses him to get an expos6 of Gladstone’s Russophile foreign policy into the conservative press, in articles on the Eastern Question. For example, on Feb 3 the Whitehall Rev pubs an article by Barry which M had helped him write; this article is reprinted in several other papers [-» :9).
Lissagaray sends E his thanks for the “brilliant note."

(or 13) E writes a report (#E436) for Bignami on the S-D party victory in the Reichstag election [<- :2J; it is read at the Second Congress of the Northern Italian Federation, Milan, Feb 17-18; pubd in La Plebe Feb 26.
E writes a note (#E527) about page 29 of Lissagaray’s history of the Commune, dealing with Thiers's armistice of Oct 30,1870, and sends it to Lissagaray.
M gets a number of visits by Utin’s wife.
M and Lavrov meet and correspond a number of times (during this period, eight letters by M to Lavrov).
Prof. H. Graetz [«-76:24) writes M a thank-you note, full of esteem, for the copy of Capital, photos, and other things sent by M.
Her fourth article of theater reportage |<— :5.5], “Shakespeare’s Richard III in London’s Lyceum Theater,” is sent in to Frankfurter Ztg und Handelsblatt; pubd Feb 8 [—► :20.5).
E stays in Brighton with his companion, who is ill.
Vanity Fair pubs an anti-Gladstone article written by Barry with M’s help [<— :6).
Writing to E, M describes his influence on Barry’s writings.

For the benefit of the Irish M. P., K. O’Clery, whom M has agitated on the subject of Russian persecutions and atrocities esp in Poland, M asks Lavrov to write a piece surveying this topic in recent years [-* : 13).
Danielson asks M to write an article on Russian land ownership for the Otechestvenniye Zapiski.
Hirsch and Castelnau (in Paris) ask M to write for their projected workers’ paper; M declines, for lack of time. (The paper does not materialize, anyway.)
M sends E the first part of the chapter he is writing for Anti-Dühring (Ch. 10 of Part II) criticizing Dühring’s conceptions on the history of polit eco |—► :30).

At M’s urging (letter of Mar 3), E writes an article, “In Italy" (#E373), on the need for a workers’ party as against anarchism: “behind the preachment of anarchy and self-rule lay hidden the claim by a few wire-pullers to take dictatorial command over the whole working-class movement” (pubd in Vorwärts Mar 16).
M resumes work on Vol. 2; he makes excerpts from his earlier mss.
Collet’s son and daughter visit M.
Prof. Beesly visits M; Beesly agrees to Lavrov’s writing for the Fortnightly Rev.
Lavrov’s article on Russian persecutions, written at M s request |<- :9), is pubd in Vanity Fair in French, “La justice en Russie" (—> :16).

Writing to Bracke three days before Russia’s declaration of war against Turkey, M expresses the fear that Prussia has made a secret agreement with Russia, and complains that the movement pays too little attention to the Eastern Question and the danger of war.
G. M. Calberla sends M his just-pubd work on him, together with a request for M’s opinion of it.
E writing to Liebknecht and M writing to Bracke, both object strongly to the way in which E’s Anti-Dühring (#E23) is being pubd in Vorwärts: as space-filler, in dribs and drabs, disconnectedly.
The info on Russian persecutions supplied by Lavrov and M [-<— :9J is used by O’Clery in two speeches in the House of Commons.
M receives from Sorge the NYDT articles written by himself and E; this collection is from Weydemeyer’s papers.
Part I of #E23 ends publ in Vorwärts after 20 installs H :21J.
E makes notes on the composition and distribution of the Russian army in the Russo-Turkish war.
M, suffering from insomnia and nerves, plans to take a curative trip to Neuenahr, since Carlsbad is too expensive.
She writes her fifth (last) article of theater reportage [<- :8.5J for the Frankfurter Ztg und Handelsblatt, “From the London theater”; pubd May 25.
E and his sick companion stop in Brighton.
E writes Part II (Polit Eco) of #E23; for the chapter written by M, see «— :10 (pubd —► :27).
E drafts the passage on “Infantry tactics . . .” (#E25), later replaced by a shorter passage. (For date, cf Register.)
At Bracke’s request, E writes a short biographical sketch of M for an almanac (#E406); pubd in 1878.

While in France the conflict sharpens between the republicans and the monarchists, with danger of a monarchist coup by MacMahon, Liebknecht’s line in Y'onvärts is that monarchy or republic makes no difference to the working class; an article by Hasenclever is even entitled “Down with the republic!"

E writes to Liebknecht in criticism of this line: it is best for the workers’ movement to develop under the bourgeois republic; the return of monarchy would push republicanism to the fore instead of socialism.
Liebknecht pubs a series of articles “Reds vs Blues" which, in M&E’s view, repeats Hasenclever’s nonsense.
M&E exchange letters lamenting the position being taken by “stupid Wilhelm” [Liebknecht]. M reports that Hirsch is furious at the Y'onvdrts position.
Carl Hirsch, visiting from Paris, meets several times with M during the week, and informs him on economic and political developments in France and on the situation in the German party.

Writing to E, M greets the outbreak of a militant strike movement in the US and its clashes with the state; this may be the start of a “serious workers’ party” which would ally itself with the blacks and the western farmers.
F. Wiede asks M (July 9) and E (July 10) to write for his planned periodical Die Neue Gesellschaft.

M tells E he will decline because its prospectus shows it will be a bad journal; M would like to see a “really scientific socialist journal” which i.a. would “expose the utter ignorance of professors.”
E writes Wiede declining on ground of lack of time; M also declines, July c.25-26.
The editors of Zukunft, which will start Oct 1, write M&E asking their collaboration, but sign no names. M refuses to answer this “anonymous circular.”
E criticizes the Zukunft project in a letter to Liebknecht [—►:37].
Johannes Wedde visits M and renews the invitation. M is also asked by J. Most. M refuses, criticizing Höchberg’s reform socialism and pro-Dühring tendency.
A pamphlet edn of Part I (only) is pubd in Leipzig; see Register for details.
Part II [«— :21] begins publ in Vonvdrts (until Dec 30).
M reads books by the Russian economist and statistician I. I. Kaufman and K. Knies’ work Das Geld.

M reads Mehring’s brochure Zur Geschichte der deutschen Socialdemokratie (1877) and another on Treitschke (1875); he considers the latter “very tiresomely and shallowly written” but making some points of interest.
E goes to Manchester for a few days.
E and his sick companion sojourn in Ramsgate.
E sends M £100 for his trip to Neuenahr.
M writes E about his efforts to find other material by Owen and material by and about the French Utopians.
M sends E the second part of the chapter he is doing for Anti-Dühring (Ch. 10 of Part II) [«— :10). He also sends along Quesnay’s Tableau Economique with some annotations of his own.
E begins writing Part III; he will finish this Mar/Apr of next year. (For publ. see—► 78:16.)

To help E on the section “Socialism," M goes through and excerpts six pamphlets by Owen and four years of his organ The Crisis, also Macnab’s The new views of Mr. Owen of Lanark (source: KMC; see —> :44).

J. K. F. Lingenau, a German socialist, 1849 emigrant to the US, dies in St. Louis, leaving a legacy of $7000 in cash to the German Social-Democratic party; the executors named are five party leaders and M. Since the executors want to give Sorge full powers, while the Bismarck government works to quash the legacy (eventually successfully), M will be involved with this affair for the next two years [—►79:47].
Uriele Cavagnari (in Naples) writes M asking for authorization for his Italian trans.

ln Neuenahr, staying at the Hotel Flora, M gets acquainted with Dr. Richard Schmitz, who agrees with M’s own opinion that his medical trouble is “of a nervous nature,” and recommends the Black Forest.
M, accompanied by his wife (who is ill) and daughter Eleanor, departs for Neuenahr, to take the waters (till Sep c.26).
Schorlemmer visits M.
M, who has been in touch with Barry about attending the World Socialist Congress (Ghent, Sep 9-15), writes Bracke to introduce Barry to the German delegates.

Until about this date M remains in Neuenahr with his wife and Eleanor [«- :33). (On Sep 27 M is again dating correspondence from London.) Note: KMC has M sojourning in the Black Forest Sep 4-20, but its references do not support this claim, which is not accepted in MEW Daten.
In a letter to Sorge, M opines that Russia is on the threshold of an epochal upheaval, hastened by the Russo-Turkish war crisis: “This time the revolution begins in the East....”
Lizzie Burns’s health begins to decline drastically, presaging her death [—► 78:35].
E and his companion are in Scotland; as for their whereabouts, a later letter shows that on Sep 20 they are in the Edinburgh area.

Writing to Sorge, M describes his dissatisfaction with the “rotten spirit” advancing in the leadership of the German party, stemming from the rotten compromise of 1875 with the Lassalleans: an influx of intellectuals is diluting program and theory; Höchberg and his Zukunft [«- :26) represent this tendency.

In a letter to Bracke, M again laments the “miserable program” of Höchberg’s Zukunft, its idealist phrases, future-society-mongering, etc.; it is a case of a bourgeois (Höchberg) buying his way into party influence.
Franckenberg, for the Deutsche Handwerkerverein in Porto Alegre, Brazil, sends M a report on the activity of the local S-D group, and asks him to establish connections with the German party.
After much labor trying to save Kurz’s German trans [«- 77:1], M writes Bracke that it is too error-filled to be usable; revision of the German version should be handed over to W. Bios.

M sends Sorge a list of changes to be made in the text of Vol. 1, intended for K. D. A. Douai who is supposed to be working on an English trans; some of the changes are indicated in the German edn, others marked in the French trans.

In no. 10 of the periodical Otechestvenniye Zapiski (St. Petersburg)—sent to M by Danielson—Mikhailovsky’s essay “KM before the tribunal of Mr. Zhukovsky” ascribes to M the view that to attain socialism Russia must first destroy the peasant common property of the village community and enter on the road to capitalist development [—> :41).

M drafts a rejoinder (#M464) to Mikhailovsky [«- :40] in the form of a letter to the Otechestvenniye Zapiski: he denies that the analysis of western European capitalism in Capital automatically applies to every other country and part of the world; for Russia, history is still open-ended; the historical sketch of capitalist development in Capital is not "a general historico-philo-sophical theory whose supreme virtue consists in being suprahistorical.” But he does not sent the letter [-► 84:20].

In a letter to W. Bios, M comments on Blos’s statement (letter sent to M on Nov 6) that M&E are “more popular figures” in Germany than they may be aware. We don’t give a fig for popularity, writes M; because of “aversion to any cult of personalities” during the period of the International, expressions of appreciation were ignored or rebuked. Back in the Communist League “everything tending to further the superstition of authority” was removed from the by-laws, the very opposite of Lassalle’s practice.

M sends a thank-you letter, on behalf of himself and E, to Moses Hess’s wife Sibylle, who sent them copies of Hess’s posthumous work Dynamische Stofflehre. (M previously acknowledged the gift on Oct 25.)
M studies the works of Robert Owen (source: MEW Daten; cf the similar entry under Aug A from KMC; these prob refer to the same notebook material).

M begins preparing the first chapter of Vol. 2 for the printer (MEW dating: Nov to next July). KMC, under Oct 26, has the following entry: “M begins making a clean copy of the first chapter (three pages).” Then, under Nov-Dec, KMC also states: "M works up a small part of the ms of Volume 2 (17 pages) so that it is almost ready for printing.”

Writing to S. Schott, M explains that the order in which he has drafted Capital, beginning with the ‘‘third, historical part” (Theories of surplus value), is the reverse of the order presented to the public.
(around the end of this year): The German trans of Lissagaray’s book, on which M has spent much time [«- :1], is pubd in Brunswick.
Jaclard sends M an invitation to write articles on the German and English movements for the journal Slovo, scheduled to appear in St. Petersburg in Jan.
Part II of Anti-Dühring (#E23) ends serial publ in Vorwärts [<- :27).
The Labor Standard (NY) begins serial publ of Weydemeyer’s English trans of J. Most’s abridgment of Capital (ST/51), which M helped revise [«- 76:18]: serialization ends Mar 10 [-> 78:30].

In a letter to J. P. Becker, E expresses gratification over Swiss progress toward the formation of an independent workers’ party, and presents two serious criticisms of the German party: its attitude toward the crisis of republicanism in France [«- 77:23J, and the dominance of ignorant intellectuals as its theoreticians, an ‘‘infantile disease” of the movement.
E sends Bignami a piece on the workers’ movement in a number of countries (#E751); pubd in La Plebe Jan 22.
(around beginning of year): E writes a study on “Natural science in the spirit world,” which will become a part of his Dialectics of nature (#E221).

At Liebknecht’s request (Jan 22) for articles on this subject, M sends two substantial letters dealing with a number of associated issues— support of Turkey against Russia in the war, counting on Russian defeat and revolution; the play of big-power politics; the impact on the British party system; etc. (Liebknecht uses parts of these letters, without M’s name, as an appendix to the second edn of his brochure Zur orientalischen Frage, with his postscript note dated Feb 27; pubd Mar A.)
Hirsch (in Paris) sends M info on the French movement, the difficulties of publishing L’Egalitä, etc.; he asks E to write for the paper.
E writes a long essay, “The workingmen of Europe in 1877” (#E922), a survey of the movement in a number of countries (pubd Mar 3-31; -* :10).
Mrs. M is ill; she goes to Manchester for several weeks for medical treatment.
E’s “Workingmen of Europe in 1877“ (#E922) [«- :8] is pubd in five parts in the Labor Standard (NY).
The Labor Standard (NY) ends publ of J. Most’s abridgment of Capital (ST/51) («-77:47;->:30].
E finishes writing the third and last part (pubd —> :16).
M corresponds with S. Schott (in Frankfurt), who sends him newly pubd material on the development of German industry and finance.
M reads and excerpts 1.1. Kaufman’s Teoriya i praktika bankovovo dela, and Kaufman’s essay in Nachalo on the Russian peasant commune.
M&E meet with Liebknecht, who is visiting London.

In a letter to Bracke, E sets forth his view of Bismarckian social reform and statification as a means of increasing the power of the existing state for reactionary ends; statification can be either reactionary or progressive.
For Vol. 2, M studies a number of works on the history and theory of money.
Kovalevsky visits M at home; they discuss the news of Hödel’s assassination attempt (May 11) against the kaiser.
E drafts a preface (#E222) for the first book edn of Anti-Dühring (which will appear in July); but this draft will be replaced [—► :20] and consigned by E to the materials for Dialectics of nature.
Vorwärts begins publ of the third and last part (until July 7).
For the editors of L’EgalitS, Labusquifere writes M asking for an article for a planned special issue. (M is unable to comply because of illness.)
For his work on Capital M makes a conspectus of statistical sources he has received from the US.
As part of his study of agrochemistry and geology, M reads and excerpts works by J. B. Jukes and J. F. W. Johnston on agronomy and geology; also, J. G. Koppe and Hlubeck (KMC dating: May).
read: Jukes_Joseph Beete,Johnston_James Finlay Weir,Koppe_Johann Gottlieb,Hlubek_Franz Xaver Wilhelm

text: A Dr. Nobiling makes an unsuccessful assassination attempt on Kaiser Wilhelm; coming on top of Hödel’s [*- :15], this will give the Bismarck government the pretext for imposing the Anti-Socialist Law illegalizing the S-D party. This is the context for M’s exposä (see next) of Bismarck’s right-hand man Lothar Bucher and his “communist” past.
M writes a letter to the London Daily News detailing Bucher’s political record (#M370); pubd June 13; reprinted in Germany June CD.
Bucher replies with a “Statement” in the Norddeutsche Allgemeine Ztg.
M writes a rejoinder (#M739); pubd in Germany June 29 and July A.
E writes the preface (#E26) which will be pubd in the book edn of this work (pubd July).
M sees Thomas Allsop often during this period.
M again takes up the study of geology; he reads and excerpts i.a. J. B. Jukes’s Student’s manual of geology.

M has a number of talks with the journalist J. S. Glennie (introduced by Fumivall); he gives Glennie material on “socialism as one of the political powers of the present time” for Glennie’s book Europe and Asia (pubd 1879).
M sees Barry often, gives him advice on his articles and lectures about German socialism.
M receives a letter from Sorge on the SLP and German-American socialists and on American affairs in general.
A pamphlet edn of Parts II and III is pubd in Leipzig (for Part I, see <— 77:27).
The first book edn of the work as a whole (#E23) is pubd in Leipzig, with the new preface (#E26) [<-:20).
M sends the reply to the magazine’s editor. Sir James T. Knowles, who rejects it July 21 [-+ :29j.
The editors of Nachalo, writing to E, invite M to write for their publ.
